PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) expresses its support for United States Senators Edward Kennedy and Mark Hatfield in their sponsorship of a motion calling on President Reagan to propose to the Soviet Union a mutual freeze on the testing, production and deployment of nuclear weapons; and
(2) calls on the Government to advise President Reagan of its support for this motion as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House notes with concern and dismay the final recommendations of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in relation to the upgrading of the Hobart Airport and calls on the Government to-
(1) erect a separate international terminal, and

(2) upgrade the runway, taxi way and terminal apron to permit unrestricted operations by B727 aircraft and provide facilities to enable Hobart Airport to be used as an alternative port for wide-body operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its disapproval of the deplorably inhumane slaughter of baby harp seals in Canada for the purposes of fashion and cosmetics, and
(2) urges the Government to-
(a) ban the importation of harp seal by-products into Australia, regardless of whether this country is at present a market for such products, and

(b) express the disapproval of this House through Australian United Nations delegates moving a motion in the UN General Assembly that calls for support of an international ban on the slaughter of the harp seal before it becomes an endangered species.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Milton proceeding to give notice of motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The notice is out of order.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: Is it normal practice for inspectors of the Industrial Relations Bureau to record that they have completed an award inspection even when there are no workers actually employed under that award at a particular enterprise? If so, what degree of overstatement is consequently involved in the official figures showing total inspections undertaken by the Bureau? What is the Bureau's official policy concerning prior notification being given to enterprises which are to be visited by Bureau inspectors? Can he assure this House that such a policy is in line with the conventions of the International Labour Organisation in this area? Finally, is the Minister aware of any instances in which successful complainants have not been fully compensated for wage underpayments because of long delays between the lodging of complaints with the Bureau and the commencement of legal prosecution?

—The question asked by the honourable gentleman is a detailed one. It will require me to refer it to the Director of the Bureau. I will do that and give the honourable gentleman an answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer to the fact that small businesses-50 per cent of them are farmers-are being asked by bankers to use bank backed money bills to raise carry-on finance and the fact that the 90-day bill is selling for 20 per cent and the bank brokerage fee is now 4 1/2 per cent, making the effective interest rate 24 1/2 per cent. As the Treasurer did not seem to agree with my calling during the adjournment debate last night for complete deregulation, statutory reserve deposit releases to term and farm development or the lowering of the Reserve Bank of Australia limit of $500,000 for imported capital, I ask: Will the Treasurer consider lifting the Government' s money supply, now at 11 per cent, to help ease pressure on interest rates, as these extraordinary high rates are fueling inflation and making it difficult for small businesses to carry on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I thought that the prescription urged by my honourable friend from Maranoa would, in fact, lead to a fall in interest rates other than in the very short term I might be attracted to what he is putting. Unfortunately, it is quite wrong to believe that easing monetary policies will lead, in other than the very short term, to reduction in interest rates. I gently point out to the honourable gentleman that the effective interest rate that he was talking about could be affected somewhat by the availability of tax deductibility of certain business expenses. I think that ought to be borne in mind in some of the statistics that he used.

ANSWER.PARA: The circumstances of present high interest rates have been explained on a number of occasions. They cannot be isolated from the present high level of interest rates around the world. The idea that Australia can live in sublime isolation from international economic forces is quite wrong. If the prescription urged by the honourable gentleman were, in fact, adopted there might for a very short period be some easing of interest rate pressure, but in the medium to longer term it would underwrite higher inflation and therefore return, in my judgment and the judgment of the Government, still higher interest rates which surely is not the objective the honourable gentleman seeks.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Hayden proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Hayden-I disagree with your ruling, Mr Speaker. How can the question be out of order? It is a very important matter to know the condition of the Government. You do not know, I do not know and the Prime Minister is uncertain. The Parliament and the public are entitled to know something about it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The reason the question is out of order is that no Minister can be questioned in this House in relation to internal party matters. If I were to depart from that ruling it would bring party matters into this chamber, which would be wrong.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Hayden-I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. This transcends mere party matters. It is a matter of fealty declared by a senior Minister of the Government to the Prime Minister and the Government. It is a matter of the condition of the Government, its cohesion, its stability, its capacity to run the affairs of the country. I merely ask the Minister concerned whether he means it this time or whether he will change his mind tomorrow, the day after or a little later as he has on other matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman has asked his question. I have ruled it out of order. I stand by the ruling.

—Is the Prime Minister aware that South African Airways operates regular flights to 28 countries in Africa, Europe, North and South America and, of course, Australia? Is the Prime Minister also aware that 22 international airlines, from African, European and American countries, fly to South Africa? Against this background, why does the Federal Government continue to refuse to allow Qantas to fly between Australia and South Africa? Finally, is the Prime Minister aware that this Indian Ocean route is extremely busy, with high passenger loadings and that, in effect, the Government's refusal to allow Qantas to share in this profitable trade is achieving nothing more than to benefit the very government and system that we are supposed to oppose? Or, to put it in another way, have we not cut off our Qantas nose to spite our own face?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas is operating to Mauritius and it is hoped that it will extend such operation to routes in southern Africa and further on. I know that Qantas has been examining the matter. The Government was concerned that Qantas should not re-establish its direct link with South Africa. I think the reasons for that are well known. We do not wish to, and do not, encourage trade with South Africa. Although there is no prohibition of it, there is no active promotion of trade with South Africa. We believe that maximum pressure should be exerted against South Africa, to seek to break down the system of apartheid. I think we all know that there is a degree of racial intolerance amongst all countries, but most countries around the world, by law, practice or custom, seek to diminish and eradicate racial intolerance. That is certainly the approach of the States and the Commonwealth of Australia. It is certainly the approach of the overwhelming majority of Australian citizens of all political complexions. The difference in South Africa is simply that racial intolerance, bigotry and discrimination are enshrined in the law in a multitude of ways. People cannot move without a police pass. People of the wrong colour cannot live in certain areas. People of the wrong colour might be allowed to get a job in an area, but their wives and families have to stay 300 miles behind, in the hills. The honourable gentleman may know people who work in South Africa. An engineer, the son of some people with whom I am on friendly terms, does in fact work in South Africa, and the letters that are sent back describe, whether it be on the playing field or whatever, kinds of discrimination which Australians would certainly find abhorrent.

ANSWER.PARA: Sir Robert Menzies indicated in earlier discussions, going back I suppose 20 or 30 years, that he believed that the whole system of apartheid was abhorrent and doomed to the most ghastly failure because, in all its simplicity, the South Africans were saying that they would give black Africans educational and economic equality but never, of course, political equality. Therein is the certainty that apartheid must one day fail, because the more people have educational or economic equality, the less will they be prepared to accept or tolerate political inequality. Whatever view one might have of the immorality of apartheid, logically, and on a straight analysis of what apartheid is about, it is doomed to failure. Therefore, successive Australian governments over time have sought, with many other nations, to exert pressure in relation to South Africa so that there may be a modification and change of policy; so that something that is abhorrent to the very nature of people and of human relationships can be modified and changed by evolution rather than by much rougher and more difficult means if there should be no change on the part of the South African Government. It is based on our attitude to the South African regime, to its nature, to the fact that apartheid and discrimination are enshrined in law, that we take certain actions that we otherwise would not. As I have said on a number of occasions, it is not South Africa that is a bulwark against communism in Southern Africa. Rather, it presents an invitation to communism because the nature of the system that it has established invites communism to overthrow something that is repugnant to the whole human race.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence: Is it a fact that there are considerable inadequacies in defence capital infrastructure in Western Australia ? Is it a fact that there is justification, in terms of a posture of Australian defence self-reliance and the proper dispersal around the continent of Australia 's defence assets, for bringing HMAS Stirling to full utilisation by Australian submarines and warships? If this is the case, and in the past the Minister has acknowledged that it is, will he undertake in his review of defence expenditure to exempt the development and utilisation of defence facilities in Western Australia from current and forthcoming defence expenditure restraints? Further, noting the announced savings in planned expenditure for defence capital infrastructure in the area of site acquisition and buildings of more than $2m, will his Department purchase forthwith a site in north-west Western Australia for a patrol boat base previously appearing in Budget Estimates as anticipated to cost $250,000?

—I cannot accept some of the assumptions that my honourable friend makes. I hope he can be encouraged to acknowledge the fact that in the planning of defence capabilities in the country it is not merely a matter of identifying a geographic requirement; the principal requirement on which all defence planning must be based is a strategic assessment. My honourable friend will be aware of the fact that both ships and aircraft are deployed at frequent intervals on exercises in Western Australia. It has been put to me as a matter of seriousness by our colleagues from Tasmania in this House that Tasmania, by dint of its geographic position, postulates certain defence requirements.
—Hear, hear!
—Well, there it is from my honourable friend the Minister for the Capital Territory.
—Is he from Tasmania?

—We are told about that quite frequently. There is a very substantial capital investment in Western Australia. As far as the patrol boat base that the honourable gentleman referred to is concerned, a site has been identified. The Department of Defence is a very considerable spender of taxpayers' money. In acknowledging the fact that the country faces economic difficulties, the Department of Defence, consistent with strategic requirements, must make its contribution to the overall economic welfare of the country. I assure the honourable gentleman that what he has said will be kept in mind by me and certainly by my Department in planning the defence capabilities of the nation.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that Zimbabwe's Prime Minister, Mr Mugabe, is seeking to establish a one-party system of government in Zimbabwe? Has the Minister advised the Government of Zimbabwe of Australia's concern at this development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that for some time Mr Mugabe has been advocating a one- party state as the most appropriate form of government for Zimbabwe. Mr Mugabe is also on record as saying that that objective would not be imposed either hastily or illegally. He has said that he wants that discussed as widely as possible. In that connection I note that recently the Minister for Legal and Parliamentary Affairs in Zimbabwe told the Press that the Zimbabwean Government intends to re-examine the Constitution. But he also reaffirmed Mr Mugabe's assurance that any changes would be made constitutionally and in consultation with the white members of parliament. I am aware of concern that has been expressed in Australia about the possible dangers to democracy in Zimbabwe.

ANSWER.PARA: Relations between our countries are close. I think it is true to say that Zimbabweans have a high regard for Australia particularly bearing in mind the role played by Australia, and particularly the Prime Minister, in achieving their independence and because of the assistance we have given them since independence. Many Australian teachers are working there. So all in all Australians are interested in what is happening in that country. I am sure that I am speaking for all of us when I say that we hope the democratic processes through which independence was achieved will continue there. Through our High Commission in Salisbury we have made known at a high level to the Zimbabwean Government the concern being felt in Australia over the question of adhering to due constitutional processes in that country. Australia and indeed all friends of Zimbabwe who wish Zimbabwe well look to a continuation of the policies of reconciliation, which have distinguished that country since independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and refer to recent public statements made by him advocating a means test for pensioners and a reduction in company tax. Were these statements made with the prior knowledge and approval of his colleagues, the Minister for Social Security and the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer in the first place is that the statement on pensions was made with the full knowledge and clearance of the Minister for Social Security. The answer in the second place is according to the Hansard of yesterday's date when I answered a comparable question. I pointed out then to one honourable gentleman opposite that that statement was made in the ambit of the Industries Assistance Commission report on budgetary assistance which will be before the Government shortly. Both statements are within the aegis and framework of Government policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. I refer him to the aerial coastal surveillance contracts in northern Australia. A number of contractors have been awarded tenders for this work in the past. Can the Minister confirm that similar tender arrangements will be made when the current contracts expire? Can he give an assurance that there will be no limitation on the number of contracts or arrangements for the extent of the work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for the Northern Territory would be aware, the Government has completed its consideration of the report into coastal surveillance. There has been an ongoing review of the coastal surveillance program for some considerable time. Indeed, since the Government took a decision on the recommendations of that report numerous discussions have been carried out between the State Ministers and officers associated with the problem of surveillance in the various States and officers of my Department. There has been a generally favourable reaction to the decision that the Government has taken. The Government has decided to strengthen the administrative and managerial procedures to increase the efficiency of the upgraded arrangements which were originally introduced in 1978.

ANSWER.PARA: The existing tenders expire between September of this year and March next year. New tender documents are being drawn up. Fresh tenders will be called as the existing tenders expire. We will continue to use the resources of the Department of Defence and civil tendering arrangements which are undoubtedly the most economic way to provide a valuable coastal surveillance service for this country . The results so far have been favourable and with the new arrangements that will apply we believe that the operations of coastal surveillance will improve even further. With the economies of scale that will be available as a result of these arrangements I feel sure that we will maximise the benefits of the existing resources available from the Department of Defence and the private sector to the advantage of the Australian taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the Begin Government's policies and actions on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip will the Minister during his forthcoming visit make clear to the Israeli Prime Minister that Australia's participation in the Sinai force is contingent upon all parties observing both the letter and the spirit of the Camp David Accords?

—Both I and the Prime Minister on several occasions in this House have emphasised the central importance of the Palestinian issue in resolving Middle East problems. There are plenty of examples of that on record. During the time in which the Government was deciding on participation in the Sinai force it was made clear to all parties that we expected them to make a continued and sustained effort to resolve the Palestinian problem through the Camp David Accords process. I regret that it is apparent that very little, if any, progress has been made in that direction. It remains our view that there must be a sustained and continued effort on the part of all parties to make progress in that area just as much as in the case of the withdrawal from the Sinai.

—Has the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs seen reports of plans to spend $1m in Tasmania on a scheme described as a 'job creation scheme'? Has any assessment been made of the value of that kind of scheme? If it has value, will the Commonwealth join in the scheme and assist in overcoming the serious problem of youth unemployment in the important but poorly governed State of Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports that the Tasmanian Government proposes to spend $1m, I think, on an artificial job creation scheme. It can be described only as a waste of taxpayers' money for the simple reason that schemes of that sort, both in Australia and overseas, have been proved to be quite unsuccessful in reducing unemployment. Indeed, the former Labor Federal Government had such a scheme which was called the Regional Employment Development scheme. While that scheme was in operation employment in this country fell. It was one of the very rare times in the history of this country that employment fell. Not only did employment fall during that period but also unemployment doubled. It is not very surprising that the Labor Government abolished the very scheme that it introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there is a lot that a Government can do. The Tasmanian Government was given the opportunity to contribute financially to a very valuable work preparation centre and skills training centre for young unemployed people in Hobart. It is conducted by the Centacare agency at Mount St Canice. The Tasmanian Government, and in particular the responsible Minister, Mr Aulich, have, I regret to say, on frequent occasions rejected all invitations to contribute to that very worthwhile scheme. They have shown a completely callous attitude towards young unemployed people in that State. Not only is it a callous attitude to take; it is extremely hypocritical to come along in the twilight hours in the life of the Tasmanian Government and now say, not having contributed when they could have to a worthwhile scheme that exists already, that they will waste $1m on a fanciful, phoney job creation scheme which is doomed to failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer and relates to an answer he gave this morning to an earlier question asked by the honourable member for Maranoa. Did the Treasurer imply by his answer that long-term interest rates were determined by the current supply of and demand for liquidity rather than the current and long term or anticipated rate of inflation? Is the short term rate of interest determined essentially by the current level of liquidity and the demand for liquidity? If the short term rate of interest is to be held down, is it necessary for the money supply to grow at a rate which will be sufficient to accommodate the current rate of inflation together with current growth? Is the money supply at the present time growing at a rate of 10.6 per cent which is about 3 per cent less than the combined inflation rate plus growth rate? If this is so, without any further increase in the money supply, must we anticipate a further increase in short term interest rates?

—I will start at the beginning of the honourable member's question. I assure him that I did not imply anything in my answer to the honourable member for Maranoa; I stated what I have always believed to be the case, that is, that the long term level of interest rates is influenced by the level of inflation. Anybody who believes that we can bring down interest rates without adopting policies that affect inflation is not being realistic. The Government remains very much of the view that controlling the rate of growth of the money supply is a major weapon in controlling inflation. It believes that, if in the interest of buying short term relief for interest rates we let go the money supply, we merely underwrite in the longer term higher inflation and thus, in the longer term, much higher interest rates.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO DRUG TRAFFICKING

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister advise the House whether the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking are wide enough to enable an investigation to be conducted into the affairs of the Nugan Hand bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago the Minister for Administrative Services had discussions with the royal commissioner. As I understand it, the view of the royal commissioner was that the present terms of reference are wide enough to cover those matters. It is worth noting that in the terms of reference there is mention of a Terence John Clark and persons associated with him, and further on the use made by Terence John Clark and persons associated with him of banking, financial and other institutions in connection with those activities. When the Acting Prime Minister, in conjunction with the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland-this is a joint Royal Commission-made the announcement about the establishment of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking , he said also that it was envisaged that the judicial inquiry may be given supplementary terms of reference referring to the activities of other drug trafficking groups should the need arise.

ANSWER.PARA: If there is any necessity for that, or if a royal commissioner felt in any sense that there was a need to widen the terms of reference, the Commonwealth would certainly accede to that request. I would be very surprised if the States likewise were not prepared to accede to such a request. But as I understand it, there has not been a request from the royal commissioner or from any of the States at this point to widen the terms of reference because the parties believe that the present terms of reference are wide enough to cover the totality of matters which I believe all members of this House would want to have covered. It is worth noting again that the Commonwealth initiated the Stewart Royal Commission. It is worth noting also that the joint New South Wales-Federal police task force was initiated by the Williams and Woodward royal commissions. Flowing out of these royal commissions the police task force was established. It was at the Commonwealth's initiative, through an approach to Mr Wran, that the terms of reference of that task force were in fact widened. Again, if there were any matters that we felt needed examination, that were not within the terms of reference, they could be widened so long as the New South Wales Government was prepared to agree.

If there are any honourable members who believe they have information which would assist the vastly important work of the Royal Commission or of the task force, it would obviously be helpful to make that information available to one or the other. I think it is worth noting also that, consistent with what I have said, if the Leader of the Opposition believed the Royal Commission terms of reference were not adequate to examine the matters which he has been seeking to raise during Question Time in this House, I would be prepared to have him discuss those matters with the Attorney-General to see whether the terms of reference should be widened to cover those matters. If there was a need to have them widened to cover those matters, I am sure we could secure the agreement of other parties to have them so widened.

It is still the Commonwealth's view, on the advice available to us, that the terms of reference are wide enough. But if on some of the matters which are apparently available to the Leader of the Opposition he feels otherwise, I make the offer to him: He can discuss the matter with the Attorney-General, or with the other law officer, the Solicitor-General, and if out of that discussion there is evidence that the terms of reference are not wide enough, I will put it to my colleagues and to the other parties concerned to secure a widening of the terms of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the answer that the Prime Minister has just given and in relation to answers that he has given on this subject in the Parliament more recently, I would suggest to him that I would prefer to deal not with the chimneysweep but with the Prime Minister. Therefore, I ask: Is it a fact that the royal commission is not competent to investigate Nugan Hand except insofar as it might be connected to the activities of Terence John Clark? Is it also a fact, as Mr Justice Woodward complained at page 1654 of his report, that the task force has grave limitations on its capacity to investigate drug trafficking in general, let alone the activities that have been raised in this House about Nugan Hand? In view of these facts I ask the Prime Minister, and not one of his subsidiary officers: Will he set up a royal commission which will have effective power and authority to investigate the association of Nugan Hand with gun running and foreign intelligence agencies, as well as narcotics and organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Woodward Royal Commision was a New South Wales royal commission and the Commonwealth has taken many actions as a result of that royal commission. I would be interested to know what actions the New South Wales Government has taken as a result of that royal commission. But I make the point again that in the reference of the Stewart Royal Commission, which has been established in co-operation with a number of States, the advice available to us is that the Royal Commission can examine any matters that are relevant, including the matters that were raised by the Leader of the Opposition. I made the offer that the Leader of the Opposition may like to discuss the terms of reference with the Attorney-General or the Solicitor-General. He was somewhat unnecessarily disparaging of them, but I made that offer for specific reasons. They are the legal officers of the Commonwealth, the first and second legal advisers of the Commonwealth, and therefore they would be able to offer fully professional advice as to whether the terms of the Royal Commission cover the matters which the Leader of the Opposition would want examined.

ANSWER.PARA: I think all members of the House would want these matters examined. I believe the debates have in part been semantic ones because the Leader of the Opposition persists in taking the view that the royal commission established by a number of governments and the task force established by two governments are inadequate for this purpose. It would seem to us totally unnecessary to establish a separate royal commission to cover ground that is already being covered by the Stewart Royal Commission, especially so since we are advised that the terms of reference are adequate.

I repeat the offer: If the Leader of the Opposition, if he likes in conjunction with whatever legal advisers he has within his party, wishes to discuss the matter with the Solicitor-General and the Attorney-General, they can come to a view on legal grounds and not on grounds of political debate in this chamber as to whether terms of reference are adequate to cover all the matters in relation to Nugan Hand. We believe they are wide enough. Our advice is that they are wide enough. We have said and others have said that if there is a need to widen the terms of reference of the Royal Commission to cover related and drug-running groups and all the rest, well then that will happen. Nothing could be plainer than that. I believe the offer to the Leader of the Opposition is a perfectly fair and appropriate one, and if he would co-operate in it we could lay at rest for all time the disputatious argument as to whether these matters are fully examined or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Primary Industry received any representations from the sugar industry or any parts of it that the formula used to determine the domestic retail price of sugar is inadequate and needs review? If he has received such representations, will he please advise what his response has been?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1979 sugar agreement was the first agreement to carry a provision for an objective mechanism to review the domestic sugar price ex refinery. It is a fact that the formula carries within it a capacity to allow for the rising cost of inputs. It is also a fact that the industry has been to me to tell me that it believes the formula does not correctly provide for the increasing prices of fertiliser and fuels and that, therefore, it believes the domestic price of sugar is too low. It is interesting to note that when we were negotiating the formula the Bureau of Agricultural Economics put up a different formula-one similar to the wheat agreement-that would have in fact allowed for a higher domestic price in July of this year when the next rise is to take place.

ANSWER.PARA: It is anticipated that, because of increasing costs, there might be an increase in the domestic price of sugar to about $425 or $435 a tonne. Under the BAE formula it would have been approximately $490 a tonne. The sugar industry has been to me complaining about the formula which it negotiated with the Commonwealth and State governments in 1979. I have said to the industry that I am, of course, prepared to look at it mid-term, but I think it would require one to see the whole life of the agreement, as most of these formulas do, before one could make an objective assessment as to whether industry circumstances require change mid-term. Therefore, it is difficult to open the formula half way through the life of the agreement. I am, of course, prepared to listen to further argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to the statements by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, that he believes the New South Wales Government has a mandate for public funding of political parties? Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that all parties which participated in the New South Wales election have now agreed in principle to the acceptance of public funding? Will the Prime Minister now agree to the setting up of a joint committee of this Parliament to introduce the same system for national elections in Australia?
—I believe the parliamentary members of the Opposition in New South Wales took a contrary view. Our view is not changed.

—Is the Treasurer aware of the Government's intention to introduce legislation to exclude medical practitioners from access to medical benefit payments if they are found guilty by a court of defrauding the system? Is the Treasurer aware that the Department of Health estimates that up to 20 per cent of the payouts made by all the health funds is money that is being dishonestly claimed by the medical profession? Does the Treasurer agree that those who defraud the medical system are also very likely to be cheating on their income tax obligations? Will the Treasurer liaise with the Minister for Health and obtain from him a list of the names of those doctors who the Department of Health believes are into the system, so that they can be investigated by the Commissioner of Taxation?

—I am aware of the very timely and appropriate proposals of my colleague the Minister for Health to deal with people who cheat on the system in the medical area. I agree with the honourable member that people who are prepared to cheat on the system in that way would probably have a disposition to cheat on the system in other ways. I shall take up the matter with the Minister for Health. I do not want to speculate as to what might be possible. I take the opportunity of making the inevitable and, I think, fair observation that the overwhelming majority of the medical profession play by the rules of the game and that their reputation is necessarily impugned by those who do not do so.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Communications. Why has there been such a delay in appointing the advisory committee to the Special Broadcasting Service on ethnic and multi-cultural broadcasting? Is it because the Minister and the SBS Chairman, Sir Nicholas Shehadie, on the one side, and the Prime Minister, backed by Mr Galbally and Mr Petro Georgiou, on the other, cannot agree on the composition of that committee? Why are ethnic communities being denied this access to the SBS while this quarrel within the Government is being resolved?
—There is no delay in the establishment of the committee, and there is no quarrel.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations as Minister representing the Attorney-General. In view of the refusal by a certain Mr Gallagher and other members of the Builders Labourers Federation to give evidence to the royal commission inquiring into the activities of that union, is the Government considering initiating contempt proceedings against them? If so, in view of the fact that some eight weeks or so have expired since the matter was referred to the Attorney-General by the royal commissioner, when can a decision be expected?

—Before I call the Minister, I should indicate to the Minister that the question as framed does not invite an invasion of the issues. The question is in order and I call the Minister to answer in that form.

—I am certainly conscious of the point that you make, Mr Speaker, and I understood the question to be directed to what action the Commonwealth Attorney- General will be taking and when a decision can be expected regarding the failure of certain witnesses who have been subpoenaed to appear before that royal commission. I am not aware of the current position of the Attorney-General's inquiries. I shall refer that matter to him and provide the honourable gentleman with an answer. However, for the information of the House, I note that the Victorian Government, which has also issued a commission to the royal commissioner, has taken proceedings against the witnesses concerned who have not answered the subpoena, and, of course, the Victorian Government is quite entitled to take that action separately from any action that might be taken by the Commonwealth Attorney-General. As we are all conscious, Mr Speaker, the royal commission is an important public inquiry and one would expect, so that the inquiry can be completed to its fullest extent, that all possible witnesses would appear and provide to the royal commission whatever information is available to them. However, I will refer the question to the Attorney-General and report to my colleague as soon as I can.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Communications. Will the television and radio advertisements which form part of the Government's $300,000 housing propaganda program be subject to the electronic black-out prior to the Victorian election? Further, if the advertisements do not include information about the increases in interest rates, is it expected that they will be referred to the Trade Practices Commission as an example of misleading advertising?

—I think the honourable gentleman will probably understand that, if there is to be an examination of whether any material falls within section 116 of the Broadcasting and Television Act, it is necessary for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to adjudicate on it. If the honourable gentleman or anyone else seeks to make a reference, he will do so. I was interested to note only this morning that $1m has been spent in New South Wales to explain the State Government's absolutely deplorable behaviour in not acting with responsibility with regard to power supply in that State. I rather thought that $300,000 for the whole of Australia did not compare unfavourably with that $1m spent by a government which, I understand, is now bankrupt.

—I ask the Minister for Communications whether it is a fact that Telecom Australia is well behind its announced program in New South Wales, in particular in the Hunter Valley. Is this causing great concern to business and the public generally? Can the Minister state whether this is caused by a lack of funds or of materials? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, Telecom has decided that because of the particular problems in some regional areas of New South Wales, of the $20m of additional funds that I spoke of a little while ago in the House being provided for the capital works program of Telecom by a rediversion of funds within its own funds supply, Telecom intends to allocate another $7.7m and to transfer some staff to accelerate capital works and program development in those regions. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) this morning that a submission from me in support of the extension of the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, which is also investigating Terence John Clark and matters associated with his activities, will be accepted. Having made the submission and, I believe, making a very strong series of points in support of the extension of the terms of reference of the inquiry so that effectively it becomes a full inquiry into the Nugan Hand organisations and into allegations of a vast range referring to that matter, I presume that those recommendations will be accepted and the terms of reference expanded.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that the terms of reference for the Stewart Royal Commission as they now stand are, in the considered view of myself and my advisers, inadequate to attend to the matters which have been raised in connection with the Nugan Hand organisation. The Stewart Royal Commission, according to the terms of reference which it has been given, is literally restricted to investigating matters associated with Terence John Clark and his connection with illicit drugs. It may well prove that the Nugan Hand organisation does have some association with Terence John Clark or with his past activities. However, the Nugan Hand activities go well beyond Terence John Clark. As I mentioned in my question this morning, there are matters apart from narcotics and organised crime which relate to allegations about gun running, about the laundering of money which it appears has been earned illegally and the bank's association with foreign intelligence agencies. Any terms of reference which fall short of allowing a royal commission of inquiry to investigate all of those matters-the vast range of very disturbing allegations about Nugan Hand-would be unsatisfactory to me. That is the first point I want to make.

In relation to the second matter which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has constantly referred to-the joint task force of Commonwealth and New South Wales police into Nugan Hand-I find again the Prime Minister's attempts at reassurance unsatisfactory. The joint task force is restricted to investigating Nugan Hand in relation very largely to drug matters. In his statement in the Parliament a little over a week ago the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) said that the terms of reference would be extended to enable the joint task force to investigate breaches by Nugan Hand of Commonwealth laws as well as all State laws. However, it is not so important what the Minister says in this Parliament as what are declared to be the terms of reference and the Prime Minister has clearly declared what they are. In his letter to the New South Wales Premier he says:

I therefore propose that we widen the terms of reference of the Commonwealth- New South Wales Police Task Force on Drug Trafficking to enable it to investigate matters raised in recommendation 5 and other related matters and report to us.
Recommendation 5, of course, refers to the Woodward Commission report. It states :

The evidence concerning Harry Wainwright, Nugan Hand Ltd and its associated companies and the affairs of Murray Stewart Riley and in particular his associates as revealed in evidence be referred to appropriate law enforcement bodies for further investigation.
I have in the body of this report referred to the circumstances under which Wainwright obtained citizenship of this country.
However, the document, in announcing that an interim report of the joint task force had been received, went on to state:
Subsequently the Prime Minister and Premier of New South Wales agreed to the widening of the terms of reference.
It continued:

Except that the force should not become involved in the investigation of the immigration aspects of Wainwright's activities nor in the financial aspects of the Corporate Affairs Commission investigation of Nugan Hand unless the finances related to illegal drug activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that out of Mr Wran's letter?

—The document is headed: 'If it is decided that the report should not be released to the Press the following Press release might be made'. As I understand it, it was released by the Prime Minister. So what it is effectively saying is that matters related to Wainwright, one of the key persons of concern to the Woodward report in respect of recommendation 5, are to be excluded from investigation. Financial matters are not to be investigated unless they are related to illegal drug activity. True, the Corporate Affairs Commission is looking at some aspect of this matter. But this does seem to be a very messy business. There are at least three agencies or instrumentalities of government which are operating in this area in discrete fashions. There is the Stewart Royal Commission which to an extent has overlapped into Nugan Hand but does not cover all of Nugan Hand; there is the joint police force which is clearly restricted in this matter; and there is the Corporate Affairs Commission which is carrying out investigation on financial matters quite discretely unless they are associated with drug running by Nugan Hand, in which case the task force can be drawn into the matter. There should be co-operation. That, Mr Speaker, is a very messy and totally unsatisfactory approach. The question is, of course: Is the Prime Minister correct in his confident assertions in this Parlimament that the task force is an appropriately structured body to investigate the vast range of allegations about Nugan Hand; that is, does he have that authority? I in no way reflect upon the competence of the people in the task force. I am sure they have been selected because they excel in their field. I am talking about their authority. If we look at the Woodward Royal Commission report we find these sorts of comments by Justice Woodward recorded at page 1646:

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to see how the proposed task force can, without the powers which were vested in me, achieve more than the State Police Department.

The task force does not have the powers that were vested in Mr Justice Woodward. He makes that point again at page 1654 of the report. I ask honourable members to bear with me as it is a somewhat longer declaration. He states:

Without the powers of a Royal Commissioner to secure the attendance of witnesses for questioning and the production of documents, the task force is still capable of doing valuable work. However, it must be conventional work and can be directed against only lower level drug traffickers. It cannot be expected , without considerable luck,-
For gosh sake, we want more than luck with this sort of inquiry-
to be successful against the high level traffickers.
Mr Justice Woodward goes on to state:

The Task Force would be more effective if it has powers similar to those possessed by its American counterpart and the ability to call upon some authority, probably a Supreme Court Judge, to exercise powers similar to those granted to a Royal Commissioner under the Royal Commissions Act, 1923.

There you have it, Mr Speaker, without my extracting any more declarations from the findings of Justice Woodward. The task force, no matter how competent its officers are, no matter how skilled and no matter what the success rate is that may backup their selection to carry out this investigation, is hamstrung by very limited terms of reference. So, in all the circumstances-that is, the clear evidence that the Stewart Royal Commission is restricted to inquiring into matters related to Terence John Clark and associated matters which perchance may meander into the area of Nugan Hand but not cover all of the area of Nugan Hand and declarations by Mr Justice Woodward of the deficiencies of the joint task force-we on this side of the House are quite justified in demanding that there should be a full royal commission of inquiry into Nugan Hand, its operations, its structure, allegations about it-all of those sorts of associated matters.

Are we justified in our concern about the way in which this matter has progressed in more general terms? I remind honourable members that this matter became an issue of contention in this Parliament on Thursday, 11 March, after the televising of a program on Channel 9, Sydney. That program followed a series of disclosures on this matter which had been regularly published in the major weekend newspaper, the National Times. That Channel 9 news interview on the morning of the day that I declared involved a man named Volkman, a former Narcotics Bureau agent. He asserted that he and three of his colleagues had been subjected to victimisation and vilification and that they believed it was because they had been gathering information on the Nugan Hand organisation. He said he had reached the point where he could take no more and he resigned. There are public declarations by other people in the Bureau of Customs-I presume from the manner in which this has been reported that it was the Bureau of Customs-and by people formerly serving in the former Narcotics Bureau, which appear to bolster the claims of Volkman. The nub of Volkman's allegations which disturbs this House is:

So far as the investigation is concerned, my information is that a Minister of the Crown, a Federal Minister of the Crown, directed that no action of any overt nature take place in respect of the Nugan Hand organisation.

Through the extraordinarily clumsy behaviour of the Government in handling this matter it has developed to the point where the Government, at least tacitly, has agreed that it will have to consider seriously the Opposition's proposals. Those proposals simply are that there should be a full royal commission of inquiry into these allegations. If it is to be the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry with expanded terms of reference, as a face saver, I quibble not at all. I am pleased. But the result that very properly should be achieved appears to be in the process of being achieved.

The fact is that they were serious allegations. Is there any evidence to substantiate them? The documents I tabled a few minutes ago are being processed with other important pieces of paper in the Parliament; the Government requires copies. I will rely on my memory for dates; they can be corrected later. It is my recollection that in about March 1978 a Mr Bates of the Narcotics Bureau put together a memorandum the effect of which was to put investigations into the activities of Nugan Hand on to the back burner, as it were. It was claimed in this Parliament by the Minister for Administrative Services that that was a misinterpretation of what Mr Bates was saying; that what Mr Bates was really saying was that the investigations would go from overt to covert in their nature . However, another document which I tabled today and which I have referred to before, declares in a footnote appended to a report by a narcotics investigator that certain information about the behaviour of Nugan Hand in its illicit narcotics operation is being provided from a reliable source and that if the investigation into Nugan Hand is ever resurrected this source can be tapped effectively. Those two things in juxtaposition seem to bowl over middle stump the claim of the Minister for Administrative Services that the operation had moved from overt to covert.

If we reflect for a minute, the claim was nonsense anyway because almost exclusively the operations of the Narcotics Bureau will be covert by their nature. There would be very little that it could do overtly; the operations would have to be covert by their nature. Largely, the overt activity would be at the time of arrest and processing through courts. If we reflect for a minute, it was a nonsensical claim by the Minister. However, I go back to the report of Mr Justice Woodward. It is a curious set of circumstances that those documents exist. They seem to give some foundation-at least I say some; I suspect more-to the claims of Volkman that impediments were put in the way of the proper processes of investigation and enforcement of the law in relation to Nugan Hand. In the Woodward report we find page after page of condemnation of Federal Government authorities for their obstructionism in the processes of his Royal Commission. On pages 1649 and 1650 Mr Justice Woodward stated:

Before proceeding overseas, lack of co-operation and, indeed, refusal to co- operate on the part of the Federal Government and its Departments provided an obstacle to me in the course of my investigations and was very much in the front of my mind when I left Australia on 1st September, 1978.
In another volume he states at page 19:
In general, I did not receive co-operation from the Federal Government and its authorities, the Customs Bureau and the Federal Narcotics Bureau.
I apologise for a more lengthly quote but, for the sake of substance in the record, I have to resort to it. At page 20 he stated:

At the time I was deeply involved in investigating heroin trafficking in this State. Few better ways of avoiding giving assistance to an investigating Royal Commission than that offered could be devised. Nevertheless, attempts were made to obtain assistance by writing letters to the nominated Commonwealth Solicitor and framing questions, in writing, about persons and activities then under investigation. Some of these questions were briefly answered. Many were not answered. At no time was full information ever supplied as sought. Despite many requests, I was never shown a single file or did I interview a single Commonwealth officer.
He did not see one single Commonwealth officer or one single file, he says in this report, when he was investigating heroin trafficking in New South Wales. He continued:

No effective information was ever received from the Narcotics Bureau and this gravely hampered and restricted this Commission's inquiries into heroin trafficking. But I did receive first hand experience of the unfortunate effects of a total failure of inter-agency co-operation.

I repeat: the unfortunate effects of a total failure of inter-agency co- operation'. That is to say, on the face of the evidence provided, there was clear, continuing and quite conscious obstructionism on the part of Federal Government instrumentalities concerning the investigations by the Woodward Royal Commission.

Therefore, one feels justifiable reason for having qualms about the determination, zeal and energy that the Government will employ in this matter. There is nothing but fiction behind the succession of propositions by the Government that the Stewart Royal Commission has authority to investigate Nugan Hand and associated matters. It is a crude, attemptedly deceptive, playing with words that gives the Government no credit for candour. It knows full well that the full range of allegations relating to Nugan Hand cannot be investigated by the Stewart Royal Commission, as it now stands. That Commission cannot look at allegations of gun running. It cannot look at allegations concerning the alleged involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency or such matters, which are just as crucial and deserving of investigation as are the allegations of drug running and association with organised crime.
The best that the Minister for Administrative Services could say in this House on 18 March, when the pressure was building up was:
In last Tuesday's debate . . . I said I believed that the evidence concerning Nugan Hand could be referred to the Royal Commissioner.
That is, the Royal Commissioner Stewart. The Minister continued:
After discussion with the Attorney-General I sent to the Royal Commissioner, first of all, on behalf of the Prime Minister, a copy of the first report of the joint task force.
He then went on to say the following, which I believe is significant:

. . . I believe that, on behalf of everybody who is concerned, this will test the ability of the Royal Commissioner to deal with these matters. Obviously the Royal Commissioner will tell us whether his terms of reference encompass these measures.

That is a curious statement by a Minister who says that he has discussed the matter with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), who in turn would have taken the advice of the Solicitor-General. He went on to say that he was putting it in as a matter of pot luck, as a fishing expedition. He was not sure whether the Royal Commission could look at it. That would be determined by the Royal Commissioner. Of course it cannot and, of course, the terms of reference have to be expanded. So, on the available evidence of public record, as the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission stand, they are restricted to the investigation of Terrence John Clark and matters related to his activities involving illicit narcotics transactions.

The joint New South Wales-Commonwealth task force, which is composed of the Federal and New South Wales police forces, suffers from clear deficiencies and limitations concerning the ambit of its operations. That has been declared, beyond any dispute by Mr Justice Woodward. There is, quite apparently, a long, continuing practice on the part of the Federal Government of being obstructionist in regard to these investigations. On the face of the evidence that is available, one would trust that that would stop. There is prima facie, on the basis of the documentation available, in association with that sort of evidence in the Woodward report, clear ground for concern that, in spite of information being available to the Government for more than five years about the nature of the Nugan Hand activities, in 1978 Nugan Hand was put on to the back burner and, it would appear, eventually into deep freeze.

In all of these circumstances, a full investigation must be made of Nugan Hand, of people associated with it, and of the allegations concerning Nugan Hand and those people. That can be done only by a royal comission which has adequate terms of reference. It is extraordinary that the matter has taken more than a week to reach today the point at which the Government is now conceding that it will consider expanded terms of reference. Incredibly, yesterday I was prevented from tabling documents relating to this matter. I say 'incredible' because I had been taunted by the Government over the preceding several days of sitting to present them. I felt some caution in so doing because names of informants were included. I deleted the names of the informants and, because I have had a chance to think about the matter overnight, have increased the number of documents that I have tabled today. There are several from the more than 23 documents, notes and other bits of paper that I have relating to this matter.

The final matter I want to mention is: With a properly set up royal commission of inquiry into this matter, with adequate terms of reference, which satisfies me that there will be no more of this fudging on the part of the Federal Government, I will supply the documentation which I have. I am asked also to identify to the Royal Commission the source or sources of my information. If that is to be done I would want to see certain very clear and convincing safeguards established for my informant or informants should his or their identities be disclosed to the Royal Commission. I do that for this reason. It will be remembered in a debate early last week on a related matter that I pointed out that this gentleman Volkman, who made the serious allegations which set this issue off, declared that after he appeared before the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs in this country and gave evidence in camera-in which he identified people within the Narcotics Bureau, as I understand the matter, whose behaviour was improper-a search warrant was subsequently executed on his premises. The consequence of the execution of that search warrant was that the transcript of the evidence which he gave to that Royal Commission, in which he named officers with whom he had served, was seized. Subsequent to that he was subjected to threats and intimidation. He later appeared in the Magistrates Court on a charge of smuggling birds. The charge was not proceeded with or whatever, but certainly he was not indicted. No conviction was recorded against him. Some nine months later an ex-officio indictment was executed by the Attorney-General against this man in spite of the fact that the case was not proceeded with in the lower court.

In those circumstances-the seizure of the transcript and the threats extended to him-he believes rightly or wrongly that he has been persecuted through the courts by the Government. We must have quite clear and quite convincing iron- clad guarantees about the protection of people who might come forward or who might be identified as sources of information for the Royal Commission. I am pleased that we at least appear to be having some success in this matter and that the dawn of common sense apparently is beginning to rise with the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The offer I made to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was very specific and clear. It was to discuss with the Solicitor-General and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) whether the terms of reference of the Royal Commission and/or the task force will be adequate for the widest possible examination of all matters related to the Nugan Hand organisation and any other matters relating to these problems. In the light of what the Leader of the Opposition has said I would like to repeat that on the advice available to the Government the terms of the Royal Commission are in fact wide enough to achieve that very result. If it can be demonstrated to law officers with some competence in this field that the terms of reference are not wide enough, then they will be widened. They are certainly not construed in the narrow sense as the Leader of the Opposition persists in doing in this House. Nevertheless, the matter will be one that will be decided by proper legal interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that the Government has not been slow or reluctant in any sense to come forward in these matters because much of what has happened has happened as a result of Commonwealth initiatives. That relates to the widening of the terms of reference of the task force and it also relates very much to the establishment of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. When the Leader of the Opposition quoted from page 1654 of the report of the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking I do not recollect that he quoted the last sentence from that page, which states:
However, a decision on whether the Task Force should have these powers must await assessment of its future performance.

It is worth noting that the Royal Commission was established subsequent to that date. Quite clearly the Royal Commission and the task force are working very closely together. Whilst they are two bodies they are in fact pursuing the one broad objective. It was the deliberate decision of governments that it was best to proceed in this way with the task force operating between the police force of New South Wales and the Commonwealth and then to have the Royal Commission embracing of all four governments.

It is not adequate to suggest that Mr Justice Woodward indicated that the capacities of the task force were inadequate because that is only part of the story. The task force is proceeding. Mr Justice Woodward did say that the decision on whether its powers were sufficient would have to wait for an assessment of its work. In any case a royal commission has been established and there can be only one matter that needs resolution. I am happy to rest on the judgment of the law officers of the Commonwealth as to whether the terms of reference of that Royal Commission are in fact adequate to cover all matters related to it. On the advice available to us the terms of reference are adequate . If they need extension, as was indicated in the original announcement of the Royal Commission, then they will be extended.

It would have been much easier to make final judgments in relation to these matters if the Leader of the Opposition had co-operated, as every citizen of this Commonwealth would have been expected to co-operate with a royal commission or with a police task force, and has made his information available so that proper judgment could be made about the adequacy of the terms of reference. I am delighted now that he has accepted my invitation to do so. I hope that the discussions with the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General are held forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. It has been brought to my attention that on 23 March 1982 in the Senate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) indicated that his attention had been drawn to a Press release issued for and on behalf of the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia. He told the Senate that he had seen a copy of the Press statement and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and which I understand emanated from the office of Mr Clyde Holding in this Parliament House--

When pressed on the matter, Senator Messner resiled from that statement and was content to say that he had received a copy of the statement from my office in Parliament House and he felt that that was strange. The implication and the thrust of Senator Messner's statements were that this document, rather than being a document put out by the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association, in fact had me as the author.

The facts of the matter are simply these: Following a debate which took place in this House last Thursday and which I initiated a large number of statements and allegations were made both by me and by the Minister who answered on behalf of the Government. Following that, a Press release was issued by the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association which was embargoed until midday on Sunday. I did not see that statement until I came to Parliament House on Tuesday where a copy of it was waiting for me. It was a lengthy statement. It not only disagreed with views expressed by the Minister on behalf of the Government in terms of interpretation but also had an alternative statement of fact.

Having regard to its importance it seemed to me, in order that all honourable members would have a complete record of the thrust of the allegations that had been made in the debate, that it would be an appropriate course for me to incorporate that statement in Hansard so that all honourable members could make their own judgments on it. I subsequently did that on Tuesday night. But it also seemed to me, as I had no method of knowing which Minister would be at the table during the adjournment debate, that as a matter of courtesy it would be appropriate for me to bring the statement to the attention of the relevant Minister in case he had not seen it. I instructed my research officer to take a copy of the statement round to the Minister's office and when I raised the matter in the adjournment debate I was able to indicate to the Minister at the table that I was seeking leave to have this statement incorporated in Hansard and that a copy had been sent to the appropriate Minister.

I think it is a matter of regret that what was essentially a simple act of courtesy should be misinterpreted in this way and also that statements should be made which were disparaging of the organisation, the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, and its President. It seems that the Minister concerned is having increasing difficulty in dealing with simple acts of courtesy, with any kind of integrity at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman is now arguing the issue. He will resume his seat.

Government Housing Policy-Broken Hill-Victorian Election: Advertising
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 18 March, we heard the results of the review by this Government of its housing policies. This matter has already been debated but, as it was directed to the Victorian election campaign, there is need to examine it again. The main thrust of the policy was the family home tax rebate. It was introduced as a desperate attempt to save a Liberal Government in Victoria, which has been proved utterly incompetent and, worse, a Government tainted by corruption, as highlighted by the scandalous land deals.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia, and particularly of Victoria, should realise that the scheme is limited to first home buyers. Therefore a scheme estimated in the first full year to cost $230m will benefit only 28 per cent of home buyers. The other 72 per cent of home buyers will continue to battle with ever increasing mortgage repayments without any assistance from the Fraser Government. Further, there is no means test on the scheme and it will therefore not be directed to those most in need.

A survey by the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research in 1980 showed that 45 per cent of first home buyers in Victoria earned in excess of 150 per cent of average male weekly earnings-that is, on today's figures, $ 450 weekly or more. This Government was prepared to buy an election victory in Victoria by a scheme directed at only 28 per cent of home buyers. But then came the real crunch. The Fraser Government allowed saving banks again to increase housing interest rates by one per cent to 13.5 per cent. That is a 4 per cent increase from 9.5 per cent in March 1980 to a staggering 13.5 per cent in March 1982. This one per cent increase in interest rates will result in a $22 increase in monthly repayments on a bank loan of $30,000 over 25 years.

The Victorian Liberals, stricken with panic, then decided to offer a one per cent interest rebate to about 72 per cent of Victorian home buyers who miss out on the Federal scheme. This proposal is an election bribe. The Liberals have no shame about plundering the public purse to retain the spoils of office. Mr Kennett, the Victorian Minister of Housing, stated on 19 March that the scheme would be an election winner. That is another prediction by that man which will be proved wrong on 3 April when the Victorian people elect a Cain Labor government. However, we should remember the disgraceful motive of Mr Kennett, being not to help anyone but only to hang on to power at all costs.

Because of the insatiable appetite of the Liberal Party for deceit and distortion, together with the capacity of the propaganda machine to peddle such political distortion, it is necessary to spell out some of the facts on this election bribe, described by the Victorian Liberals as a housing policy. Firstly , bank interest on a 25-year loan of $30,000 has increased in two years from 9.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent. As a result, monthly repayments on such a loan have increased in that period by $88. For those forced to borrow from building societies, interest rates have increased by 3 per cent from 12.5 per cent in March 1980 to 15.5 per cent in March 1982. On a $30,000 building society loan over 25 years monthly repayments have increased to approximately $390. The one per cent rebate for people who have a bank loan amounts to $22 a month but because of the interest rate increases over the past two years their mortgage payments have gone up by $88 a month as a direct result of this Government's policies. Therefore, allowing for the rebate of $22 a month, such a home buyer is still $66 a month worse off than he was two years ago. That is all that is being done for those home buyers by the introduction of the one per cent rebate scheme.

Secondly, the cost of the scheme, according to Mr Kennett, is about $30m. This is a gross distortion of the true cost. The correct figure is closer to $60m. Mr John Cain was certainly correct when he said the Liberals cannot add up. A one per cent increase in interest rates in Australia will cost approximately $300m per annum in increased interest payments. Of that amount, Victoria accounts for about $80m. The scheme will cater for 72 per cent of home buyers who are not covered by the Federal proposal. Seventy-two per cent of $80m is almost $60m. It is amazing that Mr Kennett could have arrived at a figure of $30m. He claimed that the scheme would be financed from $60m transferred from the Mark I housing policy, which was dropped like a hot potato when the Federal Government inflicted a further increase of one per cent in interest rates. Mr Kennett said further that there would be $30m left from the $60m to extend the scheme. In fact, there will be nothing left as the scheme will absorb all of the $60m.

Thirdly, there will be further increases in interest rates not just for Victorians but for all Australians. Mr Morris, the President of the Victorian Building Societies Association, said on 19 March that it was even more inevitable that interest rates would increase. He was, of course, commenting on the policies of this Government and the Victorian Liberal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't be there to subsidise them.

—Exactly. Mr Campbell, the Chairman of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, has predicted an increase of 1 1/2 per cent. In addition, we have seen the first step to deregulate the banks. We have now started along the Campbell track. Economists from the Australian National University predict that there will be increases in interest rates of between 3 per cent and 4 per cent if deregulation is adopted. That is the direction in which this Government is heading.

SPEECH.PARA: Those Victorians who are renting homes have been ignored again and face a bleak future unless urgent attention is given to the public housing sector. There have been dramatic rent increases in the past two years. For example, in the inner suburbs of Melbourne rents rose by between 20 per cent and 50 per cent from January 1980 to December 1981. Real estate agents in Melbourne are predicting that rents will continue to rise sharply this year with increases of about 30 per cent in some areas.

On Tuesday of this week the Minister for Housing and Construction announced a disgraceful proposal to spend $300,000 to advertise the housing policy of the Fraser Government.
