TALK.START.PARA: —Next year will see the city of Broken Hill celebrating its 100th birthday and this is a significant event not only in the history of that great mining city but also in the history of our young nation. It was through the wealth gained from the Barrier Range that many of Australia's industrial giants were born and, without this direct wealth being paid to mining companies and by the taxes and royalties paid to the State and Federal governments, this nation's development would have been much slower.

SPEECH.PARA: The lode still provides direct input for large industries in centres other than Broken Hill-in particular Port Pirie in South Australia, Risdon in Tasmania and, to a lesser extent, Cockle Creek in New South Wales. However, as with all mines, the Broken Hill lode is a reducing asset and, although major mining companies have invested considerable sums in exploration over many years, the only significant discovery in recent time has been that of the Fitzpatrick lode by North Broken Hill Ltd. This discovery, however, is only likely to extend the life of the North Broken Hill mine from its present life expectancy by about four years.

It has become the practice for the mines on the southern end of the line of lode, consisting of the Zinc Corporation and New Broken Hill Consolidated, to extract a greater proportion of lower grade ores, but the time has come when the economic viability of continued mining operations will depend upon the cost of extraction, with particular emphasis on labour, transport and energy. Even with these taken into consideration, much will depend upon State and Federal government decisions.

A committee known as the Broken Hill Economic Review Committee was set up in 1979, and it held its first meeting in January 1980, to look into the diversification of Broken Hill's economy and other matters that it was hoped would ensure the long-term future of Broken Hill. The committee consisted of representatives of all levels of government, and representatives of the Broken Hill community. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth representative was an observer only. The committee did an excellent job, and in its report it touched on the history of Broken Hill, the local economy, transport, population and employment, age structure of the city and work force, and education. In fact, an extremely broad range of subjects were investigated and reported upon.

There were matters raised in the report that I feel should be highlighted so that they are placed on record in this Parliament. One relates to the unique nature of the Broken Hill royalty scale. These royalties are being paid to the New South Wales State Government. The formula for this royalty scale is complicated and, as time does not permit, I shall not go into details of the formula. Suffice to say that this royalty has acted in the same way as a resource tax or a 'super-profits' tax. On top of this are paid company tax, payroll tax, municipal rates and water board rates. If one adds the tax paid by the employees of the mining companies of Broken Hill, one finds that the total payout over 10 years to June 1979 was $355.9m. In royalties the coal industry has caught up and surpassed Broken Hill in recent years. For example, from 1976 to 1980 coal mines paid $153m, whilst Broken Hill companies paid $108m.

Nevertheless, the historical importance of Broken Hill to the nation's treasuries has been significant. Not only have governments benefited, but also it is a fact that many industrial movements throughout Australia have received assistance from the workers of Broken Hill through the Barrier Industrial Council, during their times of hardship and strife, by way of voluntary levies paid by the workers of Broken Hill. The citizens of Broken Hill have always had a reputation for self-reliance born out of necessity, with the traditional feeling that governments of any persuasion were interested only in what wealth could be obtained from their city in the semi-arid region of western New South Wales. Broken Hill has, therefore, developed a tough and independent outlook, but now it is realised, particularly on the findings of the Economic Review Committee, that some of the wealth that has been won from Broken Hill will have to be returned if the city is to have a long-term future.

One way in which this could be achieved would be in carrying out one of the recommendations of the Economic Review Committee by devising an incentive whereby royalty relief would be provided to mining companies extracting low- grade ores, possibly on a sliding scale relating royalty to the head grade of the ore. It would then be up to the Federal Government to match any royalty relief approved by the New South Wales State Government with Federal tax relief. This would not only enable full utilisation of the ore body of the city but would give Broken Hill time to broaden its economic base and prepare itself for the future.

Although royalty relief is one of the major points recommended by the report, there were other recommendations. One was that a co-ordinator be appointed by the New South Wales Premier to liaise with relevant organisations and follow up on progress in relation to recommendations approved by the Government or other decisions taken by the Government in relation to Broken Hill. Another was that a Commonwealth-State task force should be established to examine and recommend an overall manpower planning measure. A Broken Hill action committee was to be established to examine and recommend ways of achieving a more attractive industrial relations image and of improving the competitive position of Broken Hill in relation to other country areas.

The citizens of Broken Hill are becoming impatient that little has happened since the committee brought out its report 14 months ago. The only thing that they can see occurring is reduced services being provided by governments. The State member for Broken Hill, Mr Bill Beckroge, has done a good job in keeping the matter before the New South Wales State Parliament, and it is hoped that the State Minister for Industrial Development and Decentralisation, Mr Don Day, will soon make a statement on the matter.

Broken Hill has the will to survive and to maintain its position as one of the major cities of inland Australia, but it will mean a great deal of flexibility being displayed by local, State and Federal Governments. The mining companies will have to play their part keeping in mind the problems that they face on a fluctuating overseas market. The Broken Hill union movement, under the leadership of the Barrier Industrial Council, has had a major part to play in the history and traditions of Broken Hill, but I believe that, because of its structure and the place it holds in the Broken Hill community, it has yet to play its most significant role in assuring the future of Broken Hill.

Since my election to the Federal Parliament, I have tried to ensure that other members are aware of the significant role that Broken Hill has played in the New South Wales and Australian economy over a great number of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has done a good job in that regard, too.
—I thank the Minister. I am sure that there can be no better way for honourable members to learn of the problems of the city than by them travelling to Broken Hill.
—For St Patrick's Day.
—Exactly. This refers not only to Government members but also to Opposition members of the State and Federal parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: Because we are a country of great mineral resources, the situation that Broken Hill now finds itself in will not be unique. Broken Hill is not asking for handouts. It wants only a fair go from both the State and Federal governments, mainly in relief from crippling royalties and taxes. I hope that, when the State Government decides to reduce its royalty scale to a more reasonable level and provide other assistance to Broken Hill, the Federal Government will be there to match its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I should like to reveal, among other things, what must be one of the biggest scandals in Australian political history. Naturally, it is concerned with the Victorian State Government, the Thompson Government-a government which, after a quarter of a century in office, is about to be swept aside on Saturday week by the Victorian people. It is a Government that has become more corrupt, corrupt in the extreme. The old school tie has paid and has been repaid many times over, no more than at present. What we have seen in the past few months is several hundred thousands of dollars spent on what I would call blatant political advertising. However, it has not been paid for by the Liberal Party. It has been paid for by the Victorian taxpayers.
—Like that in New South Wales.

—The bone of contention is, my friend, that after a quarter of a century of a definite policy of doing nothing-one might have a more reasonable attitude if the Victorian Government had done something; it has had 27 years to do something-absolutely nothing has come forward until the last three or four months, when the Thompson Government, believing that it is about to go down the gurgler, decides that it must push its image through the statutory bodies. Here we have advertisements such as this--
—Tell us about the power crisis in New South Wales.

—The honourable member for Higgins continually runs off at the mouth before he can get his brain into gear. We have had advertisements such as this in the National Times, the Melbourne Sun, and the Melbourne Age, referring to employment:

SPEECH.PARA: Your next staff member can be free-

With it is a big picture of the Minister, Mr Brian Dixon. Who is paying for that ? This has come out only in the last couple of months. Advertisements have been put forward by Victoria's No. 1 head prefect, masquerading as the Minister for Housing, in open letters to the Prime Minister. Obviously someone did not tell him that he could have done the same thing by writing a letter and putting a 24c stamp on it. It was all paid for by the Victorian taxpayers. In the short time of a few months hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money has been spent to try to prop up the Thompson Government. Here is an even better advertisement, of two pages. It is a double spread. This is not from a couple of months ago, it is only from Saturday of last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would that double page spread cost?
—It would cost several thousand dollars, probably nearly $10,000. It is dated Saturday, 13 March and is in relation to the Urban Land Authority.
—Read it out.

—I will read it out. The headline reads: 'The Urban Land Authority introduces ''Operation Home Buy''.' Then, down the bottom, under the guise of the Urban Land Authority, the advertisement-this is the crunch-in the first column states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian Government-
I repeat, the Victorian Government-
Through the Urban Land Authority, now introduces 'Operation Home Buy' . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you want people to buy homes?

—I am glad the honourable member for Higgins is here. He asks: 'Don't you want people to buy homes?' Under this Federal Government home ownership has gone down and is continuing to do so. That brings me to a Liberal Party advertisement which answers the little interjection of the honourable member for Higgins. There was a full page advertisement in yesterday's Melbourne Age. I sincerely hope the Liberal Party paid for it as, again, it would have cost several thousand dollars. At the top it is headed: 'Can you afford to pay 1 per cent more'. It goes on to say that Labor will not match the promises of the Liberal Party to help people with the new interest rates that the Federal Government has applied. It also states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ring for details of your benefits. Phone 662 2599.

A friend of mine rang and asked some very interesting questions such as what would this one per cent promise cost. The lady on the end of the telephone said: 'I don't know'. The second question was how it would be financed and-get a load of this-the answer came from the person at that telephone number on the Liberal Party advertisement: 'In the same mysterious way everything else is.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It must have been Phil Lynch's secretary.
—That is right. Another question was what rental assistance would be given?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order. Do we present Logies in this House?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The answer was that that was not known. The lady put my friend on to a person who said that he was a secretary to the Victorian Minister for Housing. His answer to that question was: 'Rental assistance amounting to $5.2m will be given by the Federal Government to Victoria.' The Victorian Government does not know how it will be used but a conference is being held on Friday. If the Victorian Government does not know how to use $5m in regard to rental accommodation, I think the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) and the Minister in Victoria might well come to my electorate. Plenty of people could tell them what to do with this $5m. I have had people come to me in regard to this matter. For instance, a widow with a teenage son who lived in a little two bedroom unit said that things were so bad that she would have to downgrade to a one bedroom unit and would have to sleep in the lounge room because they could not afford to keep a two bedroom unit going.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the situation under the policies of this Government and of the Government in Victoria. The list goes on. In my bayside electorate of Isaacs the numerous caravan parks are all full because people cannot afford to live anywhere else. For reassurance, my friend who rang this number asked this secretary to the Minister for Housing also how that one per cent would be financed. This is what one of the secretaries to the Minister said: 'I assume someone has worked it out.' In other words, the Victorian Government has this great attitude towards financing its new wonderful schemes and yet it had the cheek the other day to say that the promises of the Cain government-which it will be on Saturday week-would cost $3,000m. It cannot even cost its own promises. The Victorian Government does not know; it is making wild promises in an effort to stop itself from going down the gurgler.

I cite one more case from my electorate. In 1977 the State Government bought a place called 'Yarrabah' in Aspendale, which is on the beach, to use as a special school. It was reported then to have cost the State Government around $190,000. It paid $190,000 for a special school. The incompetence of the Victorian Government is so great. It did not even go into the project and it was found that the place was not suitable. There were numerous reasons for that, one of which was the whole area was zoned residential and could not be used. It is an absolute disgrace that 'Yarrabah' is still vacant five years later, at an original cost to the Victorian taxpayers of nearly $200,000. This type of government in Victoria has been going on for over a quarter of a century. It is about time-it will be time on Saturday week-that the Victorian people got rid of this Government.

We hear much, especially from the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), about how investment is growing and how things in Victoria are so wonderful. I mentioned that in a speech yesterday. However, he leaves out certain aspects. I wish to quote some Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on actual private new fixed capital expenditure by the State. I will refer to South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria and how the percentages have changed between September 1980 and September 1981. In New South Wales the real new fixed capital expenditure has increased by 15.3 per cent; in South Australia it has declined by 6.7 per cent; and, in Victoria, the real change has been minus 7.3 per cent. Private expenditure and new capital expenditure in the 12 months, from September to September, has declined by 7.3 per cent in Victoria. In regard to the States' shares of private fixed capital expenditure, from September 1979 to 1981 there was an increase in New South Wales from 36.2 per cent to 37.1 per cent. New South Wales is continuing to increase slightly its share. South Australia's share has decreased from 7.5 per cent to 5.7 per cent and Victoria's share has decreased from 26.6 per cent to 20.2. per cent- an absolute disgrace.

When I heard the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) and the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) attack the Liberal Government's record and proposals on housing, I tried to remember who on the other side of the House had taken a keen interest in low cost housing. The harsh reality is that the only person in the Labor Party who has shown any continuing interest in low cost housing is probably Norm Gallagher. The fact is that during this debate this morning and at other times there has been an unfortunate tendency in the election debate in Victoria to lose sight of the real issues and to forget the very significant progress that has been made by Victoria under a Liberal government. I remind the House that Victoria has the highest level of household income of any State in Australia, that Victorians enjoy the highest rate of home ownership, that Victoria has the highest skilled work force in Australia, and its unemployment rate is the lowest in any State. I have listened to honourable members opposite before. Their cliches are deserving of the purring they are giving them now. The reality is that achievements have occurred in Victoria because of the consistent and positive development policies pursued by successive Liberal governments in that State. They are the sorts of policies which clearly distinguish a Liberal approach from a Labor approach to government and which the Liberal Premier, Lindsay Thompson, has pledged to continue in the interests of all Victorians.
—Look at Labor in Tasmania.

—It is rather hard to look at it. Members of that party have virtually submerged themselves, to coin a phrase. I understand the leader is holding a meeting of his supporters tomorrow and he has booked a local telephone booth. The Liberal policy statement can bluntly be put forward as a blueprint for continuing responsible economic management, for the encouragement of growth and employment through private endeavour and for firm and responsible industrial relations policies. As has been made clear, the Liberal Government will introduce innovative and creative programs to encourage the further development of small business and to promote investment in natural resource and high technology industries. Despite all disclaimers, when one looks at the detail of the Labor Party's policies one finds that in reality they are just a re-run of the sorts of policies pursued by other Labor governments. There is hardly any need to remind the House of the various Labor government records of economic management. Look at the glitter that has gone off the image of that model for Labor leaders, the Premier of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I remarked in a rather passing way during the Lowe by-election that I could understand the concerns of some New South Welshmen with the sales tax that was imposed on certain essential items such as candles, hurricane lamps, hot water bottles and roller skates for commuters. Regrettably the joke is coming true. Rather than liberate, the private talent and resources on which future growth would depend, a Labor government in Victoria would undoubtedly mean more government intervention and regulation-except, of course, over the trade union movement-and more bureaucracy and more State socialism. The centrepiece of Labor 's development strategy is to be yet another government body-the Victorian development fund. This fund is to take $675m of the cash reserves of the State's public authorities to finance Labor's extravagant capital works program. Let us look at what the independent Cochrane-Muir report had to say about this. It has identified in fact that $225m can be prudently used and it is their advice which will, of course, guide a Liberal government. Quite properly, Professor Cochrane and Sir Lawrence Muir have said that the resources of the State superannuation fund must be managed in the interests of its policy holders. They are not, of course, the resources of the Government and they cannot be disposed of at the Government's whim.

So when the electors of Victoria make their choice on 3 April they should recall the words of the New South Wales Auditor-General who said last year that if the public authorities in that State had been run as private operations they would be bankrupt now. The Wran Labor Government has reduced that State to insolvency. A Cain Labor government would unquestionably follow in the same direction-the direction of promising to extend government controls into other areas of economic activity. According to the State Labor leadership, all of the State's energy resources would be brought under public ownership. Instead of freeing up the State's large public utilities such as the State Electricity Commission of Victoria and the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria and allowing them to pursue viable management policies and plan confidently for the future, a Labor government would in effect make them extensions of the State bureaucracy. There would be more regulation and more red tape to stifle initiative and incentive.

For some reason, which is beyond logic, the Labor Party maintains a mystical belief in the ability of bureaucrats and their alleged political masters to make better decisions for the community than people can make for themselves. One area , of course, where there will be less government intervention and less public control under a Labor government is the area of industrial relations. It does not matter what else we do in this country; if we do not get our industrial relations right we do not get our government right. There is no doubt that abject proposals have been put forward in the field of industrial relations in Victoria. The myth of that special relationship between the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement was blown apart not only in the years between 1972 and 1975 but critically and tragically in the State of New South Wales now. There is an urgent need to estabish a sound industrial relations framework not only federally but also at the State level whick is understood and accepted by all practitioners-unions, employers and government. If one examines the record of industrial relations of the Australian Labor Party in Victoria one will see that the current climate of confrontation and disintegration will worsen. In delivering the ALP policy speech, Mr Cain said:

The heavy handed, legalistic approach to industrial relations has not worked, and never will . . . All sections of the Victorian workforce must be encouraged to work together for Victoria to grow and prosper.
They are fine words, but what about the detailed application of that policy? Will the interests of Victorians be protected by Labor abolishing the Vital State Projects Act--

The latest rise is accompanied by a so-called housing package which the Federal Government is disgracefully using public money to market. That new housing policy has been described by the Australian newspaper-not exactly a pro-Labor paper-as 'an economic nonsense'. These are some of the comments made in the Australian about the policy:
It is unlikely to help the home construction industry.
. . . those moving because their families are growing-usually those most in need-get no help at all.
The scheme also does nothing to help the large number of Australians who rent.
. . . it will make life impossible for many small businessmen.

If the Fraser Government's policies are so bad that they have been rejected by even the conservative editorialists of the Australian, is there anyone left who can support it? Unfortunately, there is. The Thompson Liberal Government in Victoria. It continues to support the Fraser strategy. The evidence for that claim is clear. Did Thompson attack the Prime Minister about his economic policies which have led to the housing disaster? Certainly not. What did he do? He went through the ridiculous exercise of abandoning the housing policy he had announced eight days previously and he introduced a scheme to cover up, not to solve, Fraser's mistakes. The people of Victoria are to be fooled by the State Liberals into believing that they will not have to pay the one per cent increase imposed by the Federal Liberals. That action more than any other clearly exposes the nature of Mr Thompson and his gang. They have no new policies, no new ideas, no solutions to the massive problems facing Victoria. They are simply Fraser's ventriloquist dolls manipulated by Fraser's ideology, by his approach. But the people of Victoria will take their vengeance. They will vote in a Cain Labor government. That government will be a government of responsibility, a government which is led by a great Australian who has enormous compassion for ordinary people and high managerial ability. He will show the Liberals how a State should be run. He will provide a new direction for that State and will spell the end of the Fraser Liberals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the forty-fifth general report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This general report reviews the activity of the Committee during 1981. The report includes a reference to departments improving the standard of their submissions. We have set out in the report some key factors which should be included in the departmental submissions. These include: The need for the proposed work; the alternative solutions which have been examined prior to the decision to proceed with the work; an indication of the priority of the work in relation to other planned works by the department; details of any cost-benefit studies; details of any environmental studies; information of negotiations or discussions with other departments, State and local authorities, companies, unions and the public in relation to the work.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to environmental factors, the Committee has signalled its intention to examine more fully compliance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The Committee is frequently advised that proposed works require urgent attention, early completion of the works being necessitated by certain factors. Responsible departments should co-ordinate their planning and resource allocation with a view to giving the Committee sufficient time to publicise its inquiry, for interested groups and organisations to provide submissions and for the Committee to hold public hearings and report to Parliament. It appears to the Committee that the works become urgent because of lack of foresight and a lack of timely commitment either by the Government or in departmental decision making and through administrative and budgeting machinery.

Also in this general report is a section dealing with the construction of airport works which pre-empted consideration by the Committee. Authorisation and completion of these works without investigation by the Committee was a matter of concern. On a brighter note, the Committee observed the adoption of its recommendations in respect of defence housing. Full and regular consultation now appears to be taking place between Service families and the Departments of Defence, Administrative Services and Housing and Construction on the needs and problems of occupants of defence housing.

The Committee has commented on the Commonwealth's contribution to the national heritage. The Committee believes the Commonwealth expenditure in designing and constructing new buildings to complement historic buildings or areas should be recognised and that the public should be made aware of the Commonwealth's contribution. The Committee has drawn to the attention of the Government the need to clarify further the precise definition of a public work as noted in sections 5 and 18 of the Public Works Committee Act. The question of the definition of a public work arose over the proposed construction of an oceanographic research vessel for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

Last year was a busy year for the Committee, with 12 reports being presented and some 54 meetings being held in the year. The works examined totalled $207.9m with works costing $190.45m being recommended for construction by the Committee. The work load on Committee members and staff has been heavy, and as Chairman I wish to record my thanks to them. During the year, the Vice-Chairman, Senator Jean Melzer, retired and the Committee wishes her well for the future. Additionally, on behalf of the Committee, I now place on record acknowledgment of the help and assistance received from many departments, particularly the Department of Housing and Construction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I endorse the remarks of the Chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works-the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey)-and thank him for his kind remarks about the members of the Committee. I am very happy to serve on that Committee under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Canning. I was very sorry to lose from the Committee Senator Melzer and Senator Harold Young. Senator Young is now the President of the Senate and I congratulate him for being elevated to that high position. The Senate can only gain by having Senator Young as President. Senator Young was a great worker on the Committee. As I have said, I am sorry to lose him, but I know that he has gone to bigger and better things. I am very happy to have Senator Foreman and Senator Martyr join the Committee. I congratulate the honourable member for Sydney, Mr Les McMahon, on being elevated to the position of Vice-Chairman of the Committee. He is doing a wonderful job in that position.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make a couple of remarks in relation to what the Chairman has said about the environmental considerations that have been referred to the Committee. They relate mainly to the Department of Defence. It has stated in evidence that projects have been submitted to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment when it has been satisfied on the evidence that no environmental impact studies were required. On two occasion it has been proved by the Committee that further investigations were needed by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I suggest that the evidence given by the Department of Defence to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment led it to make its findings in that regard. I suggest to the Ministers of both departments that they look closely at environmental problems that exist in relation to Defence Force establishments and that they give further consideration to them. The Chairman gave the departments fair warning today when he stated that he would require more evidence in that regard.

On the subject of the urgency of works, work on the Townsville international terminal came before this Parliament as an urgency motion and did not come before the Committee. The report states that in 1980 the estimated costs for that terminal were supposedly $2.38m. They are now estimated at $3.2m. That terminal is still not complete. In my opinion, the Townsville international terminal was commenced for political expediency. Because of that we have to pay out more money. By the time it is finished it will probably cost an extra $2m. When we went to Townsville to inspect the sites for the new Commonwealth office buildings, we were shown over the international terminal and were told how wonderful it was that we could do all these projects so quickly, in a few weeks. When we said during evidence given by the Department of Housing and Construction that it would be a great idea to have the Commonwealth office buildings in Townsville and house all the public servants in one building, the departmental representatives said it would take quite a while to do and it would be 10 months before the plans could be drawn up. Lots of taxpayers' money could have been saved if the Department had hurried a bit more in that regard and had the Commonwealth office buildings built ahead of schedule. I thank the Parliament for allowing me to say these few words. I would like briefly to thank the members of the staff of the Committee. They work very had, as do all the other Committee members. I thank the Secretary, Mr Fenton, the Assistant Secretary, Mr Fetter, Mr Davies and the stenographer, Mrs Thompson, who have done a wonderful job. I have worked on the Road Safety Committee. The staff of the Public Works Committee are the most superior staff I have ever worked with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I concur with the comments made already on this matter. I wish to make one or two points. In my time on the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works I have noticed that great discipline has been imposed on government departments in bringing forward public works. I believe this is perhaps the most important function of the Committee. I know that there is public criticism of government committees. They can cost a fair amount of money. They employ staff and incur costs for travelling, although, of course, members do not receive allowances. But the money involved in cases such as the Public Works Committee is repaid over and over again in the discipline imposed on departments whereby they are forced to examine so closely why they are spending money and in what form they are spending it. I think that ought to be brought out, at least in the case of the Public Works Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out one aspect of the report this year that seems to me to be important; it relates to the environment. The honourable member for Griffiths ( Mr Humphreys) rightly pointed out in his remarks the concern of the Committee about all aspects of the environment. An aspect relating to the built environment is also brought out in this report, and that is that on many occasions the Commonwealth Government uses taxpayers' funds-often a large amount of them-to ensure that Commonwealth buildings are either preserved or built in such a way that the environment is not offended by a new built environment. The report points out cases where hundreds of thousands of dollars have been spent, in addition to the minimum that would be spent, to preserve buildings. Often, Commonwealth governments of whatever persuasion are criticised for not having enough funding concern for the preservation of the National Estate. Whatever funds are spent through other departments, it ought to be borne in mind that in the capital works program of the Department of Housing and Construction, large amounts of money are put forward to support the national heritage in addition to all other areas of funding. I know that this has also been carried out by such instrumentalities as Australia Post. Its most recent report points out that large amounts have been spent merely to preserve the national heritage. I hope that with politicians on both sides supporting this approach we will receive some credit. I hope that the few words in this report point that out clearly.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disruptive effects of the Governments' abandonment of regional development policy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia currently has a population of around 15 million and two-thirds of that population live in seven cities. There are physical, social and economic limitations on further population growth in those cities. By the turn of the century the population in this country is projected to be about 20 million. We are now faced with the large task of planning how and where to house that additional population; how to provide those people with income security, employment and equitable access to community services. Commonsense would lead us to look to policies of regional development in order to meet many of those challenges. Tragically, the Government is pursuing policies which run contrary to commonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time in Australia's history, we have a Federal Government that has no regional development policies, one which has cut funding for urban and regional development programs by 90 per cent. The small allocations made in the 1981-82 Budget were for the purpose of winding up former programs. The growth centres program is now defunct. In April 1981, the Government terminated the decentralisation assistance program and abolished the Decentralisation Advisory Board. It has failed to provide appropriate regional development policies. It has no vision of what our regional policies ought to be or could be. Instead, it has pursued policies that are causing many of our established regional centres to decay. I refer in particular to the areas of Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong.

Firstly, the Government is imposing restrictive and regressive monetarist policies on the Australian economy and the Australian people. In turn, those policies are having a stifling effect on domestic economic activity. In particular, they are having a devastating effect on activity in several important regional economies. Cutbacks in public capital works and Federal funding of the States for community services have taken their toll of regional economies. Again, restrictions on the availability of credit, and the dramatic rises in interest rates have taken their toll on small businesses in regional areas especially. Reductions in household spending capacity have eroded demand for domestically produced goods and services. Australian firms are going to the wall and unemployment is rising.

Secondly, the Government is promoting a major structural shift in Australia's pattern of economic development. In an unbalanced and unco-ordinated way, it is promoting a change from the post-war industrial development strategy of import replacement, in favour of export orientation. Such a shift has profound implications, not least for the viability of many of our nation's regional centres which were built up after World War II.

Let me make clear Labor's position. We support the balanced development of our natural resources and a balanced expansion of our exports of pastoral, agricultural, mineral, energy and manufactured products. The serious problems that face many of our regional communities result not from the fact that we are attempting to expand our national exports so much as from the way in which this Government is promoting that expansion, the rate and pace of which is causing much concern. Specialisation, associated with export orientation, leads to greater degrees of industry centralisation in a few regions and higher levels of ownership concentration in a few hands. Further international integration through trade brings with it costs as well as benefits. To the extent that a nation retains a viable and diversified domestic production base, benefits are maximised and costs minimised. Only then can it have the security of self- reliance. Only then can it have the security of self-defence. Only then can it promote the security of its internal regions. If a nation dismantles its domestic production sectors, if it fails to promote the viability of decentralised regions, it becomes fragmented, vulnerable and dependent.

That is the thrust of this Government's policy of scatter gun development-at the cost of writing a blank cheque for the foreign corporations which control this country. That is the price we pay as a nation for the withdrawl of this Government from its responsibility to co-ordinate the pattern and pace of resource development. That is the cost that is being borne now. and will be borne by future generations, as a result of the failure of the Government to promote broadly-based industrial development.

Let us consider the specific plight of Victoria, which has suffered doubly, first at the hands of a conservative Federal Government and, secondly, from living for years in the shadow of a moribund conservative State government. It has suffered especially, of course, at the hands of this conservative Federal Government. Both governments are in a shambles and divided among themselves. The Fraser Ministry and the 'dries' of its back benches regard Victoria as a museum. They are not prepared to assist its ailing manufacturing sector. They are not interested in the survival of important centres such as Geelong, Ballarat and Bendigo. They are joining forces with the mining companies of Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia and are uprooting their historical connections with the southern States.
I wish to quote from the October 1981 report of the Victorian Department of Economic Development, which states:
Considerable investment funds are thought to be leaving the State and are being reinvested in other States.

The Collins House Group and the wealthy members of the Melbourne Club are transferring Victorian funds to the mineral processing ventures of those northern States. That is the group that is represented by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his cohorts. It is the group that is so strongly represented in the Victorian Government. In fact, that Government is selling out its own people. Let us be clear that the Victorian Government uncritically supports the export-oriented strategy of the Fraser Government. In the 10 years 1970-71 to 1980-81, there has been a net population migration from Victoria of more than 60 ,000. As a result, a number of country towns and regional centres have experienced a population decline.

Let us consider the social cost of this agonising decline, particularly in the three areas that I have mentioned, those, of Geelong, Ballarat and Bendigo. Geelong is Victoria's second largest city and the ninth largest in the nation. It should enjoy all of the advantages of a major population centre. In 1967, it was declared a growth area by the Victorian Government. It has suffered a severe manufacturing employment decline and has an unemployment rate of 9.8 per cent compared with 7 per cent for Victoria as a whole. The Geelong regional Commission has estimated that if unmployment is to be reduced to 6 per cent an additional 3,000 jobs will be required in the region by 1983. I emphasise that we are merely talking about reducing the figure to 6 per cent. In 1973-74, Geelong had 300 manufacturing plants, employing 21,740 people. By 1978-79, the number of plants had fallen to 208 and employment to 18,583. Over half of Geelong's manufacturing employment is now found within four plants, and all are facing real difficulties. In the 1970s, job losses occurred in the textiles and wood product industries. In the 1980s, the vehicle industry faces losses as a result of the Government's policies and measures.

The Geelong Regional Commission has called for the decentralisation of Commonwealth Government offices to that centre. It argues that the serious outflow of tradesmen from the region jeopardises its capacity to pursue downstream activities. It sees the need to provide employment for professional and clerical workers as well as a basis for attracting other productive industries to the region.

Ballarat is another region that has suffered population and job losses. In 1975 -76, it had 141 manufacturing plants, which employed 7,715. By 1978-79, the number of plants had fallen to 131 and employment stood at 6,761. The greatest falls occurred in the highly protected textiles, clothing and footwear industries, the transport equipment industry and the metal industries, the transport equipment industry and the metal products industry. According to the last official figures available, in March 1981 unemployment in Ballarat amounted to 9.5 per cent and some 3,841 persons were registered as unemployed. It is a scandal that the razor gang should have terminated the publishing of local area unemployment details. The information base for regional planning was poor enough before that. Now it is effectively non-existent. How can one plan and how can decisions be made on these vital issues if one cannot at least have public discussions with the people involved to find out how many are unemployed in that region. Local estimates put the current number of unemployed at around 5,000. A recent study by the Ballarat College of Advanced Education has estimated that in September 1981 unemployment in the 15-year to 24-year age group was in excess of 27 per cent. Over 200 people in Ballarat have lost their jobs in the past two weeks. I was informed that today more people are to be laid off at Pridham's abattoirs in that region. That is the disturbing situation in those two cities.

I turn now to the city of Bendigo, which the Government Whip and honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier) represents in this House. Bendigo has also suffered population and job losses. The State Government has failed to act on its promises to build State offices in Bendigo, a new fire station, a new police station and new school at White Hills. I might sound a bit parish pump but I am replying to those people who at times are parish pump politicians, who have made these blind promises and have not kept them. The Federal Government threatens the closure of the ordnance factory in Bendigo, which employs over 600 people, including 126 apprentices which make up about one-third of the student numbers at the Bendigo Technical College. The Federal Government has also decided that engineering courses at the Bendigo College of Advanced Education will be discontinued. Employment at the Bendigo rail workshops has fallen from around 700 in 1970 to around 450 in 1981. This has all happened under the conservative Government of Victoria. Further declines are expected in Bendigo's manufacturing industries, which have already been thumped by this Federal Government's policies.

In January this year the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures argued that the companies were delaying investments until the Government clarified its industry assistance policy. The Victorian Chamber of Manufacturers claimed that 3,695 jobs in Bendigo would be affected by a further reduction in protection and that the viability of industries would be seriously damaged by even a marginal drop in protection. That has been the blind position taken by this Government. This is a conservative government in the national sphere and it is supposed to be working in co-operation with its State colleagues, the Victorian Thompson Government, formerly the Hamer Government. That State is now in the throes of an election. On 3 April the people of Victoria will make their decision. They will make their decision on what has happened. Apart from a period of three years 1972-75 in the national sphere we have seen decades of Liberal leadership. Since 1955 a conservative government has been in control in Victoria. The same conservative Government that has been in power most of that time has allowed this transfer of investment away from Victoria. This transfer has accelerated under the policies of the present Government.

Let me give honourable member's some of the positive programs of a Federal Labor Government. Labor would set up an inquiry into the problems and potentials of regions to provide for more detailed regional information collections. We would establish a regional task force to work in co-operation with the States and local government specifically to build on local initiatives of the people in the area. We would locate Commonwealth Government offices in regional centres. We would co-ordinate Federal, State and local government provisions of services with a view to expanding the provision of services in priority regional centres. We would use the Federal Government's powers over foreign investment to achieve a higher degree of technology transfer and industrial research and development suitable for decentralised location and we would change the charter of the Industries Assistance Commission which is at present concerned with eliminating industries. We would instruct the Commission to identify ways of promoting new industries, especially for regional locations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one who has watched the growth of the Australian Labor Party over a very long period, I cannot understand just what has happened to it. In many respects it was once a great party. If there is any special criticism that one would offer in relation to the ALP it would be in relation to tactics.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is a very historical and important speech. No Government Minister or honourable member representing Victoria has risen in this House to answer the serious charges laid against this Government.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Surely the honourable member for Reid will settle for a former Minister. I was on the question of the tactics of the Australian Labor Party. It is sad to think that it has lost all of its political sense of aggression. I would have thought that the one subject that it would leave alone and not bring into the spotlight would have been a subject which deals with decentralisation. It is one which deals with concern for people who live beyond the boundaries of the great metropolitan cities of this country. I would have thought that the Australian Labor Party would bring to mind the situation that exists in their classic State of New South Wales. I thought it was terribly disturbing to hear a comment made in this House this morning that in some respects New South Wales could be on the verge of bankruptcy. It is a great State, ostensibly led by a leader of great charisma and it is sad that it is on the verge of bankruptcy. If anything contributed to this condition in New South Wales it must be the complete lack of regional development. It is all very well to talk about formal regional development and the setting up of great boards and bureaucracies. But there is another aspect with which I propose to deal and that is the actual contribution made to people who live in not the isolated areas-I will not particularly push the parochial pump in the 15 minutes or so that I have-but those who live beyond the boundaries of the metropolitan areas. I would have thought that of all the subjects the Opposition could have brought up for discussion today, they would have religiously avoided this one.

SPEECH.PARA: I am talking about New South Wales. I suppose in a way it is a blessing to our people-the members of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party in Victoria-that the situation in New South Wales has been exposed. It will act as a very sober warning to those who may have been on the brink of making a decision to support the Labor Party on this occasion. Sometimes voters say to themselves: 'We will give them three years. They cannot do much harm'. But that way of thinking, of course, was totally exposed when the Whitlam Government was in power and this country was brought to its knees. Once the results of what happens in New South Wales are exposed to the people of Victoria, they will affect the election. I am sure they would not take any risk of following the example of a State that has been brought to its knees. If one thing has contributed to that-I repeat it-it has been its complete lack of decentralisation.

We recognise the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) as a sincere man although we totally oppose many of the things he brings forward in this House. He is respected. I think it unfair that the Opposition should have given him the job of presenting a case for a party that is totally condemned for its record of contempt for people who do not live in the great urbanised areas of this country .

I have so much information here that I do not know where to start. I think one very fundamental group which is associated with regional development in its purer sense is that of the local authorities of this nation, wherever they may be, the semi-governmental bodies such as harbour boards but more particularly the shires and municipalities spread throughout the length and breadth of this country. I think there are something like 939 of them. I take the opportunity of explaining that there is a committee of this House-of which I have had the privilege of chairing for many years-appointed by the local government movement. If I speak on local government, I do so with a little bit of experience and with having had the opportunity of seeing the whole spectrum of local government throughout the length and breadth of this country. It was extremely difficult for many years for local government to get any recognition whatsoever. This Government has contributed in a very fundamental sense in two ways. A very meaningful liaison has been created between local government and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I mention the Prime Minister particularly because he made the decision that local government would be brought into the pre-Budget discussions. I think that these meaningful discussions will be held on 1 May. That will be a very effective liaison.

A more important point is that if we want to talk about regional development we have to talk about what we are doing for people who live in those regions and about what we contribute to their quality of life-health, education, communication facilities and air services. This is all part of the general picture. We should not talk about the formal creation of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation-a bureaucracy whose achievements were not very impressive. A meaningful liaison has been established now. It is very important to get to the people at the top when a problem exists.

The next point I wish to raise is the matter of Commonwealth grants. The perfect formula has been adopted-Commonwealth grants are allocated through a State instrumentality. In other words, the money comes from the Commonwealth-I wish the States would remember that from time to time-but it is distributed through a State-created body. The Opposition wants to create regional boards. We on this side of the House have a great apprehension about such boards because the Opposition wants yet again to adopt the policy of centralisation. Perhaps it is not attempting to centralise in Melbourne but it is attempting to centralise in Geelong, Ballarat or Bendigo. According to general standards throughout Australia these areas are highly developed areas.

Let us have a look at one or two other points. I think it is a pretty weak argument to refer to history and say that the Labor Party has a forlorn record but I think memories can sometimes be a bit short. The people who live beyond the metropolitan areas were hammered into the ground during the short period that the Whitlam Government was in power. People who have been governed by State Labor governments have had a much more intimate knowledge of the same sort of experience. I do not want to talk too much about my own State but it is an excellent example of decentralisation. It is interesting to look at a map of New South Wales. Wollongong and Newcastle are really suburbs of Sydney according to our standards of distance. Where else can one find any developed areas in New South Wales? What do we see if we have a look at a map of Queensland? We see a most exciting situation. We see the city of Mt Isa and all that is going on in the north-west. We see the towns of Emerald and Blackwater and the huge developments that are taking place there. One can go to Cairns, Mackay and Bundaberg, which is the city from which you come, Mr Deputy Speaker, up the coast of Queensland. There are exciting developments in each of those areas.

I could talk for 15 minutes or 15 hours about each of these regional developments. Regional development is what is projected by the State government itself and, ultimately, with funds that are provided by the Federal Government. As I said earlier, I think it is a weak argument to go back in history but we suffered a great deal over the period 1972 to 1975. First of all, we in Queensland were stripped of our petrol equalisation concessions. We were stripped of air subsidies. I do not know what his motive was but when the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was the Minister for Social Security he would not receive deputations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—He would not receive deputations from my part of the world at any rate because we were considered to be second rate citizens. What about the Isolated Children's Parents Association? In 1974-1975, after a lot of struggling , debate and so on, it managed to get $9,538,000. The contribution by this Government in 1981-82 for isolated children is $16,729,000. Regional development is keeping people in those areas, keeping them reasonably content and giving them just a few crumbs-we are not looking for more than that-off the rich man's table. But during the term of the Labor Government in Queensland and then during the term of the Federal Labor Government I do not think that more than a few miles of bitumen would have been put down anywhere in the west of the State.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of the Menzies beef roads scheme was an example of regional development. One has to be able to get into a region in order to develop it. The great epic contribution to this nation was the beef roads scheme introduced by the Menzies Government. That is an example of regional development. That involved the creation of communication facilities. I could go on and on about this matter.

Admittedly, last April the Minister for National Development and Energy ( Senator Sir John Carrick) announced that the Federal Government would discontinue its regional development policy because-after all, one cannot argue against this-it felt that it was more properly the responsibility of the States. The States constantly bring before this Government the matter of their sovereign rights and they say: 'Pay, but do not interfere too much'. I refer to road safety which is a very clear and very worrying example of this attitude. The Minister, not only because of the advice, closely examined the situation at Albury-Wodonga and elsewhere-but also because of the record itself, decided to discontinue this bureaucracy. The rate of growth at Albury-Wodonga was 3 per cent and the cost effectiveness was just so out of balance that no responsible government could have continued with that bureaucracy. Certain things were kept in train.

I have been talking about my State but I wish now to refer to South Australia and to what is known as the iron triangle study. I will give a few details about that. The iron triangle study group was formed in February 1981 as a result of a joint Commonwealth-State initiative. The study group was to investigate the most appropriate long term strategies for development in the central part of South Australia, particularly with respect to the major urban centres of Port Augusta, Port Pirie and Whyalla. The study group presented its report to the Prime Minister and to the Premier of South Australia last March. The major conclusion of the study group with respect to development strategies for the region was:

The only strategy identified which will result in growth in the economy of the area is the development of resource-based industries both within the Iron Triangle and within the northern region. Flow effects from such developments will impact on the Iron Triangle cities, and commercially viable service and support industries will develop as a result.

A hard core of resource industry exists. Regrettably, until we see better times this is vitally essential. As I said, I have so much information here that I find it worrying that I cannot deal with it all.

I turn now to defence. I suppose that nothing else is of much value if we cannot defend the country and assure its security. For many years great accent has been placed on northern frontier defence and so on. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), with the co-operation of his advisers, has brought into existence a force known as Norforce. Norforce is a hard core task force which will defend northern Australia. Again, that is a clear indication of what can happen when a government which thinks along the right lines is in power. I cannot understand the behaviour of members of the Labor Party. The Labor Party once was very eminent for its tactics and its strategy. I am surprised that it has brought up a subject, the arguments about which it cannot possibly win. Its record in this field is lamentable. All it did when in government was to hammer people who lived beyond the metropolitan areas into the ground.

Let us contrast the situation in two States. Let us look at what can happen when there is a sense of responsibility and an awareness of decentralisation. I contrast the coal industry in New South Wales which is rapidly falling into shambles with what is happening in the exciting developing coal industry in Queensland, particularly in my area of Blackwater and the central highlands.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers.
Slaughter of Seal Pups
To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for Harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of Harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the Harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the Harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Charles Jones.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

We petition the Federal Government to take immediate action to ban the importation of Harp seal products. We further request the Federal Government to forward our objection to the baby seal slaughter to the Canadian Government.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Australia call on the Canadian Government to end the Harp seal hunt and halt the importation of products derived from the Harp seal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, The Speaker and Members of The House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
That baby Harp seals in Canada are cruelly and unnecessarily slaughtered. We believe that it is endangering the life of the species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: that you communicate our concern to the Canadian Government and join with us in our protest of this barbaric act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We are concerned over the extreme cruelty involved in the Harp seal kill and the great uncertainty of the remaining population of the Harp seal.

Your petitioners humbly pray that pressure is brought to bear on the Canadian Government to stop the Harp seal kill, and in doing so, not only end this cruel slaughter but also the possible extinction of the Harp seal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hearing Aids: Import Duty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned individuals concerned with the welfare of the hearing impaired citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That there are approximately one million people in Australia who suffer severe problems with their hearing.
that the greatest percentage of adults with hearing impairment are not eligible for N.A.L. aids. (1978 Australian Bureau of Statistics. 38.79% of hearing impaired are aged between 45-64 years).
that the accepted useful life of a hearing aid is only 3-5 years.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House reject all recommendations that may subject hearing aids to any import duty (I.A.C. propose 15%) and thus ensure hearing handicapped persons be not further disadvantaged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Falconer and Mr Charles Jones.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their Boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop 'normalised' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide 'non-institutionalised' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from , or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a 'disability' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal IYDP funds-e.g. non-receipt of some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les McMahon and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned do hereby request the Federal Government to abolish the recently imposed Sales Tax of 17 1/2% on Saddlery, Harness and Horse Rugs. This Tax has significantly increased prices of these items and directly affects the livelihood of persons engaged in the industry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that any proposal for sales tax on previously exempt items such as saddlery, harness and horse rugs be reconsidered and withdrawn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bellerive Post Office, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned, wish to retain our historic POST OFFICE for reasons of convenience and because we think that it is an essential part of the character of Bellerive, situated on the eastern shore of Hobart in Tasmania. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government take what action is necessary to stop this closure.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marine Mammal By-products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the Harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That:
(a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and
(b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural evironment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services programme is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important programme.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that moneys be made available to subsidise child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programmes and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Planning Association of Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing effectiveness of the Family Planning Association of Victoria.
In particular that:
Federal Government continue to provide funding to the Family Planning Association of Victoria for clinical services to meet the growing demands of the community.
Increased funding be provided to the Family Planning Association of Victoria's Training, Education and Research Unit for educational services to the community.
All funding be provided on a triennial basis to enable cost-effective long term planning.
The Federal Government grant the Family Planning Association of Victoria exemption from sales tax and allow donations to be tax deductable.

That we, the undersigned, support the expansion of family planning services to ensure that adequate contraceptive information is fully available to all sections of the community, with special consideration given to disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they were greatly pleased with the test broadcast from Melbourne Christian Radio Ltd heard in Melbourne between 18th and 24th February 1982.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that as a matter of urgency you grant a licence for a Christian Radio Station to operate in the Melbourne area.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Australian families will be seriously affected by the budget announcements which include the raising of, or imposition of, Sales Tax on the many items which must be provided by parents for their children's schooling.
We condemn the proposals as a regressive tax measure which will seriously affect Australia's students.

Sales Tax increases will affect the price to parents of a variety of items including school clothing, school footwear, exercise books, books and magazines for reading purposes, stationery, sports equipment, and other school requisites and will seriously disadvantage parents who are already finding it difficult to provide essential educational items.
Your petitioners request that the Government will not impose any further tax on those items which are needed for the educational progress of Australia's students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
