PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Minister for Communications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned members of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union respectfully showeth:

That the Prime Minister of Australia should seek the resignation of the Minister for Communications, failing this the Prime Minister should dismiss the aforementioned Minister. We seek this action following the Minister's apparent lack of concern for the welfare of his employees in the Australian Postal Commission and the Australian Telecommunications Commission.

Staff ceilings imposed as directed by the Minister show that the future employment security of Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union members is jeopardised. It is our educated estimation that these staff ceilings will also effect the standard of service provided to the public by the two commissions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Prime Minister will take immediate action to abide to our desire.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling,Mr Duffy and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway: North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government.
The Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway.
Queensland has suffered a 15% disadvantage over the other states during the past ten years in road funding.
And the state of the highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Showband
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the Australian Parliament as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Showband we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra.

We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We, therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Whales, Dolphins and Seals
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth that:
We think it is immoral and inhumane to kill Whales, Dolphins and Seals and are therefore opposed to it.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government take what action it can to stop the slaughter of Whales, Dolphins and Seals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 25 of the Australia-Japan Foundation Act 1976, I present the annual report of the Australia-Japan Foundation 1980-81. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a short statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The establishment almost six years ago of the Australia-Japan Foundation was an important event in the development of Australia's relations with Japan. It is no less important today. The Government intends to maintain its support for the Foundation's development and activities in the sphere of trade and commerce and in the wider field of broadly-based cultural and personal exchanges. On the occasion of the visit to Australia in January 1980 by the then Prime Minister of Japan, the late Mr Masayoshi Ohira, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced that the Australian Government intended to increase substantially the funds made available to the Foundation. As a result of this increase, during the 12 months covered by this report the Foundation was able to support over 250 projects-more than double the number for the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foundation, during its five years of operation, has supported a wide range of activities, including many important new initiatives. While the trading and financial links with Japan continue to strengthen, there is still much we do not know about each other's society. Foundation programs emphasising people to people contact and the dissemination of knowledge about one country in the other seek to lower the cultural barriers and give us a better understanding of each other. The attention which has been given to the involvement of ordinary Australians and Japanese through the Foundation's travel grant and media programs has ensured that its focus has not been narrowly academic. Nevertheless , support for scholarship, particulary the development of Australian studies in Japan and Japanese studies in Australia, occupies an important place in the Foundation's overall activities. Other important projects involving people to people contact include support for exchanges of Australian and Japanese youth and sporting exchanges. The AJF Trophy Australia-Japan Golf Match, now an important event in the international golfing calendar, brings Australian and Japanese professional and amateur golfers together in a unique event. Wide television coverage of the event has ensured that it is enjoyed annually by millions of Australians and Japanese.

The Foundation has sought to keep people in both countries well informed of its activities. It distributes its own newsletter and more than 60 journalists and newspaper executives from Australia and Japan have visited the other country under the Foundation's journalist exchange program. Other major media projects have included the joint production of television documentary programs on both countries and a series of film festivals. Some new areas of Foundation activity include: A major conference of Australian and Japanese sister city representatives to promote community exchanges between sister cities; the establishment of a Press award in Japan to encourage wider and more informed coverage of Australia in the Japanese Press; support for a series of visits by Australian trade union officials to Japan; and, in association with the International Cultural Corporation of Australia, financial assistance towards an Australia-wide exhibition of the Idemitsu collection of Japanese paintings and ceramics. These are only some examples of new areas of contact between Australians and Japanese which the Foundation is developing.

Members of the Australia-Japan Foundation are normally appointed for five years and the terms of all the original members of the Foundation, including its first Chairman, Sir Russel Madigan, have now expired. I pay tribute to Sir Russel and the other members for their excellent work during these past five years in establishing the Foundation on a sound basis and in developing such a wide program of activities. I have much pleasure in tabling the fifth annual report of the Australia-Japan Foundation for 1980-81.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-The Opposition welcomes the statement and joins with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in expressing our appreciation of the work done by members of the Australia-Japan Foundation. It is an interesting foundation. I think I can use the words of the Executive Director, Professor Hocker, when he said that the purpose of the Foundation is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to encourage a closer relationship between the peoples of Australia and Japan to further the mutual knowledge and understanding of those peoples . . .
That is important because never before in our relationship has there been a greater need to achieve knowledge and understanding of each other.

It has been said, particularly when talking about money and trade, that one country might need the other country more than that country needs it. For example, it could be said that in money terms we desperately need the Soviet trade because it is on a ratio of five to one in our favour. In that context, it could be said that Australia needs Japan more than Japan needs Australia. The trade figures confirm that. Australian exports to Japan represented 27 per cent of our total exports and were valued at over $5 billion. Our imports were somewhat less: They represented 19 per cent of our total imports and were valued at $3.5 billion. The Foundation is doing very important work because it operates outside the market place and it endeavours to show to the Japanese that Australia is not just a farm with a mine on it; it is a country which produces agricultural goods and minerals. The Foundation seeks to develop personal contacts between Australians and Japanese and to assist with the dissemination of knowledge about each other.

The Japanese perceptions of Australia were examined recently in two detailed and constructive papers prepared by the Japan secretariat. I might add that it appears that these papers were leaked to the Press as they were featured in the Sydney Morning Herald. Leaks can be useful because we of the Opposition do not have access to the secretariat's work, nor do we have any access to the work of the committees. Perhaps that matter ought to be remedied at some stage. These reports indicate, perhaps of some surprise to Australians, how the Japanese perceive us. The Japanese regard Australians as rich, as having a derivative culture and as being rather racist. As the Japanese perceive countries in a hierarchical order, the West, the United States and the English speaking countries are now at the apex. They have replaced China, which is the source of much of Japan's culture. It is deemed that Australia, by association, is part of this Anglo-American group of capitalists that run the world's economy, though Australia is at the bottom of it. I suppose that part is accurate.

Our economic success is seen as the result of luck, through the possession of natural resources, and not because of hard work. The Japanese appreciate the fact that we seem to be successful because we are rich. In the past-I am not going to condemn them-they have not shown a great deal of interest in the poor, but they have improved their performance. Net overseas development assistance disbursements increased by 29.6 per cent in the national currency to $3,304m in 1980, equivalent to 0.32 per cent of gross national product. Australia, which must continue to do better, devoted 0.48 per cent of GNP in this area.

It is vital that the programs of the Foundation continue to be recognised. I commend those projects which are directed at the youth of both countries. The working holidays scheme which exists between the two countries is excellent. It is worth noting that Australia is the only country with which Japan has such a scheme. I note that there is trade union representative on the board of directors of the Foundation. I note he was lately appointed. I also note that trade union matters have been all but ignored in each of the Foundation's programs. Japan has a very strong and healthy trade union movement.

The work of the Foundation's library is to be encouraged and funds should be made available to have as much Australian source material as possible translated into Japanese. We have a library but there is no point in having a wealth of printed material available in Tokyo if it is not printed in Japanese. The work of the Foundation staff in Tokyo and the Australian Information Service at the Australian Embassy in Japan could be analysed to ensure that there is no duplication of effort and that the competence in Japanese of Australian officials doing information work is very high. The AIS, if it does not already do so, could leave inquiries from the Japanese public to the Foundation office while it does the job of supplying the Japanese Government and Japanese business and journalists with information from Australia, written in Japanese.

We of the Opposition stress the importance of having sufficient high quality printed matter in Japanese. They are sophisticated people who need to be persuaded to take an interest in Australia. The material should reflect the subtle aspects of Japanese cultural interests and be made to appeal to it. I commend all the efforts that the Foundation is making to promote language studies. We must have Australians who are not only competent in their chosen profession but also fluent in Japanese. Having people who are merely linguists ensures only that we have some potential good quality interpreters. Let us remember that interpreting is a difficult art that needs close study and it is not always given full support in Australia. Much good work has been done by the Foundation and much still needs to be done with imagination, money and foresight .

In conclusion, I suggest that Australia should take some initiatives with Japan in securing peace in South East Asia. I think there is a good chance for Australia to take initiatives with the Japanese, particularly in respect of the difficulties between China and Vietnam and also the Kampuchean problems. I want to see a lessening of the hostilities between the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations and Vietnam. I think our ally, the United States, is somewhat unwise in urging re-armament or taking up a greater share of what is called the defence burden. I have just seen an address given in Canberra by Professor Hideo Hitaki, who makes very much the same point. In talking about the link between government and business in Japan, he made a significant point by referring to the fact that the American Government has begun to urge Japan to accept a larger role in the defence of the West, which has some connotations for Australia as it is on the rim of the Pacific. The analysis in Japan of the proposal for increased defence expenditure was that the Japanese political elites, who do not believe there is any serious Soviet threat , felt that in order to soften American pressure on trade Japan had to increase its defence appropriations. Even though they were sceptical of the interpretation by the United States of the international situation, Japanese political elites were ready to accede to the suggested increased defence role in order to maintain good relations with the United States. This opinion is widely held not only in the ruling party in Japan and in the defence agency but also in the Foreign Ministry, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the business community. It is for that reason, apart from the excellent work that has been done by the Foundation, that we must take further initiatives with Japan. We live in this region together and we want to guarantee peace. I think we can do it by taking initiatives such as those I have in mind.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF ADDITIONAL TRAINING AND SLEEPING ACCOMMODATION AT RAAF BASE, LAVERTON, VICTORIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed works which were referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of additional training and sleeping accommodation, R.A.A.F. Base, Laverton, Vic.

The proposal is for new facilities to support an increase of about 17 per cent in the number of staff and students at the Royal Australian Air Force school of radio. The RAAF needs more people skilled in electronics and radio for new equipments being introduced into the service, such as the new tactical fighter. The work will consist of the following elements: Two-storey cluster groups of accommodation units for 208 airmen; a three-storey training building; and associated external works, services and landscaping.

In reporting favourably, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has also raised two issues on which I believe the House would wish to have an indication of the Government's views. Firstly, the Committee has noted that it was disturbed to hear evidence of a failure rate of 50 per cent at the RAAF radio school among apprentice recruits. I am advised that the current failure rate is now lower than this. Over the past three years, it has been around 36 per cent. I am also advised that recruitment selection criteria are kept under review, and that the school is giving added attention to improvements in training methods, to raise the pass rate.

Secondly, the Committee has suggested a reconsideration of the recruitment of young women as trade apprentices in the RAAF, having also noted that the basic principle for equal opportunities would appear to be selectively applied and in need of urgent review. I am advised that up to date the policy has been to provide opportunities for women to obtain technical training through the adult technical training scheme, which recruits down to the age of 17 years. The RAAF is further considering its ability to provide a proper domestic environment and training facilities for women apprentices. The estimated cost of the work is $5. 6m at August 1981 prices. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning may proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

While I am on my feet, I draw to the attention of the Minister for Housing and Construction, whose interest in housing in Victoria is very well known--

—I draw to the Minister's attention the urgent need to do more about Service housing generally. DEBATE.TITLE: UPGRADING OF AIRPORT FACILITIES FOR THE INTRODUCTION OF DOMESTIC WIDE-BODY AIRCRAFT AT ADELAIDE AND HOBART AIRPORTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed works which were referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Upgrading of airport facilities for the introduction of domestic wide-body aircraft at the Adelaide and Hobart airports.

In the original motion of 27 August 1981, the House referred to the Committee proposed works at six airports. The Committee previously reported on four locations, Coolangatta, Melbourne, Perth and Sydney in report 11 of 1981, recommending the construction of these works at a total estimated cost of $12. 85m at August 1981 prices. Planning and implementation of these works are now in hand. The Committee's current report deals with the proposed work at Adelaide and Hobart and completes the original reference. The works to be provided by the Commonwealth to accommodate the wide-body aircraft at Adelaide and Hobart will include, where necessary: Alteration and expansion of terminal facilities; strengthening and extension of runway, taxiway and apron pavements, and associated engineering works.

In recommendation 1, the Committee states that there is justification and a need for a further study by a parliamentary committee into the subject of aircraft noise as a matter of urgency. Accordingly, the House of Representatives should refer to the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation the matter of aircraft noise, and that the Standing Committee be requested to inquire into and report on all aspects of aircraft noise within and adjacent to major urban areas. This matter has been referred to the Minister for Transport ( Mr Hunt) for his consideration. Recommendation 2 states that Adelaide Airport will need to operate at its present site until an alternative location can be found, land acquired and new facilities provided. The Committee also recommends that planning for the future airport needs of Adelaide should start now. The Minister for Transport has informed me that the above recommendation is in hand. The South Australian Airfield Committee consisting of representatives of the State and Commonwealth governments is actively pursuing this issue and is expected to report before the end of this year.

Recommendation 3 states that projections of aircraft and passenger movements for Adelaide indicate these will increase and that existing facilities at Adelaide Airport are inadequate to meet present and future demand, especially for wide-body aircraft. The Government agrees with this. Recommendation 4 states that, as an interim measure, the proposed extensions and upgrading of pavements and the terminal extensions should proceed as proposed. The Government agrees with this. Recommendation 5 states that there is scope for more rigorous application of noise abatement procedures and that such procedures should be immediately reviewed by the Department of Transport, especially such aspects as the operation of light executive jets and the ground running of turbo-propellor aircraft within curfew hours. This matter has been referred to the Minister for Transport for his consideration.

Recommendation 6 states that there is a need to upgrade and extend the apron pavement at Hobart to eliminate congestion and to provide for increasing Boeing 727 operations. The Government agrees with this. Recommendation 7 states that on the basis of airline projections for Boeing 727 aircraft at Hobart, the proposed runway and taxiway upgrading is not a proven necessity at this time and that this work should be deferred for at least two years unless pavement distress begins to appear earlier. The Government notes this recommendation. However, the pavement condition will be kept under review, as the effect on the pavement by the aircraft traffic forecast by the airlines will be only marginally less than that forecast by the Department of Transport. This pavement is constructed of material which would be seriously affected were water allowed to enter through deterioration of the bituminous surface. Accordingly, the work will be implemented immediately it is found necessary to protect the pavement from any deterioration.

Recommendation 8 states that justification for the fillet widening and turning nodes for wide-body operation has not been shown and that this work should not proceed. The Government accepts this recommendation. However, if it is found necessary to undertake the runway and taxiway upgrading, consideration will need to be given to the economic advantage of proceeding with the fillet widening and turning nodes at the same time. In paragraph 9 the Committee recommends that modification of the existing domestic terminal be made for international operations at Hobart Airport rather than providing a separate international terminal building. In regard to this recommendation members will be aware of Ansett's withdrawal from the Hobart to New Zealand route and a reappraisal of what may be necessary at Hobart is in process. A separate international terminal building will not be proceeding pending this reappraisal.

The estimated cost of the work recommended by the Committee is $8.85m at January 1982 prices, being $8m at Adelaide and $0.85m at Hobart. The Government accepts this recommendation. With the exception noted previously, the Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning may proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be said that the report is good in parts. I think that the reason for this view is the degree of public involvement, in particular at the Adelaide hearing on 3 December and again at the hearing that continued in Melbourne. In the submissions that the Committee received, there were documented some 70 or more letters from residents, the vast majority of whom were opposed to the extensions. I think that the Government needs to give a great deal of weight to the views of the residents who have to put up with the inconvenience of an airport. It is also fair to put on record that the residents , in the main, to my knowledge, are not opposed to Adelaide or South Australia having an international airport, although, by their enemies, they are portrayed as holding such views. They are, in fact, trying to ensure that Adelaide is serviced by an international airport, giving due consideration to the people who may have to live in the vicinity.

SPEECH.PARA: At the hearing on 3 December I made a number of submissions and I still hold by those submissions. I want briefly to refer to them. One submission was that the State and Federal governments should declare the site for the new international airport. That has been on the cards for many months now. I am concerned that if we do not get a declaration of where the site is to be before the commencement of building is to take place then we will have a situation whereby the people currently around the airport will be fobbed off. The second main proposition that I put concerned noise proofing. This has been carried out in other countries. I am glad to see that the Committee did not wipe that off but I want to pursue the matter because I do not feel that the answer given today is sufficient to assure me-certainly my constituents, particularly those residents around the airport-that the Government will take this matter seriously. The third matter was that of the curfew. Only those people who live in the vicinity of an airport-I live very close to the Adelaide Airport-understand the problems of having to put up with jets flying in and out inside the curfew hours. That is one of the most harassing things that the residents have had to put up with for some time.

I have said that the report is good in parts. We will have to await the action of the Government flowing from the report to see whether or not the good parts or the bad parts are picked up. I want to make mention of what I suppose could be called a minority report of Senator Foreman, on page 23, entitled 'Senator Foreman's views'. I believe that Senator Foreman has listened to the problems of the residents. In his minority report he states:
(a) tangible and positive steps must be taken now by the Commonwealth and State Governments for the construction of a new airport for Adelaide;
(b) the present curfew must be maintained and more rigorously enforced;
(c) the operations by small executive jets inside the curfew must cease forthwith; likewise the ground running of turbo-propellor aircraft;

These are three of the areas that I touched on and about which I made submissions. The last point refers to the problem caused by the ground running of Fokker Friendship aircraft at Adelaide Airport. They run sometimes for two to three hours, starting at 2 o'clock in the morning. Once one is awakened by them, the opportunity to get back to sleep is lost.

The fourth point raised in Senator Foreman's views is that of noise proofing. Whilst he does not take anything away from the recommendations of the Standing Committee that the matter be referred to an inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, he has stated fairly strongly the view that all schools and hospitals-particularly those in flight paths of the main runway-must have sound proofing treatment where necessary. The question of air conditioning is dealt with likewise. These are things that will come. They will have to come. Certainly they have been tackled in other countries where within certain radii of runways or in particular zones surrounding airports people are reimbursed for soundproofing. The fifth point raised by Senator Foreman is that noise abatement procedures outside the curfew be rigorously enforced and that punitive action be taken against operators who do not comply with the procedures; that is, other than those who break the curfew because of safety or emergency reasons. I commend Senator Foreman's views and feel that he was receptive to the minority of the people of Adelaide-that is, the residents who have to put up with the inconvenience of an airport.

I come now to the other minority report, that of Senator Martyr. Perhaps this is where we find the bad parts. I do not find that surprising because I was able to be at the hearing in Adelaide and I felt that Senator Martyr was not responsive to the views of the public and, quite frankly, was rather aggressive. On page 24 of the report, Senator Martyr said:

. . . no hard evidence was adduced to prove psychological or physiological damage or distress of such proportions as to warrant the Joint Committee's recommendation. Nor was there any hard evidence adduced to prove structural or mechanical damage to homes or other buildings.

For God's sake, I do not know what the man expected. Did he expect the residents to bring in broken windows, doors hanging off their hinges and so on? The transcript shows that a number of residents at that public hearing invited him to their houses at the time flights were taking off. I well recall one old lady referring to the fact that she could do a jig without getting off her seat. When the jets took off the vibration was such that her feet were dancing an Irish jig . I am quite sure that that would be acknowledged by the Chairman of the Committee and those who were at that hearing. I have to discount Senator Martyr' s views because he has shown a clear bias towards the Department of Transport, the technocrats, and has ignored the people who put their views as to what they had seen and experienced.

The quality of the general recommendations and conclusions of the report is pleasing but, as I said at the beginning, it depends on what the Government does with those recommendations. What will happen to the proposition that there be a parliamentary study as a matter of urgency of the question of noise? Certainly those members of the Public Works Committee at the hearings I attended heard the views of the residents. I hope they will use their influence wherever possible to make sure that the Government accepts the report in full.

On the general question of airports and the people who have to put up with them , it is important for this Parliament to recognise majorities and minorities. In this case I want to talk about minorities. In any democratic society one has to accept the decisions and wishes of majorities but we cannot in all cases ignore the views of minorities. The people around Adelaide Airport are looking for help and assistance. They are not trying to hold back progress; they want people to understand their problems, to have sympathy and to try to accept some responsibility. They are saying to the public in general and to this Government that if they are to have imposed on them an international airport with increased traffic, more noise and all of the other problems that go with it, the Government should do a number of things to look after their particular problems, including the problem of noise.

The Committee in its recommendations accepts the need for some inquiry. That recommendation will not have gone far enough if it turns out to be an inquiry looking into things for years. That is the concern I have. But if the views of the minority are to be given due consideration then I think that the majority- that is, the travelling public and the rest of society who benefit from technological advances such as international airports-have to be prepared in part to pay some of the cost to make life a bit more comfortable, a bit more reasonable, for the minority; that is, those people who live around Adelaide Airport. No doubt people who live near airports in other States feel the same.

Statements have been made by Ministers and the Prime Minister on the upgrading of airports for wide-bodied jets. However, there is no doubt that upgrading will go ahead to cater for international flights. The question of the safety of people who live around airports then arises. Only recently an exercise was conducted at Adelaide Airport in the main by the Department of Transport and various other safety and emergency organisations. I have explained to the House on a previous occasion that that exercise was nothing less than a farce. I described it, I think aptly, as being like a transcript from a Dad's Army television production. If we are to accept the responsibilities for upgrading airports to handle wider-bodied jet international flights we have to start to take safety seriously. The exercise that was held in Adelaide was a joke. I understand that similar exercises are held annually. I believe that the frequency of these exercises has to be upgraded to a point where they are held at least three or four times a year and perhaps more often. I believe that the various emergency services have to be involved, that governments-Federal, State and local-have to be prepared to put in finance to make these services worth while and able to cope with the kinds of disasters we have seen in other countries.

We saw recently the disasters which occurred at Washington, Boston and in Japan . Australia has been extremely lucky in this respect. The flying times of aircraft in Australia are as high as those in other countries. However, the number of accidents is well down in this country. This makes us all the more vulnerable for the accident to happen. I certainly hope that when an accident does happen it will not be in Adelaide. I hope that the people responsible will start to take seriously the question of safety.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, the report of the Committee is good in parts. The good parts will come forward if this Government is serious about the issues that have been brought up. These issues concern the minorities-the people who live around the airport. I wish to thank the Chairman of the Committee for his assistance in preparing the report and in the discussions we have had. I also thank him for the assistance he has given me and to the people of Adelaide. I look forward to seeing the people of Adelaide next week when we again deal with the question of upgrading Adelaide Airport to international status. I am sure that the Chairman and the Committee will take seriously the views of the residents which will be put most firmly next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing to see the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey) in the House. I have the greatest regard for the honourable member, who is the Chairman of the Public Works Committee. I think he does a very good job as Chairman. However, I am afraid that I disagree with some of the recommendations that have been made in the Committee's report concerning the upgrading of airport facilities for the introduction of domestic wide-bodied aircraft at Hobart Airport. We are supposed to be looking to the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to tell honourable members a little about the geography of Tasmania. Tasmania is an island with a population of 420,000 people. Tasmanian members get rubbished in this place by honourable members on both sides for our pork barrelling, for the way we look for freight equalisation subsidies, subsidies for our apples, et cetera. We are trying to get Tasmania on its feet and one of the important ways in which that can be done is through tourism. Therefore we do not just look at the present situation-we look to the future. The only way we are going to survive is to get people to come to our beautiful island-the most beautiful island in the world. We want people to come and appreciate what we have to offer. The only way in which they can come to Tasmania-travel by the seaways has been mucked up by many things which I could mention-is by air. We are dependent on this form of transport.

At present Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines fly into Tasmania. However, we want international flights to come to our State. We do not want flights just from New Zealand. We want international carriers to bring people to our beautiful island. Therefore we have to prepare and make facilities available. I do not want to criticise the Department of Transport or anybody else, but I get sick of other people making decisions for Tasmanians. As I said, we need to be forward looking. When Sir Denham Henty built a beautiful airport and terminal at Launceston everybody said: 'What are they building that for? It will never be used'. It is certainly being used at the moment and it is certainly an example of what forward thinking can be all about. It seems a bit stupid to me--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the north west coast?

—The honourable member for Braddon is a dashed good member, but I ask him to give me a chance to get my mind flowing the way I want it to flow. I am not owned by Ansett and TAA. They can do what they like. But I am a politician and like the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) and the honourable member for Phillip (Mr Birney). I represent people. Therefore we do not have to bend to the will and wish of TAA and Ansett, or the Department of Transport or anybody else. They might say what they want for Hobart, but it does not follow that that is what Hobart wants. Hobart wants a separate international terminal which can be used by people visiting our State. Surely we should not expend $650,000 on renovating or altering the present terminal when it will cost only $950,000 to construct a new terminal. It is common sense to spend a little extra and build a new terminal that can be used by everybody. We do not want to be at the whim or fancy of anybody.
—Why should we be?

—We should not be. Everybody who comes into Tasmania would be able to use such a facility. If I could take a little bit of credit-as a rule I do not like taking credit-I said to the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) that it is absolutely imperative that we have a separate terminal. I think that the Government is now going to reappraise the situation and hopefully we can get a new terminal.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the whole situation is a bit stupid. I heard a few little tidbits-I am sure the honourable member for Canning would not mind me saying this-concerning Ansett and TAA which at the moment have a monopoly on air services to Hobart although we have a few little airlines. It is true that Ansett has pulled out of the New Zealand run and left the service to TAA. I have heard it said on behalf of one airline: 'Oh, it is impossible to build a new terminal because the only place it can be built is alongside our competitor's terminal'. It is argued that the terminal should not be built because its passengers would suffer a little bit of inconvenience. That is a lot of stupidity when we are comparing a cost of $650,000 with $950,000. I hope that the Government will heed not just my advice but also the advice of most Tasmanians who are looking to the future.

I do not want to be continually criticised for pork barrelling about apples and about freight equalisation. Tasmanians want to be able to stand on their own feet. The rest of Australia wants Tasmania; we want to be independent. We want a terminal which will be used not just by TAA or Ansett but by future Tasmanians including Tasmanians from the north and north west. I notice that the honourable member for Braddon is nodding his head in agreement. On how many occasions have we criticised the way in which roads are constructed? We have seen bulldozers and other equipment moved in to build a road. However, after about three or four miles of road have been built the machinery and men are taken away to somewhere else. Would it not be common sense to think of the future when we are considering the upgrading of runways at Hobart? Would it not be better to do a bit of forward planning? We all know that changes are being made in the airline industry every day. The airlines are even cutting fares around Australia at the moment. TAA has cut fares because it cannot get the passengers to travel on its wide-bodied aircraft. But the airline cannot cut fares into Tasmania because wide-bodied aircraft are not used on that service. The point I want to make is that we have to look to the future; we have to make decisions for the future. We should disregard the Department of Transport and the airlines which are interested only in their own area and start thinking about people. Let us start looking to the future. If we do we might get somewhere.

I do not wish to condemn the report of the Public Works Committee. If the honourable member for Canning does not mind me saying so, the Committee has done a dash good job. It has presented only the facts. However, I would like to quote the following statement from the Committee's report. The Committee said:

The Committee regrets that works relating to international facilities at Hobart were not referred to it in conjunction with other works proposed for the Hobart Airport. Failure to include such works in the reference to the Committee has denied the people of Hobart, airline and tourist interests, from publicly commenting on the proposals.
The people of Tasmania are the ones to comment on those proposals, not the Department of Transport, Ansett or TAA.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, before this debate was adjourned, I was replying to the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) who made the point that the coal industry is in difficulty. I mentioned that employment had increased to such an extent that it is now in excess of the 1952 post-war peak.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the performance of the industry in recent times has been extremely impressive. Exports of New South Wales coal in 1980-81 rose by 8.4 per cent to a record 23.7 million tonnes. That is hardly the performance of an industry in the doldrums.
