The Joint Coal Board report for 1980-81 puts the prospects for New South Wales coal exports in 1981-82 at 27 million tonnes, as against 23 million tonnes for the previous year. The report, which puts New South Wales domestic consumption at 28 million tonnes for 1981-82, states:

Thus, in the Board's view, total disposals of coal to all markets should increase to about 55.0 million tonnes in 1981-82. . . . this would require a raw coal output for the year of about 65.0 million tonnes. The coal industry has the capacity to produce this amount.
The Coal Board's long-term prosperity chart, which is contained in the report, shows that by the 1990s exports will quadruple and there will be a trebling of domestic consumption.

Development is also taking place in the public sector of the coal mining industry where expenditure is as impressive as is the large scale increase in private expenditure. In New South Wales, a great deal of progress is being made in the development of coal loaders. At Port Kembla, for example, in September 1981 the loading facilities had a maximum hourly rate of 2,500 tonnes, but by the end of 1982 it is expected to increase to 5,000 tonnes. Over this 12-month period, the port is being dredged from a depth of 11.6 metres to one of 15 metres. Nominal vessel size has increased from 75,000 tonnes to 110,000 tonnes. As well, the annual capacity of the Port Kembla loader will increase over the same period from 7.5 million tonnes to 15 million tonnes.

A similar situation prevails in Newcastle, especially with the development of the new Kooragang Island facility. Without going into all of the particulars about the increased depth and the maximum hourly rate-impressive though they may be-I summarise the Newcastle situation by saying simply that the annual capacity of the Newcastle loading facilities will be increased from 18 million tonnes to 25 million tonnes in the 12-month period. That is obviously an extremely impressive development in the State of New South Wales.

I know that there are knockers. Doubtless I will be followed in this debate by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), a prospect almost too horrible to contemplate. But we have to face the facts of life. He will be a Jonah with regard to the coal mining industry. He will point to current problems in the industry and disregard the mark of confidence demonstrated by the enormous increase in private investment in the coal mining industry which, whilst not providing the most lucrative returns for the current year or even the next financial year, will reap over a period a very lucrative harvest for the entrepreneurs involved. The honourable member should have more confidence and faith and give credit where it is due. I believe it is due to those entrepreneurs and certainly to the Government of New South Wales. It is true that more public money could be expended and that more loading facilities could be provided, but we can also have more than we need at a given point in time. It is important to obtain a rate of expansion and growth which is not inhibiting. We might be dragging the chain a little in the development of our coal loaders, but that has a great deal to do with the adequacy and flow of funds from Commonwealth to State instrumentalities and governments.

One of the worst things that could happen to the industry at the moment-I acknowledge that it has troubles on the industrial front-is to follow at the Federal level policies which will aggravate the situation. I acknowledge some of the points made by the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie). His speech was very well informed, if I may say so. He has obviously had the benefit of talks with colliery owners. He drew attention to the incidence of industrial turbulence and the like which are of the very nature of coal mining industries throughout the world; it is the case today and always has been. Doubtless it reflects the element of danger and the bad features involved in this type of employment. It is true that wages are now beginning to reflect the disabilities and adversities which employees in the industry suffer. Employees now have better hours and higher wages, as they should. In recent times industrial disputation has been engaged in to prevent the erosion of living standards which has occurred as a result of this Government's policies and its failure to index wages and taxation. Also, there have been efforts to obtain a prosperity loading which is a justifiable demand on a prosperous industry.

The worst thing that can happen now is to disturb the comparative quiet and tranquility that prevails in the industry by introducing aggressive industrial legislation, particularly of the kind that is proposed at present. What an absurd thing it would be if the Government went to the coal mining industry now with its proposal to create company unions. If it really wants to set the industry aflame, bring about disruption and destroy our export potential and the confidence of people who want to purchase coal from Australia, it will in that way aggravate the industrial scene in the coal mining industry. If it wants to contrive a recipe to blow asunder the industry's impressive prospects, tell the coal miners that the company union concept will be introduced. Coal miners in Australia, or anywhere else in the world would never concede to such a ridiculous proposal.

On the other hand, tell them that compulsory unionism, which has been traditional in the industry in this country, and many others, will not be permitted. The Government should tell them that you intend to invoke in private enterprise-and in the coal mining industry in particular-a private enterprise counterpart of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) legislation. I would not want to be a coal entrepreneur, an investor, in that situation. However, I would not be surprised if this Government resorted to that course of action. I have the feeling that this Government would even set out to preserve its flagging electoral prospects by creating industrial disputation, by provoking trouble in industries such as the coal mining industry.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you have been very tolerant, as is usually your demeanour. The purpose of these Bills is to make alterations to the payments made in respect of long service leave in the coal mining industry and also to make alterations in respect of the coal mining research industry provisions. In that connection and in the very short time I have left I want to raise one matter which concerns the Illawarra area and which especially involves the research program which is financed by one of the Bills being debated at present. The Illawarra area in the vicinity of Port Kembla, as the honourable member for Macarthur knows, has a very great problem in disposing of coal wash refuse. The honourable member for Macarthur, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) and I, have had representations from the Wollongong council for the financing of a large-scale environmental program to deal with this phenomenon. The fact is that whereas up to recent times some 3.7 million tonnes of wash refuse has been generated annually, this is moving up to 14 million tonnes with the new Port Kembla loader facility coming on service. In the second stage of the loader facility it will go to a massive 22 million tonnes of refuse disposal each year. I know that certain programs are financed from the proceeds of this research levy. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick ) in another place has told me of these things and of the fact that $190,000 has been allocated for a study of colliery waste disposal practices in Australia. This was initiated in 1979. I want to make the point that that is not good enough; it is not a substitute for an effective environmental impact study in regard to this problem. It would be silly to cause all the States to undertake such a study. We should be looking at it from the standpoint of a Commonwealth initiative which would bring benefit to all the coal mining regions in Australia .

In conclusion I believe the coal mining industry, while mildly despondent this year, has a great future. When the Opposition comes to government, which is a very likely prospect in the not too distant future, that industry can be assured of every backing and governmental support, especially in respect of the public services that are necessary to aid and abet those private entrepreneurs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity to follow my colleague from the Illawarra region, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson), particularly as it gives me the opportunity immediately to nail a bit of the nonsense he has just spoken. When he said that we are dragging the chain on the coal loaders, I presume he was talking about the Australian Labor Party of New South Wales, which has done so little to increase the capacity to export coal in that State. He said that the adequacy of coal loaders has a lot to do with the adequacy of federal funding. The nonsense of that is evidenced from the fact that the private enterprise sector offered to build a coal loader at Botany Bay in New South Wales in 1975. The then Liberal-Country Party State Government accepted that proposition after an environmental impact study. This was cancelled by the new State Labor Government in 1976. We are now in 1982; six years on and there has been no significant increase whatsoever in the capacity to export coal out of New South Wales, although a loader is now under construction at Port Kembla.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that the inadequate level of coal loading facilities out of New South Wales, particularly from Sydney and Port Kembla, is due simply and uncomplicatedly to the refusal of the State Government of New South Wales to allow private enterprise to build a coal loader. It has nothing whatsoever to do with any alleged or imaginary lack of federal funding. It is incredible that the Labor Party has the capacity to rewrite history in this matter, just as it manages to rewrite history on a date relating to early November 1975.

I am intrigued too that the honourable member for Hughes suggests there are only short term problems in the coal industry and that the evidence of investment and increasing employment shows that people still have immense faith in the future even though they are losing their shirts today. I think what he has to recognise is that the level of investment that has gone on certainly will enable some very efficient and modern mines to survive this present problem, but that there is an inevitability of closures of coal mines, particularly underground coal mines and particularly those in my electorate as well as in the electorates of the honourable member for Hughes and the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). There is an inevitability of closures if the present situation persists. That present situation is being severely worsened by the anti-coal mining policies of the New South Wales State Labor Government, not simply in relation to coal loaders but also in respect of the secret tax that that Government imposed on the industry through enormous rises in rail freights along with, of course, the requirement that all coal should travel by rail, rather than by the far cheaper method of road transport. This system is to be introduced later this year when the new Port Kembla coal loader begins operating . It will add enormously to the costs of production of coal mines that are already suffering huge losses. There will be an inevitability of closures of coal mines and a loss of jobs if this takes place.

The relevance of these facts to this Excise Tariff (Coal) Amendment Bill is clear-cut because this Bill requires the industry to pay an excise in order to do various things, including, of course, some coal research. The capacity of the industry to keep meeting charges of this nature is being severely limited by its unfortunate financial experience right now. I must say I acknowledge the point made by the honourable member for Hughes that the speech made by the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) was very well researched indeed and was full of some very significant facts. One of those facts was that 11 million tonnes of coal that should be exported from New South Wales in the coming financial year will no longer be exported because of a lack of capacity to load the coal and because of continual industrial disruption, particularly at the port level. The fact that this 11 million tonnes of coal will not be exported will have an enourmous impact on the coal industry. For example-perhaps the Labor Party should think about this a little more-there is about one employee for every 2, 000-odd tonnes of coal that is mined. If 11 million tonnes of coal is done away with, well over 5,000 existing or potential jobs in the coal mining industry will be done away with.

In my area I am looking already at a situation in which substantial reductions have occurred in the number of people employed in the coal industry because of the Wran Government's anti-coal policies in that region. The thought of 5,500 jobs not simply at risk but inevitably lost or else not fulfilled-the jobs will simply not turn up as they should in view of the enormous investment in new mines that has been going on-is something that is incredible at a time when the industry, according to the honourable member for Hughes, faces a great future and is going through only a temporary downturn. The problems that will face the industry from losing that kind of skilled labour are serious enough, but even more serious is the fact that once an underground coal mine is closed down it is virtually impossible to go back into it. It means that the coal is lost not simply to the company but also to the nation.

I would like to make a few other points about the burden imposed on coal companies which does, as I said, limit their capacity to meet other excise levels such as those contained in this Bill. For example, the New South Wales State Government's decision to nationalise or socialise-whatever else honourable members want to call it; perhaps an appropriate word is thieve-the rights of owners of land who have coal rights attached to that ownership of the land, without compensation, is one of the most incredible bits of socialist activity that this State Government of New South Wales has been guilty of. Of course, it is in the same pattern as taking away the quotas of dairymen in my electorate without offering any compensation-quotas for which in many cases they paid very dearly.

In this case I refer to the rights to coal beneath the surface of people's freehold property which did obtain in some areas and where this title had in many instances been acquired at great expense. For example, many of the coal mines had purchased property in their areas in order to acquire the rights to the coal. I know of one company which is seriously involved. About 40 per cent of its reserves are on freehold land that that company had purchased. Those rights are now to be taken away without compensation by the New South Wales State Government. Another company had about 30 per cent of its coal reserves in freehold land with these particular kinds of rights. These lands have simply been expropriated. I think the people of Australia do not realise that a Labor government, even with a smiling pleasant face and even with a respectable appearance--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the dangerous ones.
—As the Minister says, they are the dangerous ones because that is where we get secret socialism hidden--
—Closet.

—As the honourable member for Werriwa says that is closet socialism. I agree with him and I wish he would come out of the closet. The problem is that even when we have what appears to be a reasonable State Labor government we will find this kind of socialist acquisition of people's property with no compensation. This adds about $1.70 per tonne to the cost of saleable coal for those companies whose rights have been expropriated by the New South Wales Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are other charges that the industry has to face such as the secret tax through rail freights-I have raised this in this House on previous occasions-and industrial disruption. I am intrigued by the comment of the honourable member for Hughes that it would be a disgrace if this Federal Government brought about industrial disruption which was stimulated-I think that is the word he used-in order to achieve some political objective because of the impact this would have on the coal mining industry. If by that he means that it would be disgraceful for the Federal Government to resist excessive wage demands then I am afraid I cannot agree with him.

It seems to me that the honourable member for Hughes recommended that the Federal Government should adopt the same principle that led the State Government in New South Wales into absolute chaos. It always gives way immediately it comes under any kind of wage pressure from its unions. In the electricity power generating area, for example, the New South Wales State Government allegedly came to a deal with the unions which brought the unions increased wages and reduced hours. There was a guarantee from the State Government that there would be no increase in the price of electricity and that there would be industrial peace. Of course, the consequence of that was that we got half the package. We got that part of the package which brought increased wages. We got that part of the package which brought reduced hours to the workers but we did not get that part of the package which got rid of industrial disruption and we did not get that part of the package which guaranteed us no increased costs in electricity because of higher productivity. I guarantee to the honourable member for Hughes that the Federal Government will not adopt those crazy, ratbag policies of the State Labor Government. It gave ground on every occasion in matters of this kind and it has simply led us into more disastrous disruption.

I wish to stress one other massive cost that is hitting the industry. I refer to the cost of financing the enormous stocks of coal at grass because of a mixture of the inadequacy of the coal loader system of New South Wales under the State Government, following its rejection of the private enterprise proposal to have a coal loader at Botany Bay which by now would have been working for many years and, of course, the excessive level of industrial disputation, particularly by workers at those instrumentalities that are run by the State Labor Government of New South Wales. The Maritime Services Board of New South Wales would, without doubt, be the most incompetent employer in Australia and would certainly have one of the worst industrial records. One has only to look at the queue of ships outside Newcastle and Port Kembla to see the mute testimony to the incompetence of the Maritime Services Board in terms of its industrial relations.

Let us examine the cost of keeping the mines open and storing the coal at grass because about 12 million tonnes of New South Wales coal is stockpiled at grass at the moment mainly because it has not been possible to export it. In passing, I add that because of these huge queues of ships the coal proprietors of New South Wales have cancelled the total shipments for the month after next. There is no chance of getting those ships into the ports. The current situation is that the ships being loaded now have been waiting for up to four and a half months. The coal proprietors have a simple choice: Do they get rid of their employees or do they keep producing and put the coal at grass? They have endeavoured to do the right thing-to keep the mines operating and to keep the men at work. That is why they have 12 million tonnes of coal at grass. The average value of that coal is at least $40 a tonne. The total value of this coal which is lying at grass is about $500m. The interest cost of this money that should have been received by the proprietors, the coal mining companies, is about $100m a year. That is how much money is being wasted; effectively, $100m is not being earned. A large amount of interest is being paid by the coal companies because they are having to finance their stocks at grass.

Added to that is the enormous cost of demurrage. It costs $10,000 to $15,000 a day to have those coal ships lying off Newcastle and Port Kembla. In many instances we find that the demurrage paid is worth more than the cargo that the ship eventually takes away. These are costs not only to the coal industry but also to the Australian nation. They are the costs of disruption and the costs of ratbaggery in sections of the union movement. I do not refer to the whole union movement because there are some responsible sections of the union movement. For example, the Transport Workers Union sought quite properly and sensibly along with the coal miners at the South Coast to take over the operations of the old Port Kembla coal loader. I commend those two unions because they know how important it is to keep exporting coal. Honourable members should realise the enormous cost to the people of Australia of this kind of disruption and this kind of anti-coal policy adopted by the New South Wales State Government.

I should like briefly now to deal with the specific problems raised by the Excise Tariff (Coal) Amendment Bill. The amount of money to be raised by this Bill is relatively small. Basically, it is part of a package of measures designed to give effect to the Government's decision to increase the amount of revenue raised to ensure adequate funding of the coal mining industry long service leave fund in the coming financial year. The excise revenue obtained from black coal currently is apportioned on the basis of two-thirds-that is, 10c a tonne-to the coal mining industry long service leave trust fund, and a one- third allocation-that is 5c a tonne-to the coal research account. It is proposed to increase the amount going to the superannuation fund to 20c a tonne. There is also a proposal-negotiations are in fact being conducted to this end with the New South Wales, Tasmanian and Western Australian governments-to withdraw the Commonwealth from involvement in the funding of the long service leave situation as recommended by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The reason for this is very simple. The long service leave fund was set up in 1949 to finance long service leave in the industry on a national basis from this excise duty paid by the producers of black coal. Claims made on the fund by employers for reimbursement of the cost of long service leave granted to their employees made on the fund by employers, of course, offset the excise that was raised by the Commonwealth. The reason for suggesting the termination of Commonwealth involvement in this long service leave trust fund was that basically the industry in effect was paying the money for its workers' superannuation fund. This is obviously a private sector responsibility and it is an accepted condition of employment.

There are precedents in Victoria and South Australia for coal industry administration of long service leave arrangements. There is no doubt that in many people's eyes improvements in labour conditions since the Act was introduced in 1949 have made the continued involvement of the Commonwealth unnecessary. For example, in 1976 the Bland Commonwealth Administrative Review Committee considered that the Commonwealth could withdraw. The task group on Government regulation of industry was of the opinion that there should be a review of the appropriateness of continued Commonwealth involvement. The Lynch Committee took the view that it should be withdrawn.

They are all sensible arguments for the Government getting out of this area which is properly that of private enterprise. However, I make one comment of a cautionary nature: As the payment is presently arranged on a tonnage basis the more efficient open cut mines, which produce more coal per employee than the more expensive underground mines, are in effect subsidising many of the underground mines in New South Wales, particularly in my electorate. In other words, many Queensland open cut coal mines are subsidising New South Wales underground coal mines. I regret to say that I find that an attractive proposition, representing as I do an area that has underground coal mines. I think also that it does have some significance-I concede it is only marginal-in ensuring that we do not simply allow our easily won coal to be mined to the major disadvantage of our coal which is more expensive to mine. So one little disadvantage can emerge from this proposal which is now being discussed with the State government's.

I conclude by saying that I think the Opposition and the nation must recognise that the coal industry's growth prospects for the next few years have deteriorated seriously as a result of the international economic recession and the resultant continuing oil glut. The coal industry cannot afford to be belted around the ears by governments, particularly State governments but also Federal governments. I think it important that State and Federal governments combine to get their houses in order so that they do not keep competing for the coal industry's funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before us, the Excise Tariff (Coal) Amendment Bill and the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, determine that the amount paid into the coal research account will remain at 5c, but that the amount paid into the long service leave fund will double from 10c to 20c to ensure adequate funding for the remainder of the 1981-82 financial year and for the 1982-83 financial year. Having defined the legislation before us, I now direct my remarks to the vacuousness of the arguments that have come forward from Government speakers. We hear them month after month, year after year. I refer to the arguments of the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie), the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), who has just resumed his seat.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government must recognise that the coal industry is a major industry in this country. It is a major source of international revenue. Yet, speech after speech, week after week, from the Government side we hear-and I can describe it in no other words-claptrap, point scoring, whinging, 'blame the State governments', 'blame the trade unions', 'blame the delays in the transport services', 'the transport charges are too high'. But most of the unions involved in the movement of coal through the ports of this country are Federal unions. The trade they are involved in is an international trade, a national responsibility. Nevertheless, after 30 years of conservative government the only solution Government members can come up with is to point score. Therein lies the tragedy of this Government. It does not have any positive attitudes. It does not have any solutions. It does not have any proposals to help this industry-it is a major industry-which is facing severe competition on the world scene.

One would expect that if the honourable members to whom I referred and if the Ministers who are responsible for the coal trade-the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony)-had any sense of responsibility for their portfolios, they would be taking action. I defy any member of the Government to show me one constructive proposal that has come forward from any Fraser Administration to assist or improve the coal trade or to expedite the movement of coal through our ports. Not one proposal has come from the Fraser Government. That is because it is bereft of ideas. Its members are more concerned about fighting amongst themselves on the matters of who might be the Prime Minister, who might be a Minister and who will get kicked out.

Let us get back to considering this very important industry and the remarks of the honourable member for Macarthur. The honourable member for Macarthur is still harping about the Botany Bay coal loader. It might be news to him that the New South Wales Liberal-Country Party Government did absolutely nothing for the coal industry of New South Wales in its 10 or 11 years in office. Last week the honourable member said that it was essential to keep the existing coal loader open to trucks. Yet the truckers and the coal committee from his own electorate have said that after months of talks they have agreed that truck transport should be only to the top of the Illawarra escarpment.

The honourable member for Macarthur ignores the fact that it is the Wran Government that is spending hundreds of millions of dollars on coal loading facilities, on upgrading rail lines, on the purchase of locomotives-150 new locomotives at $1m each. That is the expenditure for one item alone. The Wran Government is spending that money to facilitate the trade, to improve the throughput of coal at our ports. But what do we get from this Government? We get point-scoring, name-calling, rat-baggery and a total absence of any positive proposal or suggestion to improve our standing in the international market-place for coal. The honourable member talks gloom, he acts in gloom, he lives in gloom and he spreads gloom around his electorate. He was not prepared to come into this House and play a positive role by defending the lack of action from his Government and Ministry. He preferred instead to spend 18 of his 20 minutes caning the Labor governments and the Australian Labor Party and two minutes on the substance of the Bill. So much for the honourable member for Macarthur. So much for the policies of this Government-it does not have any policies.

I return to the tragedy the coal industry is facing. The coal industry, the movement of coal, the competitiveness of coal, are complex issues. The honourable member for Paterson comes from my region, the Hunter region. He also has yet to make one positive suggestion to improve the situation. In that region most of the unions involved in the movement of coal to the port, through the port onto the ships and away, are Federal unions. The number of unions increases the potential for friction. On the other hand, the number of bodies involved in the production, marketing, sale, chartering of vessels and loading further complicate the picture. There is no on-going mechanism anywhere in Australia, at any of the coal ports, that is designed to bring together all of these parties, to create an awareness within each of these parties of the complex nature of the industry, of the ramifications of delays or disruptions to shipping schedules.

On the other hand, from those who are involved in the industry there is no acknowledgement of what these things mean to people working in the industry or the risks they take working under the ground. It is a job I would not take on for any money. Because of the risks those people take, they think they are entitled to certain rewards. When people are working underground in a dangerous industry such as the coal industry, in which the death rate has increased with mechanisation and the removal of pillars, and when the owners, the corporations that control those mines, in earlier years revealed massive profits, is it not reasonable to expect the people in this industry to say 'We participate in production, aren't we entitled to a fairer share'?

All of those problems could be brought together if there were a co-ordinating mechanism. It should be originating with the Federal Government, through the Ministers who are responsible for international trade, foreign affairs and international transport, but there is a vacuum. The best they can produce is the throw-away line of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) a few weeks ago in the Lowe by-election when he referred in a rather arrogant and demeaning way to the ships waiting off Newcastle as Wran's navy. Even then he exposed his almost total lack of knowledge of this subject as he could not even get the number of ships right. The best he could do was say that there were 57 ships off the port. There have never been more than 45 vessels waiting off Newcastle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 45 ships! Good heavens, how extraordinary! There is really no problem!

—That is the kind of contribution that we get from those who sit opposite. That kind of vacuous, innane comment comes from the responsible Ministers who ought to be taking a positive stance. They are point scoring. It is petty, party political point scoring. The taxpayers just brought the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs back from four weeks abroad. He spent three days at a conference on youth affairs but it took him four weeks to get there and back. Heaven knows how much it cost the taxpayers. That is the kind of comment that we get from the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: A whole range of reasons lead to delays in shipping. Firstly, given a normal situation without any disruption of supply of product to the port, given a normal situation in which everything is running smoothly and there is no disruption or delay on the part of the producers or shippers or in the arrivals of vessels, there will be a minimum of 15 vessels off Newcastle for the foreseeable future. That comes about through the nature of the global shipping industry and the positioning of vessels. Vessels take their place under the coal loaders in order of their arrival off the port. So let us try first to understand what the industry is about and how it functions. Then let us try for once as a nation, despite the obstruction of honourable members opposite, to find a solution. To have 15 vessels waiting off the port is normal; to have over 15 is abnormal and disrupts shipment schedules, causing difficulties for the purchasers at the other end, that is, at the receiving ports.

In view of the number of unions and parties involved, how do we find a way of minimising disruptions and delays? I have taken up with the Prime Minister this matter of the delays of vessels. In July last year I wrote to the Prime Minister about the unique position off Newcastle, Port Kembla and Port Hedland. Most of the vessels there are in international waters and there is no way we can control their movements. I asked him to take up the whole subject with the governments of the countries of origin of those vessels. The answer that came back from the Prime Minister was to refer it to the Minister for Transport. The answer that came back from the Minister for Transport was that he saw it as a waste of resources to spend time on such an issue. So nothing came from that.

The only approach that we have put forward in the absence of any other initiative from the government has been the creation of port co-ordination committees. Those committees could have representatives of the coal producers, the shippers, the relevant unions involved, the port authorities, local government authority and, in the case of Newcastle, the fishing industry because that industry has been disrupted by refuse from the vessels, by the number of vessels and by ships swinging on their anchor chains because of weather changes. That is not, I suggest, an optimal solution but it is a proposal that is put forward in the absence of anything from government. It is a proposal put forward because the Federal Government ought to be involved. I understand that the Minister for Transport is prepared to participate-nobody else on the Government side has said anything-as are the State Government, the Port of Newcastle, the Maritime Services Board and each of the unions involved. We should try to get a better understanding, as I mentioned earlier, of the factors involved so that we can minimise the disruptions. There will always be some kinds of industrial disruptions but if there is an understanding of the impact of those disruptions we will have a chance of minimising them.

On an issue like this we could head in the direction of fostering industry unions to reduce the number of unions involved. There is a willingness on the part of the unions concerned to do that. I believe that also will help to solve the problem and reduce interruptions and delays. But let me come back to this point because there are two factors involved. One is that delays for vessels outside ports are not unique to Newcastle or Port Kembla. Also at Newcastle particularly there are special human problems involved with the crews of the vessels, which again is a matter on which this Government has refused to act. I have written to the Government asking for a streamlining of the quarantine procedures, but there has been no action; only talk. In the meantime, there has been point scoring.

I invite honourable members to look at the position in ports around the world, particularly in the Indian Ocean, such as Calcutta, Madras, Durban, Colombo, Rangoon and Chittagong. All those ports, which are within Australia's breadth, have considerable delays in ships waiting to get in to the facilities. I can give a better example. I refer to the leading coal port in the United States, Hampton Roads on the east coast. On a fine day when the sun is warm and the breeze is light one is likely to find 100 vessels there. On odd occasions one can find 150. That is due to similiar problems-the positioning of vessels, vessels looking for spot cargoes and the incapacities of coal loading facilities . I have heard honourable members opposite say that we are wrecking the coal market by having these delays. We on this side of the House want to minimise delays. But we want positive action, co-operation and leadership from the Federal Government, whose prime responsibility it is. Let me quote from the American magazine Fortune of 14 December last a report of a statement attributed to Mary Ann Heider, Manager of the bulk department of Anders Williams and Company in the Port of Hampton Roads. She recalls the reaction of a group of visiting foreign customers during the worst delays. The report states:
'They did some heavy threatening,' she remembers. 'They screamed and screamed and screamed.' Their message: 'We've either got to come to some arrangement or we'll go elsewhere.'

I have heard those words over and over again from the incompetents opposite, from those who prefer to point score rather than to put forward positive proposals for this problem. All we have is a Federal Government without responsibility, without leadership, without any sense of direction on this very important trade matter. We have an industry that is complex, that is fragmented, and that competes abroad fragmented. Its members sell as individuals or small groups to one customer or to buyers operating as a unit. In the words of the late Rex Connor, there are occasions on which one can only draw the conclusion that some of our coal traders abroad behave like hillbillies in the market in which they are dealing with their customers.

Let me conclude on this note: The ball is in the Government's court. We do not want point scoring. We want an improvement to the coal trade. If, as the honourable member for Macarthur suggests, the coal companies should be subsidised, the cost of transporting coal to the ports should be reduced, let this Government provide the subsidies as it is doing with the airlines. If he expects the public of Australia to pay for health care under the good old user- pays principle, I think it is reasonable to expect profit-making major corporations also to be treated on the user-pays principle. I conclude on this important issue by saying let us for once have some positive leadership from the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak for a minute or so to reply to some of the things that were said by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris).
—No, fair go.

—I am being told by my Whip to sit down but I was very concerned to hear some of the statements that were made by the honourable member for Shortland insofar as the Newcastle coal industry is concerned. The allegations he made about the Federal Government are not correct. We have a wonderful opportunity within Australia to produce more coal for an expanding industry in different parts of the world, particularly our steaming coal. I am very concerned about what the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) said because, in the Gloucester area within my electorate, there is potential for tremendous development of steaming coal. It is essential that that coal be allowed to go out of the ports.

SPEECH.PARA: What the honourable member for Shortland has said about the ships off the ports is that it is the fault of the Commonwealth. Many of the unions concerned are in the hands of the State. The people of Newcastle and of the Hunter Valley see that their area is being severely disadvantaged because of the actions of unions in the area. I go so far as to say that, in the electorate of the honourable member for Shortland and in the southern end of my electorate and in other electorates within the Newcastle area, there is grave concern about the militant action, unnecessary action and unfair action that is being adopted by the unions that the honourable member and his party represent in this House. I do not want to see the Commonwealth blamed for this. All that we want to see is a little common sense on the part of the unions in relation to the winning and the transportation of our coal, and the letting of our ships into the harbour and the letting out of those ships in a reasonable time. We know that some of the ships have to queue up. That is so. But there is unnecessary queuing up. I fly across the harbour twice a week. There are 30, 40 or 50 boats there.

The companies which own the boats and the exporters to whom we are selling are getting very concerned about this problem. If honourable members want to know anything more about the matter, they should ask the Mitsubishi organisation and other companies that are buying our coal. Those companies will find substitutes if we are not in a position to supply the natural resources, the goods. We do not want that to happen. If it happens, the honourable member for Shortland, who protects the unions by statements in his local newspaper and in this Parliament, will be the guilty man. He and others with whom he abides support the unions in the Hunter Valley area whose actions are killing the district which is an area with wonderful opportunities. It will never achieve them whilst it has a representative who says the type of things that he says here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. I seek to make a personal explanation.
—I will hear the honourable member for Shortland who claims to be misrepresented.

—The outrageous remark just made by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) is untrue. The only positive action being taken in the Newcastle area on this important problem has been taken by me. I wish that the honourable member would join me.
