DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Mr Viner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will amend the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act to accomplish six different objectives. Clauses 4, 5 and 6 provide amendments to allow five land trusts to be set up to hold separate titles to land within the Hermannsburg lease, also to reduce the numbers of members required on a lands trust and to remove the necessity of having a chairman of a lands trust. Clauses 8 to 11 will enable Cliff Island to be included within the Tiwi Lands Trust area and the consolidation of titles of Bathurst and Melville Islands under the Tiwi Trust. I understand that the Minister will be given discretion by clause 9 to transfer funds from Aboriginal benefit trust accounts to Consolidated Revenue to repay previous advances to land councils for administrative expenses because of a shortfall of royalties. Clause 10 simply provides for the payment of legal costs in closures of seas hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 is included, I understand, ostensibly to remove doubts about the ability of the Minister progressively to grant land recommended to an Aboriginal land trust and also allow the Minister to establish a different number of land trusts than that recommended by the Aboriginal Land Commission.

The Opposition does not oppose the Bill. We certainly do not wish to oppose the granting of leases to the Aboriginal people, particularly to the people at Hermannsburg. However, although we are not opposing the Bill, we have some reservations regarding the true reason for the Government and the Minister including clause 7, that is, as I have just said, the clause which will allow the Minister to grant lands recommended by the Commissioner on a progressive or step-by-step basis. The Minister says that he must have this power to allow an early transfer of title to the relevant land trust without waiting for a High Court decision regarding eight small parcels of land which are currently subject to a challenge by Peko-Wallsend Ltd in the High Court.
To establish my doubts about the purpose of this provision, I quote briefly on this aspect from the speech in the Senate of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). He said:
The purpose of clause 7 will be to allow me to grant any land in stages. That could apply to the Alligator Rivers region as it could to any other region.
Then Senator Peter Baume said:

within the Alligator Rivers area there are eight small parcels of land in the area recommended for grant by the Lands Commissioner, each of which is held up at the moment because of concerns that we have over the Finniss River Appeal which is before the High Court of Australia. The matters being appealed in the Finniss River case are matters which are relevant to these eight small pieces of land.
Then the Minister added:

Those eight pieces contain land which may be of great importance to traditional Aboriginal owners because they include areas which are controlled by Peko- Wallsend Ltd which may contain mineral wealth and which Aboriginals want to become Aboriginal land in due course so that negotiations could take place in the usual way for mining to proceed on them. If the Senate or the Parliament chose not to pass this amendment, the only losers could be the traditional Aboriginal people; the only winners could be the people who hold the pieces of land-
That is, Peko-Wallsend.

In effect, there the Minister is saying that, if this amendment is not passed to allow the land grants to be made on a step by step basis, the Aboriginal title to those eight small parcels of land would be at risk. If he grants the major portion, including Jabiluka, there is a barrier, he says, to eventually granting these eight areas at later date. But the important thing is that he is inferring, in his second reading speech and the Committee stage in the other place, that only two grants will be made, one large grant and one small grant. But I understand that there is now a strong probability, due to the Government's desire to push uranium mining at Jabiluka-that is the huge Pancontinental Mining Ltd mine in the heart of the sensitive wetlands area-that the small uranium mining area may be granted to the Aboriginal people first, to allow mining to proceed, with the rest of their land to be transferred much later. That is because, I understand, there is some difficulty about surveying the land, on the ground, from Commissioner Toohey's map. It will be easy to survey Jabiluka quickly but it will take a much longer time to survey the whole of the area that Commissioner Toohey recommended be passed on to the Aboriginal land trusts.

I ask honourable members to examine the process by which Aboriginal land is granted to traditional owners and is held in trust by Aboriginal land trusts; to examine how land councils are set up to negotiate for traditional owners and how land trusts are supposed to lease land granted to them to the National Parks and Wildlife Service for national parks and conservation areas; and, finally, to examine how traditional Aboriginal owners have a right to veto over uranium mining, or indeed any mining, if they wish to exercise a veto. The Commissioner recommends to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and area of land claim that should be granted to the traditional Aboriginal owners. This is covered by section 11 (1) (A) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. If the Minister agrees he then establishes a land trust and recommends a grant of land, or part of the land claimed, to an Aboriginal land trust set up under the relevant section of the Act. That Aboriginal land trust is then obligated under the relevant sections of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and the Australian National Parks and Wild Life Conservation Act to grant a lease of Aboriginal land, or any part of the land, as the Director of Parks and Wildlife specifies for declaration as a national park or conservation area. This is the way that stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park was handled.

So clearly if this matter was not complicated by this Government's manic desire to expedite uranium mining-in this case at Jabiluka-the procedure would be thus: The Minister grants the latest recommendation from Commissioner Toohey to the traditional owners through an Aboriginal land trust and then leases the land to the National Parks and Wildlife Service for stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. No doubt at that point the Government would instruct the Director to excise the Jabiluka area from the park, as it has already excised Koongarra and Ranger, to allow uranium mining to proceed. But now we are giving power to the Minister to grant Commissioner Toohey's recommendations via not one but any number of grants . That is fine if the Government's only motive is to grant one large parcel of land followed later by the eight parcels in question which are under the jurisdiction of the High Court. But it is not as simple as that.

I put it to the House that the Government has some secondary and more devious motives in mind. Two highly contentious actions could occur because, as I have said, the surveying of all this land in question is not completed. The surveying of the Jabiluka enclave could be completed well in advance of the survey of the total area. The Minister is now considering-he did not say anything about this in the Senate-first granting only the Jabiluka area to the Aboriginal land trust that will be set up to make it possible for an early start to mining at Jabiluka . Of course that will be after an agreement is pushed through with Pancontinental by the Northern Land Council and if it is agreed to by the traditional owners. The Minister could then follow later with the rest of the grant when the surveys are finished and, later on again, perhaps buy the eight small parcels of land involved in the Peko-Wallsend High Court case.

It is further likely, though, that even now Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park will not be declared because the National Parks and Wildlife Service seems to have been pushed completely from the picture. I understand that Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park will be declared at some later date after all the land has been surveyed and handed over to the Aboriginal land trusts. At a still later date, the rest of the original area for Stage 2 of this beautiful proposed national park will be declared a conservation zone only, to allow minerals exploration at the behest of the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government.

Is it not entirely fortuitous for the Government that via this seemingly innocuous piece of legislation it says it can expedite the title transfer to the Aboriginals without waiting for a High Court decision on eight small parcels of land. At the same time it is very fortuitous for them that this Bill will allow an early start on the Jabiluka uranium mining project by cynically surveying that tiny piece of land first and then giving it to the trust to allow the Northern Land Council to negotiate the deal with Pancontinental and the Getty oil company. That explains the conditional approval last week by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) for the Jabiluka partners to seek sales contracts.

This also will deliberately extend three great pressures on the traditional owners. The first pressure comes from the ministerial announcement to which I have just referred, the second from the inference that if the traditional owners do not agree to the agreement worked out by the Northern Land Council there might be some delay in the transfer of the title for the majority of their land, and the third and final pressure is that the Northern Land Council has already, on 27 February last, initialled an agreement with the uranium mining partners. What pressure is being placed upon these traditional Aboriginal owners by those three actions?

We in the Federal Australian Labor Party will not oppose the Bill because our motives could surely be misconstrued as being obstructive of Aboriginal land rights. Of course we are the instigators of Aboriginal land rights and we would never be obstructive of those land rights. We wish to see the Aboriginals get their land. We have a strong and enduring commitment to land rights but we are awake to the Minister's real motives and reasons for pushing this Bill through the Senate-in one day last week and now lifting it up the order of business today and whacking it through this afternoon as quickly as possible. This action is not to see that the Aboriginals get their land-they have waited 200 years for that-but to see that Pancontinental gets approval to go ahead with the Jabiluka mining lease as soon as possible. Make no mistake, this Bill is designed to expedite the Jabiluka project, the largest of all the uranium mines, just as much as it is designed to transfer title of Aboriginal land. If the Minister gets title to Jabiluka only he is exacerbating the heavy pressure that the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources has already placed upon these traditional bush people. I quote what the Minister for Trade and Resources said last week after a rushed trip to Darwin. He said:

I have today given conditional approval under the Government's uranium export policy for the development of the Jabiluka uranium deposits in the Northern Territory. This means that I will be able to authorise the project partners to enter the market place to commence negotiations for the sale of product from Jabiluka.

He then went on to say that that was conditional on agreement by the traditional owners, but he knew full well that his signing of this initial agreement to allow them to go ahead and seek conditional contracts would put pressure on these people to go along with it. There is a panic element in the whole Jabiluka exercise, anyway. That is the point. Now we come to the bitter heart of it. I quote the Northern Territory Minister for Mines, Mr Tuxworth. Some little time ago, when questioned about the viability of the uranium mining industry in the Territory, he said:
Our view is that if we haven't sold our uranium by contract by 1985, we won't be selling any more 'till the year 2000, or of that order.
Our assessment is that if these two (Pancontinental and Denison)-
The Jabiluka and Koongarra crowd-
haven't sold their cake-
I like his use of the term 'cake'-
and are off and running by 1985, they aren't going to go.
When asked by the interviewer from the Australian Financial Review whether, in view of the falling uranium market, it would not be wiser to hold off development, Mr Tuxworth said:
Do you want half of something or all of nothing? I'll take half of something every time.

This is why this Bill is being rushed through: Jabiluka needs to be quickly handed over to the Aboriginal land trusts so they can be pressured by this Government, by the Northern Territory Government, by Pancontinental, and by the Northern Land Council too, into signing an agreement to proceed at Jabiluka. This mine should not proceed at all. Leaving aside the Aboriginal land rights argument, it is not a goer. It will compound over production of Australian uranium as world demand is declining.
Last week our great Minister for Trade and Resources and Deputy Prime Minister said:
Jabiluka-

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—It is a pity he did not understand the exigencies of the world uranium market a little better. If he did he might be saving some of his investors a little money. Australia seems to be the only country in the world taking a bullish attitude to uranium mining. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Jabiluka is a world ranking deposit with total estimated reserves in excess of 200,000 tonnes of uranium oxide.

He went on to say that the Government expected to sell at least 4,500 tonnes of uranium a year and hoped to employ 540 people. He said that the Government hoped the $600m development would eventually sell 9,000 tonnes of uranium a year and employ a few more people. The truth is that it is extremely irresponsible of this Minister and this Government to be pushing this industry at a time of downturn and world oversupply.

The Government's own Australian Atomic Energy Commission which could scarcely be accused of not being a promoter of nuclear power and the uranium industry said in its last report that the forecasts of the Western world annual requirements for uranium by it since 1975 had consistently fallen. It was saying in 1975 that the Western world demand would be 108,000 tonnes by 1985 but this year the figure is down to 39,000 tonnes. The story is similar with regard to enriched uranium. When using the measurement unit involved in the description of enriched uranium, the figures were: Australian Atomic Energy Commission production in 1975, 52 million separate work units; this year, down to 25 million separate work units. That is the state of the industry. Some of the mines this Minister and the Government are pushing are in the Northern Territory -in the beautiful Kakadu National Park that has been included in the World Heritage list and in the National Estate list. It is one of the most sensitive areas in Australia. It is on a par with south-west Tasmania and the Great Barrier Reef. The Government wants to put these mines-create enclaves-in the middle of this area.

If all of the proposed mines-Ranger, Jabiluka, Nabarlek, Yeelirrie in Western Australia and Koongarra plus Roxby Downs-go ahead we would be producing 15,000 tonnes of uranium a year. Yet the AAEC says that world demand will be less than 40,000 tonnes by 1985, and thus we will be lucky to be able to obtain 20 per cent of that market-that is, 8,000 tonnes. Where is the Government going to sell the rest of it? How hard are we going to push in the declining market situation? I can only say that in this situation there will be more hawking of uranium around the world. In a situation where the price falls, where in the scramble to sell, the much publicised safeguards are watered down. This is happening now. Witness this Government's somersault to allow reprocessing to proceed in which plutonium is produced from Australian uranium from used fuel rods in conventional reactors. Plutonium is the fissionable material from which nuclear weapons are made. They say they can control this under the safeguards agreements , under an inefficient International Atomic Energy Agency procedure. That is simply wrong. It is nonsense. The Government is completely misleading Australia in professing confidence in safeguards arrangements. This Government will do anything. It has proven that. It will break down its safeguards to sell uranium in a declining market situation, in a world downturn situation, even at the risk of plutonium from Australian uranium being used to manufacture nuclear weapons.

I return to the role of the Northern Land Council in this whole affair of Jabiluka and the transfer of title. It is most unfortunate the Council has already initialled contracts with Pan-continental Mining Ltd. I understand that, however, the traditional owners are unhappy and confused. They do not know what the NLC is up to. They do not know what they are going to get. Many, as always, are again opposed to uranium mining. My colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) will develop this theme further. But perhaps the Northern Land Council can explain to me its rush to agreement with Pancontinental. There are now some fundamental concerns about the structure and, indeed, the whole model of the Northern Land Council-not concern at giving land to Aboriginal traditional owners but at the administration and negotiation of mining approvals that should now be the concern of this Parliament. For instance , is the Northern Land Council's haste to rush to agreement to develop Jabiluka due to a desire to finance its own growing bureaucracy which is now dominated not by blacks but by white lawyers and barristers-a bevy of legal representatives with a staff now of over 70 people? Are both the land councils and the Aboriginal owners becoming too dependent on mining funds? Is the Northern Land Council developing a vested interest in mining against the interests and desires of the traditional owners? Have some of the legal advisers openly expressed a pro-mining view during the conduct of the negotiations? If so , have they put a no mining option to the traditional owners when explaining the options of the agreement as they are obliged to under section 48 of the Act? Finally, is the Land Council and traditional owner model, now showing signs of inbuilt basic conflict between two sets of values?

As an illustration of this, I refer to a speech I made last June when debating an earlier set of amendments which were partly designed to allow uranium mining at Jabiluka to proceed. In that speech I described the country that I saw when I was in the area a couple of years ago. I said:

As we drove along the road into Jabiluka, a representative of Pancontinental said to me: 'This road over the crossing we are going over, this low lying area next to the mining area, is eight feet under water during the wet season'. That indicates the climate and rainfall in that area. The mining companies say that they will contain the radio active water within a closed system. In the dry season this wetlands area is a maze of creeks and billabongs. In the wet season it becomes an area of fast flowing waterways feeding the south and east Alligator Rivers system. The threat of radio active leakage into the park region will always be present althought things have improved since the 1979 environmental impact statement was submitted proposing open cut mining.

Honourable members can imagine my amazement -this was when the Bill was debated in the Senate- when a Mr Eric Pratt, Q.C., senior counsel for the Northern Land Council, had the audacity to send a telex without, I understand, the approval of the Northern Land Council to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), in which he criticised my statement as being either misconceived or dishonest. Mr Pratt said in his telex:
Have seen Press statement issued by Stuart West.
The Minister stated:
I take it he means the honourable member for Cunningham.
Mr Pratt went on to say:

The mining is justified environmentally and economically and will result in substantial economic benefits to Aboriginals. Environmental requirements have been established and agreed to by Government, the supervising authorities and the Northern Land Council, so as to ensure protection of the environment.

Here is the situation: A senior counsel of the NLC 9 months ago, before and/or during negotiations with Pancontinental, comes out in a predetermined way and says he has made up his mind, and without the approval of the NLC, sends a telex to the Minister to use during a debate in this Parliament. Did the NLC instruct its Q.C. to send a telex like that on a Pancontinental telex machine after he had lunched with Pancontinental officials? If he did that, who in fact is running the Northern Land Council in these negotiations-white barristers and solicitors or blacks on behalf of the Aboriginal traditional owners? Who is running it-the Aboriginals themselves or the hired silks who have suddenly taken over the organisations and who are supposed to negotiate on behalf of these simple traditional owners?

Another question I want to raise before I finish is: What is in this initialled agreement for the Aboriginals? To what extent are they becoming dependent on mining, perhaps against their own basic interests, and certainly against the interests of proper socio-economic programs developed under the Government but in cohesion with them in the Territory? Funding of the Land Councils from uranium mining companies is on this basis. Royalties of 4.25 per cent are paid to the Aboriginals. Of this amount, 24 per cent goes to the NLC, 14 per cent to the Central Land Council, 2 per cent to the Tiwi Council, 30 per cent to the Northern Territory Aboriginals and 30 per cent to the traditional owners. In December 1981, the first payment of $1.5m was made and $144,000 of that went to the NLC, plus an up front payment to the community. So far, so good.

What is the situation with the initialled Jabiluka agreement? I understand that the Northern Land Council is to get $200,000 a year for the first four years, then gets its share of the royalties thereafter. I have heard that the up front payment will be anything from $1m to $10m, but the NLC will receive only a small amount of that; the rest will go into the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account. That is not enough money for the Aboriginals if they are to go ahead. I am not saying that they are getting too much. I am saying that the organisation and the model that has been set up are now showing distinct signs of being used not for the benefits of the Aboriginal traditional owners but in the interests of a prevailing, and snowballing bureaucracy in the land councils which are taking the decisions and not properly informing the people, on the grounds probably that the people are not, because of their traditional life style, capable of understanding these highly complicated agreements anyway. I only hope that the Aboriginals use the power that they have under section 40 of the Act; that is, the power of veto over what the Land Council is doing. Let us remember that the Land Council initialled an agreement some time ago. Under section 48 the Minister can at least ensure that they are properly informed of what is going on and that they do not sell their birthright for a Toyota 4-wheel drive.

I conclude by returning to the role of the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the declaration of Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park, which is being completely ignored in this whole affair. Stage 1 of Kakadu National Park is on the National Estate. In October last year it was accepted by the World Heritage List Committee in Sydney for inclusion in the World Heritage List. The National Parks and Wildlife Service, in its submission to the committee of the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation, said that the natural heritage of Kakadu National Park is of outstanding universal value, and gave 13 major justifications which cover preservation of Aboriginal cultural, physical and biological assistance of the whole park ecosystem. Now, besides not being satisfied with mining at Koongara in an enclave within Stage 1 and mining at Ranger on the parameter, Jabiluka will be established as an eventual enclave within Stage 2, if it is ever declared.

Why is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) pushed aside in these matters? When will Stage 2 be declared? Without the protection of being included in the park, the Aboriginal land will be subject to the massive effects of uranium mining at Ranger and Jabiluka. No Commonwealth environmental protection legislation will apply to this area before it is declared as a park. Separate transfer of Jabiluka will prove that this Government's priorities lie with the uranium companies and not with the Aboriginals or with the interests of the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Finally, I am informed that the National Parks and Wildlife Service has not been consulted on the implications of this amendment and two senior officers have voiced their disapproval. That Service, under the administration of this Government, has been left completely in the dark on this matter. We support Aboriginal land rights. We support the declaration of all of the Kakadu area as a great national park that Australia can be proud of. I believe that we must seriously question the structure under which Aboriginal land rights are administered once granted. We do not support uranium mining and we put those companies on notice that they will not receive our support when we are in government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tambling) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 February, on message from the Senate:
The Senate transmits to the House of Representatives the following Resolution which was agreed to by the Senate on 26 November 1981:

That the Senate, having considered the Report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing- (a) endorses the conclusions of the Committee as summarised on pages (viii) and (ix) of its Report and the recommendations contained in the Report;

and in relation to the recommendations of the Committee in Chapter 6 of the Report- (b) resolves that the Senate should establish a Standing Committee as recommended to consider the Senate's appropriations and staffing;
(c) proposes that the Estimates for the Senate as finally agreed to by such Standing Committee be submitted to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate Parliamentary Appropriation Bill;

(d) calls on the Government to agree that the appropriations for the Parliament be removed from the Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government and included in a separate Parliamentary Appropriation Bill;

(e) agrees that the expenditure administered by the Executive departments on behalf of the Parliament be brought together in a Parliamentary Appropriation Bill and that provision be made for an advance to the President of the Senate on the same basis as the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

(f) directs that the President arrange for discussions to be held with the appropriate Executive departments to review those functions which are currently administered by them, and subsequently to plan the transfer of functions suitable for administration by the Senate: and

(g) agrees that section 9 of the Public Service Act 1922 be amended to vest in the Presiding Officers, separately or jointly as the case may be, the power of appointment, promotion, creation, abolition and reclassification of offices, and the determination of rates of pay and conditions of service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the message.

This statement arises from the Government's consideration of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, which was tabled on 19 August 1981. While the recommendations in the report essentially deal with the Senate, the Government's response covers, and is therefore being made in, both Houses of the Parliament. I note in passing that the current procedures for considering the parliamentary estimates were to be reviewed in any event for the 1982-83 Budget. The Government acknowledges the valuable work of the Committee. In developing its response it has had the benefit of the Committee's further views and has discussed the matters raised by the Committee with the Presiding Officers.

The terms of reference of the Senate Select Committee were to inquire into and report upon Parliament's control of its own appropriations and staffing, and related matters. The central theme in the report is that Parliament should have greater independence and autonomy in regard to its internal arrangements and operations. Control of parliament's appropriations and staffing is seen by the Committee as essential to achieving this independence. The Government, of course , agrees that the independence of parliament as such from Executive control is a central principle of our Constitution which must be upheld. But just as the Parliament must exercise its rights and meet its responsibilities, so must the Government be able to fulfil its constitutional obligations; in this case the control of the expenditure of public money.

In responding to the report, the Government has had to devise a balance between these fundamental principles bearing in mind the provisions of the Australian Constitution and the development of parliamentary government in Australia. I believe that the detailed measures I will outline a little later meet this challenge. This balance assumes there will be a continuing dialogue between the Parliament and the Executive, and it remains the Government's firm intention that such dialogue is effective, and recognises the proper roles and responsibilities of each party. The fact that this response has taken the time it has flows in part from our commitment to such discussions at all stages.

I now turn to the Government's response to the specific major recommendations of the Jessop Committee. The report contains recommendations on five main topics : Parliament's control of its own funding; a separate parliamenary appropriation Bill; transfer of items in appropriations of Government departments to the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill and parliamentary administration; control over staffing and terms and conditions of employment; and a parliamentary appropriations and staffing committee.

On the first and key issue the Government believes firmly that it needs to maintain control over the total amount of funds available for expenditure by the Parliament because of the constitutional responsbility of the Government for budgetary policy and for the level of public expenditure. Obviously, the funds that are spent on the Parliament are funds that come from the Australian taxpayer in exactly the same way as funds that are spent in any of the other recurring circumstances that are provided by government, although, as will be seen shortly, the parliamentary appropriation Bill will, for the first time, remove parliamentary appropriations from those recurrent services of Government. Moreover, it is the Government which has the odium of raising the revenue which funds that expenditure. However the Goverment recognises that detailed control over individual expenditure items is not necessary. The Government therefore proposes that it simply approve overall figures, broken down into a capital and a recurrent item, for each of the Senate, the House of Representatives and, as a group, the three joint departments. This arrangement properly balances the overall Government responsibility for the level of public expenditure with the responsibility of the parliamentary departments and the Presiding Officers to determine, subject to parliamentary approval, the direction of that expenditure.

The Government also proposes that, commencing with the financial year 1982-83, there be a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill which, consistent with the Select Committee recommendations, will not be treated as a Bill for the ordinary annual services of government, and will cover all recurrent and capital expenditure items currently administered by the parliamentary departments. I should also say that the arrangements for consultations between you, Mr Speaker, Mr President, my colleague the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) and myself, as well as consultations at officer level, during the Budget process will of course be maintained.

Within the total figure for parliamentary departments, the Government is also suggesting an Advance to the Presiding Officers as recommended by the Select Committee, provided that such an advance is operated in the same way as is the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The Government will be proposing an amendment to the Audit Act in due course to facilitate the use of this Advance. On the question of the transfer of certain items from appropriations of Government departments to the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill and parliamentary administration, the Government proposes that the two aspects be considered together and therefore that these items should be the subject of further discussions.

I turn now to the topic of control over staffing. The Government has most carefully considered the need to maintain a measure of control over the total number of public sector employees and of course, the terms and conditions under which they are employed. The Government's policies in this regard are a matter of public record. Suffice it to say that the Government does not wish public sector employees to have any pace-setting role. It expects that due regard therefore be paid to principles of wage restraint. On the basis that the Presiding Officers undertake to consult with the Public Service Board before determining staff ceilings for individual parliamentary departments, and provided that the Presiding Officers publish projected ceilings in advance, with the previous year's actual ceilings, by reporting annually to this Parliament, the Government is willing to give control over staff numbers to the Presiding Officers.

On terms and conditions of employment of parliamentary staff, the Government is also asking Presiding Officers to give an undertaking to consult with the Public Service Board before determining-as they are now empowered to-those terms and conditions, and that such determinations should also be published annually when the Presiding Officers report to the Parliament. The reason for this is to avoid any undesirable 'leap-frogging' in terms and conditions between parliamentary and executive departments. I should make it clear that these consultations would be on the basis that the final powers reside with the Presiding Officers, that they agree to consult, but that there is to be no statutory requirement on them to do so.

The decisions of the Parliament in these areas should be subject to the same types of scrutiny, inside and outside the Parliament, as those of the Government itself. It is up to the Parliament to prove its managerial ability in the same fashion as it is for the Government. It is for this reason that the Government is proposing that the Presiding Officers report annually to the Parliament on the numbers, classification and disposition of staff, as well as any variation in terms and conditions of employment. They should also provide a detailed breakdown of previous and proposed expenditure within each of the items contained in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill. Given these arrangements, a number of further powers will be transferred to the Presiding Officers as recommended by the Senate Committee. The Government will be proposing amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill 1981, now before the Parliament, to vest in the Presiding Officers power to create, classify and abolish offices, and to make appointments below the level of permanent head.

Finally, the Select Committee proposed the establishment of a Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee. The Government considers that it is appropriate for the Senate itself to decide on the mechanisms it wishes to establish to advise the President on his responsibilities and, therefore, proposes to leave this recommendation in the Senate's hands. For this House, the Government will not be proposing, nor would it support, any similar committee

I am confident that the revised arrangements, as I have outlined, will provide the basis for a reasonable balance between the need for the Parliament to have a greater degree of autonomy in relation to funding and staffing and the need for the Government to retain a limited number of overall controls in the execution of its proper responsibilities.

Mr Speaker, I understand that the Opposition wishes to move an amendment with respect to the establishment of a committee. Because under the procedures that we have adopted I would not have an opportunity to respond, I want briefly to expand upon the reasons that I have given.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable gentleman could ask his colleague to move that the House take note of the paper. Then he would have an opportunity to respond.

—Also, Mr Speaker, I could speak to the amendment and cover the subject in that way. I will not address the matter in great detail. It seemed to me that I needed to make two other points. One was with respect to the establishment of a committee. Mr Speaker, under the Westminster system the office that you occupy and the office of your counterpart, the Presiding Officer of the Senate, have always been seen as paramount in the functioning of the Parliament. The Standing Orders largely accord to you responsibility for determination of those areas in respect of which such responsibility is not otherwise specified. It seems a pity to impose on you, as part of your ultimate responsibility to the Parliament, a committee system which will not enhance the function and structure of the decisions that you are called upon to take in exercising your executive responsibility, as distinct from your responsibility as Speaker to administer this chamber. Therefore, the Government does not regard the establishment of a committee as a way in which this place can be better governed.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not believe that a committee is necessary, given that already there is a range of joint and House committees to advise you and the Parliament on the respective functions which are of prime concern to honourable members. Indeed, we believe that within the structure of the present procedures and practices ample opportunity exists for honourable members to contribute to policy formulation by making recommendations on the funding of particular areas of parliamentary responsibility. There is, of course, already a standing Library Committee. The projected amendment makes reference to the Parliamentary Library, but at Question Time on many occasions over the course of the years you and your predecessors have been called to answer specific questions with respect to matters of administration.

Therefore, taking all of these matters into account, the Government does not believe that the establishment of a committee along the lines that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) intends to recommend represents a way by which the Parliament can be better and more efficiently governed than by the Speaker and the President having ultimate responsibility for determining funding , staffing and other matters towards which this statement is directed.

The second matter concerns the staffing of committees, as well as other staff demands within the responsibilities to be transferred henceforth to yourself and to Mr President. Quite obviously, the constraints that will be imposed under the Parliamentary Appropriations Bill will be constraints which, for the first time, will relate to the actual amount of money that is to be allocated for expenditure in the operation of the Parliament. That will mean that decisions will need to be taken in relation to the best utilisation of those funds, for recurrent and capital purposes, in the three categories to which reference has been made in the statement.

I hope it will not be a matter of one House setting terms and conditions of employment which would lead to an escalation in the pay expectations of individual officers in the other. In other words, one would hope that, in the very natural desire to meet the expectations of those who will serve the various committees in this and the other place, there will not be a tendency on the part of those who make recommendations on one side or the other of the Parliament to set in train a leap-frogging process which will erode the real benefits which I have no doubt that you, in your discretion, would seek to exercise in providing the services that honourable members seek. In other words, I hope that the very leap-frogging process that we seek to avoid in the broad area of public service will not occur in respect of the committees-or those employed by them-that are established in either the Senate or this House. On that basis I commend this new procedure, which I see as a notable advance in the regulation of the funding and operations of the Parliament, to this House. I trust that it will enjoy the support of all honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'the House is of the opinion that-

(1) a joint committee should be established to inquire into and report upon the Parliament's control of its own appropriations and staffing, and related matters , including the functions administered by the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, and the Joint House Department, and
(2) provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the committee should be contained in a subsequent resolution'.

In a nutshell, the amendment proposes the establishing of a joint committee. It is a matter that could well have been dealt with without any difficulty at all. I would be surprised if Government back benchers and other interested honourable members on that side-be they members of the Liberal Party or the National Country Party-did not agree with what I am trying to say. I assume they have discussed this matter. I might add that the Opposition has not given it a party discussion because it did not know the matter was coming on for debate until today. We do not take any umbrage at that because we are looking at a Senate committee on which our own members participated.

I think it is important that we have the chance to discuss these matters of how we can improve the Parliament. For example, honourable members would be aware that my leader has had notices of motion under General Business as far back as November. One is about how the machinery of the Australian Parliament, amongst other things, could be bettered. He has another about annual appropriations for the Parliamentary Library, et cetera. Neither of those notices of motion has had a chance to be discussed because of the way the Parliament functions. That, of course, is a problem of time.

The very significant thing about what has happened to the House of Representatives in relation to the Senate committee system is that we have fallen miles behind. I think this is to be deplored. Nobody is at fault. If we go back to prior to 1972 it will be seen that a simultaneous resolution was put forward in both the Senate and the House of Representatives that a committee system should be established. At that stage we were in Opposition. We favoured the committee system. But because we were in Opposition and the Executive of the day did not agree with us, no committee system was readily established in the House of Representatives. Strangely, because of what could be called the minority party in the Senate agreeing with the Opposition, which we were, it became the practice of the Senate to establish committees, and it has done so. In the course of that procedure it established the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing which, honourable members might note, in its terms of reference not only talks about the Senate's appropriation but also states:
That a Select Committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon Parliament 's control of its own appropriations and staffing . . .

So the Senate has been kind enough to indicate how we might be able to control our own appropriation and staffing in the House of Representatives. I would have thought that whilst any reasonable Executive would applaud what the Senate has done, it might have given the House of Representatives a chance also to make recommendations. After all, we have a much closer affiliation with the electorate. We have all sorts of different approaches to the problems of the nation and in constitutional terms we are the people who have to talk about appropriation and taxation. To use the words of the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) 'we have the odium of raising it'. I think it is important therefore that we ought to have some input as to how the appropriation can best be spent in the terms of this Parliament. We agree that it is important to divorce the Parliament from the Executive. I again make the point that I assume the Executive has taken this matter to its own party rooms and had a keen discussion as to how it sees the proposal. I am not objecting to the Committee's recommendations but I could not see, for example, how the office of the President is to remain paramount, which was an expression used by the Leader of the House today. In paragraph 6.6, the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing makes this recommendation-a Senate recommendation:
It is proposed that the Committee would be chaired by the President and would comprise 6 . . . members . . .

The Committee would be charged with the responsibility of the Estimates of the Senate and the consideration of staffing proposals affecting the Senate and its committees. So it is very clear that the distinguished President of the other chamber is going to be told, in a reasonable way, how best the appropriations and the staffing should be dealt with. I do not think he will have that paramount position that was mentioned by the Leader of the House. Again-this is an interesting one-in relation to the Estimates the report states that the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee would examine the proposals and then there would be a submission to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill. This is the Senate. The recommendations go on to say:
Should the Government of the day be opposed to any of the Estimates as agreed to by the Committee and included in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill . . .

I am not too clear how that happens. It does appear that the Committee is going to suggest the amount that should be in the Bill and then it is assuming that it will be in the Bill because the Committee then says that an opportunity will be afforded to the government of the day to raise its objections. I think this is a bit unusual because if we look at the constitutional position for a start, it does appear that the Senate is not really in a position to increase the appropriation, in other words, to engender more taxation. That is just a minor point. But I think it is very much to the point that this Senate Committee will be a very strong and paramount committee. The Committee report also states:

In relation to staffing, the Committee would examine proposals seeking to vary the organisational structure of the Senate . . . and staffing and recruitment policies and make recommendations to the President.

I think in view of that, the Senate has certainly gone a long way along the road to working out its own destiny with an appropriation which we would be expected to provide. We do not seem to have any of those facilities. One is not critical of any Speaker, least of all yourself, Mr Speaker. But what we are trying to get here is some input into what would be a reasonable appropriation for both Houses to cover all the matters that are the subject of concern.

If we look at the House of Commons (Administration) Act we see that the commission includes the Speaker, the Leader of the House, a member of the Opposition and three other members. One gets an input. But we have a very unusual situation here where there will be no input from the point of view of the House of Representatives. If we are going to talk about controlling our own funding, we agree with that, but we would want to see also some intelligent appraisal of what the funding should be. Therefore, it would be on the basis that we would have some clear knowledge of the input. I think the Bill, whatever it is, would certainly pass both Houses without too much trouble if we had a joint committee that could look at some of the matters I have in mind. At least the committee would have dealt with the Bill. It would be a bit unfair to be talking about an annual appropriation if people feel they have never had a chance to make an input on these matters.

Again, in relation to staffing, we think it is certainly important that the Public Service not be the pacesetter. But also it does not want to be the last rung of the ladder. We have had awful trouble here in a number of areas outside the Parliament. But certainly relating to Public Service administration and industrial matters, we have had massive strikes that have been settled only by arbitral processes which have castigated the Public Service administration. The Professional Radio Employees Institute dispute which brought every airline in Australia to a halt is a classic example. The Australian Broadcasting Commission is having dreadful trouble at present trying to get some flexibility into what is called the rigidity of the Public Service administration of salaries. We are breaking out of that. That is to be welcomed. At the same time we do not want to be creating salaries which are in any way above what would be the norm.

I think it is also important that we attract the best, as we should in Parliament. It is important that we perhaps take people from outside the Public Service. We might need them from the private sector in the terms of getting the expertise that we want. For example, there is some concern in the research area available basically to the back bench and more importantly to the Opposition which, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, has to compete with the Executive and with all the resources of its bureaucracy available to it, plus its own ministerial staff. It is not really a fair competition unless we can get adequate research staff. There has been some limitation and cut back in respect of research staff. That is not an indictment of any particular person but it is an Executive approach to appropriation. We see nothing wrong with improving the quality of staff and certainly guaranteeing that there would be no stranglehold by the Public Service Board. I make the point again that we would like the Presiding Officers to be able to get the best possible staff.

What I am saying is that I hope the Government could see some merit in a joint committee where we could perhaps go back jointly, as we do in a number of areas, and say: 'Let us look at this Parliament as one segment, not in two separate parts'. It is certainly in one segment when it talks about the question of the Parliamentary Library, the Joint House Department or the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. It is important that we have an input there. Nobody disagrees with that.

It seems to be quite blinkered in vision to think that when it comes to the appropriation of what is worth while from the point of view of the House of Representatives we will not really have an input into it and the Senate will be making all sorts of arrangements to suit itself. It would not be beyond exaggeration to suggest that the Senate might think it needs a lot more financial resources than the House of Representatives and would be expecting to get them simply because it is the Senate that makes those determinations. It could be some sort of an embarrassment and it could perhaps lead to conflict if it is suggested the Senate needs so much more. One of the things the Senate would certainly be pitching its focus on in that respect would be its committee system because it has so many committees. It wants to give support to them, it wants to get more staff for them and more appropriation. We, by the same token, are bereft of that facility. Perhaps now we will be bereft of an appropriation.

I think it was an intelligent move to establish joint committees in a number of areas. They have worked well in the past. I think in relation to this matter it is important for the Government to suggest to the Senate that it welcomes the work done by the Senate but that in respect of the appropriations a joint committee should be set up. It could benefit from input of members of the House of Representatives. None of the senators have any knowledge of the House of Representatives or of the responsibilities of members of this House. They work in a different area altogether and they are motivated by their priorities. Again , I make the very clear point that the senators will dictate all sorts of conditions, which they feel is their right, to the President of the Senate in relation to staff and appropriations. Before we reach that situation, I have moved:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'the House is o the opinion that-
(1) a joint committee should be established to inquire into and report upon the Parliament's control
That is the whole of the Parliament-

of its own appropriations and staffing, and related matters, including the functions administered by the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, and the Joint House Department, and-
This is a machinery provision-
(2) provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the committee should be contained in a subsequent resolution'.

I conclude my remarks on this basis: The Opposition envisages a committee that would not be large in size but would comprise the usual joint membership. It should be able to report quickly because it would have all the advantages of the Senate investigation and recommendations. Without being offensive to the Senate, I do not think such a committee would agree with the detailed recommendations of the Senate as I have outlined to the Leader of the House in respect of paragraph 6 which appeared at pages 21 and 22. It is for that reason the Opposition feels that there should be some input from members of the House of Representatives. The only way to achieve that is to establish a joint committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that the Aboriginal land rights legislation has had a huge effect in the Northern Territory on both Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act has now been in force for just over five years. The amendments in question today, contained in the Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, are not controversial but they are significant. They are good amendments recognising both the wishes of Aborigines and the needs of the wider population. For that reason, I support them. From the outset I identify to the House the particular importance of clauses 4, 5 and 6. It is these clauses that provide for title to the Hermannsburg area south-west of Alice Springs to be granted to the traditional owners.

SPEECH.PARA: I was struck recently by a comment in an article written last year by Mr Charles Perkins, Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission. He claimed in an article entitled 'Fifteen Years of Development' that:
The developments in the last decade have been remarkable but in the last five years even more so.

I believe it is no coincidence that the period cited by Mr Perkins is the period in which the Aboriginal Land Rights Act has been in force, because it is only over the last five years that Aborigines have emerged from the paternalism of previous administrations into a period of self-management and self-reliance. But what of land rights in the Northern Territory? When the land rights Act was proclaimed Aborigines were granted some 19 per cent of Northern Territory land under Schedule 1 to that Act. Since then 60 land claims have been lodged. Of those, 17 were settled or received, one was withdrawn, one was amalgamated with another and 41 are still outstanding. Nearly all the land available for claim in the Northern Territory has become the subject of one land claim or another. In fact, over 45 per cent of the Northern Territory either has been granted to Aborigines or is under claim. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two tables which outline the status of Aboriginal land claims in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —In incorporating these documents, I point out that since they were prepared in 1981 a few minor changes have occurred. The changes relate to a few claims for which hearings have begun. It is interesting to note that the area of Aboriginal land claims represents well over 600,000 square kilometres, an area almost three times the size of Victoria. Clauses 4, 5 and 6 of the Bill before us provide for land to be granted to the Hermannsburg people in accordance with their wishes. Ever since 1976 it has been made clear that they do not want just one land trust for their area. They have said that just one lease could not recognise traditional ownership of their land. They have insisted that only the direct grant of separate titles to each clan group could suit the needs of the people. They have said that the different groups could speak for their own land but they could not speak for each other's land. Since then a great deal of survey work has been carried out by the Australian Survey Office, assisted by Finke River Mission and the clan groups, to define the traditional boundaries within the lease. The result, incorporated in clause 4, is that the grant of a title to the land will go not to a single trust but to five land trusts. Clause 5 meets the request by the Hermannsburg people regarding the membership of the trusts.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point I place it on record that the Hermannsburg people have waited too long for their land, and the Commonwealth has certainly been tardy in bringing in these amendments. I indicate also that the Aranda people in Hermannsburg and Alice Springs have been frustrated and have had to put up with a lot of tensions . The area just south of Hermannsburg takes in Palm Valley in the Amadeus Basin, where there are huge deposits of oil and natural gas. The Palm Valley mining partners are Magellan Petroleum Australia Limited, Flinders Petroleum N.L., Charles Davis Limited and United Canso Oil and Gas Co. (N.T.) Pty Ltd. The position of the Aranda people is clear. They want to see a pipeline from Palm Valley to Alice Springs. They can see the benefit of this for all concerned and they certainly want to reap the benefits of the royalty payments that will accrue to them. What the Central Land Council must do as the secretarial agency for the owners is meet the different groups involved frequently and get on with developing any solutions which in the long run will advantage the Aranda people.

Another significant clause of the Bill before us is clause 7, which will allow the Minister to grant land in stages. An immediate effect of this will be to facilitate the granting of the Jabiluka project area. There have been some suggestions that this amendment is aimed solely at Jabiluka. This is simply not true because the land will be capable of being granted in a matter of months anyway. Contrary to what the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) said today, nothing is being pushed through. There have been long consultations and negotiations with the Aboriginals in the area and they are yet to agree on matters relating to the Pancontinental proposals. The significance of this Bill is that it places beyond doubt the Minister's power to deal with those portions of land recommended by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner for grant but upon which the Minister cannot act on account of an application now before the High Court arising from an earlier claim.

Since its inception, the Land Rights Act has created a number of problems for both Aborigines and the rest of the Northern Territory. Unfortunately there are groups in the community who, because of their own vested interests, refuse to acknowledge that any problems need to be resolved. There is a need for continued discussions between the land councils, the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth to secure further amendments to this legislation as a matter of priority. I am aware that negotiations are current on issues such as the conversion of pastoral leases, repetitive claims, land for public purposes, rights of access and protection of mining interests following exploration. I want to emphasise the need for amendments to be worked out within a reasonable time frame so that community tensions should not be let get out of hand.

This legislation recognises the problem of claims on land adjacent to seas. It is an issue dealt with at some length by Barry Rowland, Q.C., in his examination of the Act last year. At the moment both land claims on the coast, if granted, and Schedule 1 land adjacent to the coast, have their seaward boundaries at the low water mark. The problem is that a large part of fishing in the Northern Territory is involved in fishing inshore in creeks between high and low water. The method of fishing is by placing traps and nets on the land between high and low water and collecting fish that are caught when the tide goes out. But, as Rowland points out, 'Effectively all of the coastline of the Northern Territory is, in the absence of permission, out of bounds'. So the present methods of fishing amount to trespass.

Clearly there is a detriment to fishermen in land claims along the coast. Clause 10 of the Bill therefore provides for the cost of legal representation to be paid for fishermen by the Commonwealth on the same basis as assistance with legal fees applies for pastoralists. My reservation about this is that some people might be precluded from assistance on the basis of income. Surely there is a moral principle involved here whereby the Commonwealth should pay, within reason, for the legal costs of people who are forced to defend their interests through no other reason than a piece of legislation that was forced upon them by the Commonwealth. Regardless of this assistance, the closure of seas adjacent to Aboriginal land will still remain a problem. For this reason, I urge continuing discussions to see whether a suitable compromise can be found.

There are many more problem areas to be resolved, such as the lodging of claims on stock routes. Even though this is technically possible, I believe the action by the Central Land Council was provocative in the extreme and certainly contributed nothing to the acceptance of land rights in the Northern Territory.

Putting aside these other problems for today, I would like to deal with one other issue, and that is pastoral leases purchased by Aboriginal people that can be claimed by other Aboriginals. The case that sticks in my mind is the Bathern family of Beetaloo station. The Batherns are an Aboriginal family whose property has been subject to a land claim. Yet when we look at the claimants we see that they are traditional owners from Newcastle Waters, which is off Beetaloo station . To make matters worse the Batherns were denied legal aid to help them defend their own interests. I am aware that a claim has been lodged on Vanderlin Island where the Johnson family, an Aboriginal family, has found its property subject to claim. The problem of the deprivation of rights and the livelihood of Aboriginal lessees has been identified by Rowland. It is worth while noting his comment that 'It would seem to be counterproductive to place the Aboriginals in jeopardy'.

The massive boost for funding Aboriginal enterprises over the last few years and the payment of mining royalties to the land councils has had a tremendous positive impact on Aboriginal development. I must record how impressed I am with the Aboriginal Development Commission, which is a progressive organisation catering successfully for the varying needs of Aboriginals throughout Australia. I believe this is due partially to the flexibility the Commission has but also to the professional expertise of its commissioners and their approach to Aboriginal issues. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) should consider the possibility of the Aboriginals Benefits Trust Account contributing money to the ADC at some future date when royalty income is more substantial.

I also want to commend the positive attitude that has been taken by the Northern Land Council towards Aboriginal development in the Northern Territory. The NLC understands the benefits that mining can bring the Aboriginal people and accordingly has undertaken to negotiate properly with mining compamies. Because the NLC is operating as an effective administrator it is now unfairly incurring the jealous wrath of the Labor Party. Obviously, the Labor Party wants to put Aboriginals back 50 years and put them under some sort of ALP yoke and further bureaucracy. In order to give honourable members some idea of the massive benefits that accrue to Aboriginals as a result of mining royalties, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document setting out my estimates of the mining royalty situation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

the Commonwealth, are disbursed as follows:30 per cent of payments to Traditional Owners;30 per cent of payments to the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account;40 per cent of payments to Land Councils
