INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr TAMBLING

TALK.START.PARA: —On my estimates it is important to note that royalties are expected to yield, yearly, $28m for Aboriginals in the future in addition to considerable pre-production payments, which also will amount to many millions of dollars. I note that when debating this legislation in the other place the Opposition spokesman on Aboriginal affairs, Senator Ryan, used the debate to reiterate her narrow-minded views on uranium mining. She said:

INTERJECT.PARA: At this point I would like to state the total opposition of the Labor party to the mining and export of uranium.

When one listens to the impractical jeremiah comments made today by the honourable member for Cunningham one wonders how noble he is in trying to protect the uranium industry because he is on record as trying to destroy that industry. Let me ask these questions: Whom does the Labor Party think it is kidding about this matter? Whom does it think it is helping? Does not the Labor Party know that the Aboriginals actually support uranium mining? The honourable member for Cunningham is patronising and offensive to the Aboriginals when in speaking for them today he says that he knows what is best for them. The traditional owners are not simple bush people, as the honourable member implied. He is out of date. Instead ALP supporters, who come into this House with tears in their eyes and bleeding hearts on Aboriginal issues, would deliberately use Aboriginals to further their anti-uranium policy. The ALP is very good at supporting Aboriginals when and only when it suits ALP purposes. But when the Aboriginal people disagree with the ALP, that party forgets them. Who does the ALP really think it is helping by taking a stupid anti-uranium stance? Certainly not the Aboriginals. Where else will the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Fund receive royalties upon which the Aboriginals will rely to gain some independence from government funding?

To conclude, I would like to reflect on what the future might bring for Aboriginals as development increases. We are reaching the stage at which many Aboriginal enterprises are becoming self-supporting and, as the documents I have incorporated in Hansard show, royalty payments will be about $28m per annum. I believe that we are reaching the stage where Aboriginal organisations themselves can start making more of their own decisions about Aboriginal development programs and start funding them out of their own considerable resources. I would envisage that community needs programs such as health and social welfare, over and above that which would normally be provided by the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments, could be paid for in this way. As I mentioned before, I suport these amendments because they are good amendments. I hope that, in the course of this debate, I have also prompted discussion on a range of issues which still need to be addressed and resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by refuting the allegations made by the honourable member for Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) in respect of the attitude of the Australian Labor Party towards Aborigines in that part of Australia. If the honourable gentleman had spent a little more time talking to traditional owners, he would have realised that he is exaggerating the case if he says that all traditional owners in the Northern Territory support uranium mining. I know that he supports it. He is entitled to that position. But equally , just as he is entitled to support it, traditional Aboriginal owners are entitled to have the option to refuse it, if they wish.

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been indicated by the shadow Minister in the Senate, the Labor Party is not opposed to this legislation, because a number of the amendments are a response by the Minister to legitimate requests from Aboriginal communities to meet problems in ensuring the grant of title to Aboriginal land. I want to relate most of my remarks to that part of the Bill which deals with the issue of title to land in the Alligator Rivers Region. The Minister has stated that his objective in pressing this amendment is to issue title in respect of some seven parcels of land which were recently granted by the Lands Commission, and not to delay the issue of title by virtue of some appeals that have been brought in the High Court of Australia. If that is the Minister's only motive, there can be little objection.

However, these titles include areas of land which are currently the subject of negotiation between the Northern Land Council and Pancontinental Mining Ltd in respect of the mining project at Jabiluka. My concern is that, given the opportunity to amend the Act, the Minister or the Government has continued to ignore some of the problems inherent in the legislation, which were pointed out by Mr Rowland, Queen's Counsel, in his examination of the Act, which was completed in August 1980. One of the more important criticisms made by Mr Rowland which, to my mind, operates continually adversely to the interests of traditional owners, is that in the legislation that created the Aboriginal Land Rights Act and which gave birth to the Northern Land Council, we created an organisational framework which was not related to the structures of Aboriginal society, and in which the potential for conflict of interest was endemic.

I do not want to minimise the significance of either the land rights legislation or the creation of structures such as the Northern Land Council as being important milestones in the continuing quest of Aboriginal communities for land rights and the protection of their culture. The fact is that, within the legislation, Parliament has created, in the Northern Land Council, a conflict model which would test the skills of the most able manager in the corporate sector or the capacity of any very senior and experienced public servant.
In his important analysis of the operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act, Mr Rowland, Q.C., pointed out:
The Land Council is funded in part from royalty type payments received from mining on Aboriginal land (section 64 (1) and section 35 (1)).
This is his opinion:
It may at times be seen to have a financial interest that could temper the objectivity of its advice to the traditional owner.

It is regrettable that, given the amendments to the Act contained in this legislation, there has been no attempt by the Government either to act on the Rowland recommendations or to initiate discussion of these recommendations with Aboriginal communities or within land councils. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Rowland recommendations on land councils, at pages 54 and 55 of his report.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Land Councils
I have already indicated earlier the areas of concern that relate primarily to the conflict of interest situation that can arise where:
(a) a Land Council acts for several parties that may have different views and interests relating to proposals that affect more than one party; and

(b) the Land Council is funded in part from royalty type payments received from mining on Aboriginal land (s. 64(1) and s.35 (1)). It may at times be seen to have a financial interest that could temper the objectivity of its advice to the traditional owner.

With respect to (a) above, I would suggest that either the local Land Trust or the Aboriginal owners and communities be given executive power to seek their own independent advice and do their own negotiations, subject to overriding approval , or otherwise by the Land Council and the minister before any agreement can be finalised, with the Land Council holding the balance to decide between conflicting views or interests where consent is not a requisite.

I have been told by senior officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs that the suggestion that Land Councils be relieved of their function to negotiate on behalf of Aboriginal groups would, in their view, be a departure from a basic principle established under the Act. Clearly also Woodward J. place great emphasis on the role of the Land Councils in this regard. I do not intend to debate whether this is a basic principle or not. I believe there are practical as well as philosophical difficulties in this area and I see a need for a change of emphasis.

With respect to (b) above, I would suggest that the Land Councils should be funded from consolidated revenue or from the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account; the main thrust being that their funds be not linked directly to the amount of royalty type payments received. No doubt the 30% of the amount paid by the Commonwealth could still be paid to the Land Council for payment to the Aboriginal groups in the area affected (sections 64 and 35). I have mentioned earlier that I am told that there will be sufficient funds available for the purposes of negotiation without relying upon future royalty type payments. It may be thought that this is sufficient to overcome the problem I have raised.
Funding will also be required for the local groups referred to under item(a).

It seems to me that this would retain the original concept of the Land Councils , enable them to be seen to be completely independent and objective, and at the same time it would give some standing and autonomy to the local groups.
It is outside my competence to deal in detail with the administrative procedures that this would entail but I cannot foresee that they would pose any great problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In his speech in the Senate supporting the Bill, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) indicated that the stage had been reached in negotiations between Pancontinental Mining Ltd and the Northern Land Council that the Council was now going back to the traditional owners to explain the agreement to them and to ensure-to quote him-'that it has their agreement'. He indicated that he, as the Minister, must be satisfied that appropriate information is available to traditional owners to enable them to make the judgment which they are required to make under the Act. I wonder how serious is the Minister. I wonder how serious is the honourable member for the Northern Territory. I wonder how serious are we, as a Parliament, when, at the same time as these discussions are taking place, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and the Government have given approval for the sale of uranium from Jabiluka even before the traditional owners have allowed mining to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Does not that decision, which has been publicised, as the honourable member for the Northern Territory knows, throughout the Northern Territory, reduce the process which the Minister describes under the Act to a charade? Does not such action reinforce the attitude that is to be found within Aboriginal communities right throughout the Northern Territory, that is, that irrespective of any opposition that they might have to mining, their values and their views will be overridden by a government determined to have mining, a government that prefers to achieve its mining objectives by a legal charade that could project the view that Aboriginal approval to mining is an approval that is freely given. The decision taken by the Deputy Prime Minister is to be deplored. It is just one more additional pressure designed to produce agreement from traditional owners.
In speaking of requirements under the Act and the appropriate methods and procedures, Mr Pratt, who is now a Queen's Counsel, said in the 1977 issue of Habitat:

Among the important duties of the Land Council is that of consultation with the traditional owners of Aboriginal land before any decision is made in respect to that land. This removes the responsibilities from miners and government alike in establishing in any given place at any given time precisely with whom they should be negotiating.
He goes on to say:

If the right people are not brought together and given an opportunity of consultation in their own time and unless they are given adequate assistance in reaching a decision, including due explanation of any proposal, then it cannot be said-
Let me repeat that-
it cannot be said that true Aboriginal consent or dissent has been obtained.
He says later in the article:
Time is needed for consultation and experimentation. It should be emphasised that it is not likely that the same measures will suit all clans or communities.
So Mr Pratt is as aware as the honourable member for the Northern Territory of the diversities in attitude within Aboriginal communities on this very important question.

Those very commendable sentiments seem to have been abandoned recently by Mr Pratt, who during the Koongara debate publicly entered the political arena on behalf of the Government to rebuke the shadow Minister responsible for the environment and conservation. The honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) has referred to that. I thought that it was strange at the time that a Queen's Counsel acting on behalf of the Northern Land Council would seek to involve himself in what was an area of public political controversy. I presumed that he was acting on instructions. It was not until I was in Oenpelli some time later that I learned that the relevant meeting of the traditional owners had not yet taken place, so there was no way that Mr Pratt could be said to be acting on their instructions when he sent the telex to the Minister which was quoted in Parliament.

I believe that that highlights the dilemma in which traditional owners find themselves. Under the Act, traditional owners have to be advised on the range and the options available to them. One of those options is a non-mining option. On the evidence, I do not believe-nor do I think that the honourable member for Northern Territory would believe it if he talked to traditional owners; nor do I believe that the Minister would believe it if he examined what is happening on the ground-that anyone could honestly reach the conclusion that the no-mining option has ever been seriously available to traditional owners. My discussion with them confirms that. I am not arguing that there may not be some Aboriginals who favour mining. But what seems to me to have emerged in this situation is a new form of legal paternalism in which negotiations are entered into by legal advisers for and on behalf of the Northern Land Council and when, after Mr Pratt has reached what he regards as satisfactory arrangements with the mining companies-who, after all, ultimately pay his fees-considerable pressures are applied to traditional owners to give their approval and to comply with those agreements.

Further, I for one am sick to death of reading in the southern Press articles about black nomad millionaires and about the large sums of money received by some Aboriginals, so that within the white community there is the view that there is a whole group of tribal Aboriginals wandering around the Northern Territory who can write a cheque as if they were Saudi Arabian oil sheiks. I say this on the facts: In any agreement signed to date no traditional owner has received financial benefits which would compare in any way favourably with the fees that have been received by the lawyers who have negotiated these agreements . I am concerned that these legal advisers are so confident of the benefits of their negotiations that considerable pressures are applied on traditional owners to have them concur with whatever agreements have been reached with mining companies. One such owner was so concerned about the future of his land and the pressure placed upon him and his family that he wrote a letter to the Northern Land Council. I will read only sections of it but I seek leave to incorporate the whole letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
3 March 1982
The Chairman,
Bureau of the Northern Land Council,
P.O. Box 3046,
Darwin, NT 5794
Dear Sir,
We had a meeting today. Chris Haynes came out to check up on what I have been saying. He said I should write to you and tell you myself.

My father's father lived on this land. He was the King of the Gagudju. He looked after this land and the people who lived on it. My father was all the same. Now it is my responsibility. I am an owner for this land. We all together look after this land, the managers and the owners.

We have been telling people for a long time about our land but they haven't been hearing us. They listen but they haven't been hearing us. This has happened many times but still they don't understand.

We can't wait any more. Everybody is pushing us. Pushing, pushing, pushing. Now they want us to sign but they don't understand what it means for us. This is our life. Everybody said 'You're asking far too much money. You Aboriginal people have got to have good reasons for asking for a lot of money. What do you want this money for?'

Now I'll ask you one question. How much is your life worth? How much do I have to pay you so I can take your life away? People will say that we are just trying to make trouble now and stop everything, but we don't want trouble. We just want you to understand what we are giving up . . . our life. It will cost Pancon money. It will cost us our life.

We know you don't understand by the things you ask us to do. We can't tell you all our sacred sites, like you want us to because you don't understand. How can a fence protect our culture. Our culture is more than a painting on a rock. You even think that all our culture is there painted on a rock for everybody to see. We've got big places. Some for men. Some for women. We've got places where we make boys into young men.

We've got places where our ancestors came when they made the land and gave us our language and songs. How can you think that your fences can save our culture. We need more than fences. We need understanding but you haven't got that yet.

I am not trying to stop you. I know you have been trying but you are all the time pushing and wanting us to sign. Some ceremonies take six years or seven years, but you have only given us six months or seven months to negotiate.
These rocks, they've been here for millions of years. We are only new. We have only been here for forty, maybe fifty thousand years. You have only just come here. You don't even know the place yet.

So, we are still responsible and this is what we say. Because you don't understand, we have asked others to write the story for our places. They sit, they listen. We tell them and they understand. We asked one man, Stephen Davis, to tell those men how we feel but you didn't listen. We didn't want trouble. We just want you to understand. We don't know what is wrong with you. We tell you the truth. We are always straight with you. But now we must do something ourselves. We have seen what happened to others when mining came too quickly. They've lost. They're getting skinny. They don't believe in that mining any more . We don't want that to happen to us and so we have asked for our stories to be written. We want our sacred places to stay as they are. We want to make sure they are protected. They are our culture. They are our life. When our stories are written we will tell them ourselves. We cannot tell you our sacred things but we can teach you with the outside stories that are written down.
We want you to understand this so that we can work together.
Yours faithfully,
(BIG BILL NEIIJI)

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of the letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: We can't wait any more. Everybody is pushing us. Pushing, pushing, pushing. Now they want us to sign but they don't understand what it means for us. This is our life . . .
Now I'll ask you one question. How much is your life worth? How much do I have to pay you so I can take your life away?

I am not trying to stop you. I know you have been trying but you are all the time pushing and wanting us to sign. Some ceremonies take six years or seven years, but you have only given us six months or seven months to negotiate.
These rocks, they've been here for millions of years. We are only new, we have only been here forty, maybe fifty thousand years. You have only just come here. You don't even know the place yet.

I find that a singularly sad, moving and eloquent letter which highlights the plight of one traditional owner and stands as stark testimony to the pressures upon him. It is not just a matter of pressure upon him. Pressure has been applied to individuals whose personal association with this traditional owner, Mr Neiiji, has made them targets-targets of Mr Pratt, the learned Queen's Counsel who is acting for and on behalf of the Northern Land Council. If the Minister cares to inquire he will learn that one of the younger, more dedicated park rangers responsible for Aboriginal training schemes in the National Parks and Wildlife Service recently was called back from leave to meet false charges levelled against him by Mr Pratt. I invite the Minister to make that examination .

Equally, if the Minister inquires he will be informed that by virtue of the assistance provided by Mr Davis-who is mentioned in Mr Neiiji's letter-to Mr Neiiji to write his story, the story of his land and his relationship with his land, the Sacred Sites Authority was approached and told it should terminate any relationship it had with Mr Davis, again on the basis of representations made by the enthusiastic Mr Pratt. I do not know whether these representations are made on Mr Pratt's own initiative or whether he regards that as part of a continuing brief for his client. I doubt whether there is any resolution or minute on the records of the Northern Land Council to justify these actions by senior counsel who seems to be confused as to where his duties lie. On Mr Pratt's own analysis the relationship of his clients must also include traditional owners. If perhaps there is some conflict between the interests of the Northern Land Council and the traditional owners then the Minister should be paying close attention to the recommendations of Mr Rowland which would enable, through the Northern Land Council, separate legal representation for traditional owners.

If the Minister's undertakings are to be taken seriously, I invite him, not at the conclusion of the negotiations but now, to examine the comprehension and the understanding of the traditional owners of agreements that are already initialled. I had discussions last weekend with some traditional owners as to their understanding and their comprehension. If the Minister can say to this House that the traditional owners are in a state of real knowledge in respect of those agreements then the Minister would be deluding himself. In fairness to all the parties concerned, areas of understanding, of trust and of comprehension by traditional owners of their rights and entitlements, should have been established at the earliest point of the negotiations. The fact is that they were not. The fact is that the Government is so anxious to push mining development in the face of declining markets that it is prepared to allow standards to prevail which would not operate and which would not be accepted at any other level of the Australian community.

The time is well overdue when we must do more than pay lip service to Aboriginal hopes and aspirations and like the honourable member for the Northern Territory believe that we have satisfied those aspirations by standing up and quoting some general sum of money which will be flowing to Aboriginal people. The glib assertions to be found in the honourable member's speech and in the Minister's speech may well satisfy a compliant back bench which is committed to mining on traditional Aboriginal land but it will not satisfy the hopes of the Aboriginal people of Australia. It certainly will not satisfy the members of the Opposition, the Australian Labor Party. The Aboriginal Land Rights Act gave important rights to traditional owners and placed important responsibilities upon the Northern Land Council. It is the Minister's responsibility to see that those rights are protected and it is the Minister's responsibility to see that those responsibilities vested in the Northern Land Council are effectively discharged.

The relationship which exists between this Government, this Parliament, this nation and its Aboriginal people is moving to a point where increasingly it is inviting the scrutiny of the Western world. It is important-it is overdue-that in developing those relationships we see that many of the basic concepts which were contained in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act are maintained. It is important also that while giving due recognition to the many things that have been achieved we realise that in meeting the debts which Australian society owes to the Aboriginal people, who are still the most oppressed group in Australian society, we will not settle for the smug rhetoric which has been expressed by the Minister in respect of this Bill and which has been expressed by the honourable member for the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I take the opportunity in concluding this debate to address a few remarks to the House. So many things have been put by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) as fact. Let me just put to the House some real facts. Firstly, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) tried to assert that this legislation was being put to the Parliament in order to enable the Jabiluka project to be given the go-ahead. The assertion was that without this legislation the project could not be given approval by the Aboriginals or by the Government. That assertion by the honourable member is simply not correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The position was very plainly put by my colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), in the Senate on 18 March as recorded at page 758 of the Senate Hansard of that date. The Minister said:

The honourable senator raises the question about whether I need this clause to be passed to enable the Jabiluka project to go ahead. The short answer to that is no, it is not necessary for this clause to be passed. The Jabiluka area can be granted once the appropriate survey work is completed. The Jabiluka project could go ahead whether or not this amendment is passed. In fact, the purpose of this amendment is to put beyond doubt the capacity of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to make progressive grants. The purpose of that is to ensure that Aboriginals are not disadvantaged.

So the beneficial reason for this legislation is to favour Aboriginals so that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs may make progressive grants of title in respect of Aboriginal land. My colleague went on to explain the kind of circumstances in which it would be beneficial to be able to make those progressive grants of land.

Let me state one other incontrovertible fact. The Northern Land Council has not reached any agreement for the mining of this land. Consultations are still proceeding. If honourable members, particularly the honourable member for Cunningham and the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, know the requirements of the Aboriginal land rights legislation they will know that before an agreement to mine can be consummated the consent of the traditional owners is required to any agreement reached by the Northern Land Council. That is stipulated by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but what sort of effort is put in to explain--
—Order! If the honourable member thinks he has been misrepresented he can use the forms of the House after the Minister has made his speech. I call the Minister.

—The third fact is-the legislation also stipulates this-that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is required to be satisfied that a land council, in this case the Northern Land Council, has itself satisfied the requirements of the Act. That, as I have pointed out, required consultation with the Northern Land Council. But it is more than consultation. It requires the consent of the traditional owners to any agreement proposed to be entered into for mining on Aboriginal land. I can speak not only from a knowledge of what the Act itself requires but also from personal experience having been directly involved in the preparation and passage of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and in the negotiations which were conducted by the Northern Land Council with the Government and the Ranger mining companies with respect to the Ranger uranium mining development. So I have some personal knowledge of the lengths to which the Northern Land Council goes to consult with traditional owners, to ascertain their views and to be satisfied that they consent to the agreement negotiated.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose 'hypocrisy' is a word that is very lightly used in this place. Indeed , it ought not be used at all because it is unparliamentary. So I do not use that word. But I make this point, having listended to the honourable member for Cunningham being critical of white people who provide technical and expert assistance on a proper professional and commercial basis to the Northern Land Council. Of course, we heard in this place the derisive comment by the honourable member for Cunningham about hired silks. The hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party really does seem to know no bounds because have honourable members opposite forgotten that white lawyers fought hard, honourably and properly on behalf of Aboriginal people to achieve Aboriginal land rights and see legislation of this kind passed by this Parliament? Do they forget that Mr Justice Woodward, who provided the report which is the foundation of Aboriginal land rights, was himself a lawyer? Do they forget that Mr Justice Brennan, a distinguished member of the High Court of Australia, and previously a leading counsel of the Woodward Commission, is the father of Aboriginal land rights? If they look at the Bill annexed to the Woodward Aboriginal Land Rights Commission report they will see what distinguished legal work he carried out. He is a white lawyer. Do they forget the example of the work that was done by Geoff Eames for the Central Land Council? He is a white lawyer. Do they forget the work done by Phillip Toyne, a white lawyer who did so much to achieve land rights for the Pitjantjatjara people of South Australia? He was responsible for legislation that the Tonkin Government placed before the South Australian Parliament. It seems to me that the Australian Labor Party so quickly and so easily forgets the work of these white lawyers when it so quickly seeks to condemn those who are being properly employed and who are properly working for the Northern Land Council today.

The attack by the Opposition has not been launched against this Bill. Rather, it has been launched against the prospect of further uranium mining in the Northern Territory. One wonders where the Opposition's support for Aboriginals begins and where its vehement opposition to uranium mining ends. I have gone through that experience before. I have heard before all the sorts of things that members of the Opposition have said this afternoon. I have observed at first hand the lengths to which members of the Opposition will go in the vehemence of their opposition to uranium mining to prevent Aboriginals in the Northern Territory, through their own body-the Northern Land Council which is an all- Aboriginal body-conducting negotiations and consultations with traditional owners in a proper way having due and proper regard for the interests of those traditional owners and the necessity to communicate with them, to take that approach cautiously and carefully and at great length to see that they understand and know before any consent is given.

I can understand the position of Big Bill Neiiji. I understand that his letter, which has been incorporated in Hansard, has been published in the Northern Territory. I am quite sure that Big Bill, as a traditional owner, will be heard and will be listened to by the Northern Land Council and I am quite sure that before the Council agrees to anything with Pancontinental Mining Ltd for mining at Jabiluka it will be satisfied that the traditional owners collectively consent to whatever is proposed. I ought to make the point, as members of the Opposition have tried to attack my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), that the Government proceeded to give the project approval conditional upon the conclusion of an agreement by the Northern Land Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that proper, putting that pressure on them?
—Nothing could be clearer than a conditional approval of that kind to indicate-
—What enormous pressure on the small, simple people.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Cunningham that if he persists in interjecting, I will have to take direct action.

—Nothing is clearer than that to indicate that the Government understands that the Northern Land Council must satisfy the requirements of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act before any mining can take place. Let me conclude by picking up a remark made by the honourable member for Cunningham earlier. He referred to the Aboriginal people of this area as simple bush people. I only wish that he would not embark on and use such condescension towards people who are properly called a proud people. They are an intelligent people. They are living in this modern world more intelligently than are so many white people, including some people in this House.

—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister is entitled to his opinion, just as much as the honourable member for Cunningham. He will resume his seat or I will name him.

—The honourable member for Cunningham will withdraw that remark. It is a reflection on another member of Parliament.

—I conclude by saying that I only wish that members of this House would not indulge in such condescension in the future when speaking about the Aboriginal people of Australia. The Government proposes this Bill to the House as a beneficial piece of legislation for the Aboriginal people, necessary to enable the Aboriginal Land Rights Act and its intentions to be properly fulfilled.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). In his answer, he named a whole bevy of very prominent and not so prominent members of the legal profession, some of whom I know personally and for all of whom I have the highest regard.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat for a minute. As I see a matter of personal explanation, the first question I should have asked was whether the honourable member claims to have been misrepresented, which was glossed over in this case. Clearly, Parliament requires the honourable member to get up and point out how he was misrepresented-not argue the case-and leave it at that. Has the honourable member finished?

—I want only to say that was an intentional and gross misrepresentation. A specific allegation has been made in respect of one lawyer who has entered the list and, to try to confuse the issue, the Minister has thrown into the debate the names of very distinguished lawyers who have served the Aboriginal community very well indeed over many years.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not take much time but I do claim to have been misrepresented on two points. In his reply, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) sought to show that, because I used a phrase which described the traditional owners as simple people, somehow I was being condescending towards them. No one knows more than I that the affection for the land passes the understanding of both myself and him.
—The honourable member is now debating the point.

—The Minister misrepresented me when he sought to prove that I was being condescending towards Aboriginals. That was not true. The second substantial point is that he sought to say that I said, during my speech in the second reading debate, that I thought that the Jabiluka claim could not be granted without the clause 7 amendment. DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS (PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1982.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent reported.
Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Social Services Act with respect to the payment of the family allowance to certain temporary residents of Australia, the waiting periods for unemployment and sickness benefits and the recovery of a sickness benefit from compensation payments. It also contains a number of minor technical and machinery amendments.

As honourable members are aware, family allowance is payable to parents residing in Australia who have the custody, care and control of children under the age of 16 or who have dependent full time student children aged between 16 and 25. In the case of parents not born Australia, and where there is no clear intention to reside here permanently, family allowance is payable after residence in Australia for 12 months. Under these provisions, family allowance is payable to diplomats and consuls and their non-locally-engaged staff, also to overseas armed forces personnel who are not attached to the Australian forces, and the close families of these persons. Such persons have no real claim on the Australian community for the support of their children. Rather, they are the responsibility of their own governments. It was never envisaged that the family allowance scheme should encompass the support of people in these circumstances and it is considered appropriate that the eligibility which these people have at present should be removed. Similarly, as the law stands at present, family allowance is payable with respect to the children of a person who is a prohibited immigrant and has entered or remained in Australia without approval.

The Bill renders such persons ineligible to receive family allowance. If, of course, the position of a prohibited immigrant is regularised under the provisions of the Migration Act, thus rendering him eligible to remain in Australia, his exclusion from family allowance would cease.

As regards diplomatic personnel, I mention that there are situations in which certain countries are represented by honorary consuls who are Australian citizens or permanent residents. The amendment in the Bill will not apply to such persons as the exclusion is expressly limited to persons in the relevant categories who are not Australian citizens or permanent residents.

I turn now to the provisions in the Bill which will modify the operation of the rules which specify the day from which unemployment and sickness benefits are payable. New administrative arrangements were made last year under which claims for unemployment benefit are lodged with the Department of Social Security rather than the Commonwealth Employment Service as was previously the case. Unemployment benefit is payable from 7 days after the date the person became unemployed, or 7 days after the date he makes a claim, whichever is the later. It has become apparent that, in some circumstances, an unavoidable delay occurs between the time an unemployed person registers as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service and obtains a claim form for unemployment benefit, and the time that the claim is lodged with the Department of Social Security. Where, for instance, people in rural areas receive and submit claims by post, the lodging of this form with the Department of Social Security may be delayed. As a result, entitlement to unemployment benefit is delayed.

The Bill provides that, where a person registers as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service, and his claim for unemployment benefit is made within 14 days of the date of that registration, he will be regarded as having made a claim on the day on which he registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. In special cases, such as where mails or travel are disrupted by floods , bush fires, industrial disputes etcetera, the Director-General will be able to extend the period of 14 days, thus further minimising any adverse effect of the claim being delayed.

The Bill also amends the provisions of the Social Services Act relating to the waiting period for sickness benefit. Generally, under the existing provisions a claimant for sickness benefit is required to serve a seven-day waiting period before entitlement to benefit commences provided he has not already served such a waiting period in the previous 13 weeks. There are people who suffer from chronic illnesses who require treatment or who otherwise become incapacitated for work in respect of the same sickness at periods longer than 13 weeks. In these cases a claimant is requires to serve a second waiting period on recurrence of the incapacity. This can cause hardship where such people have exhausted their sick leave entitlements and have no other means of support during the waiting period. The Bill rectifies this situation by providing that the waiting period may be waived in respect of a recurring incapacity which is connected with the cause of a previous incapacity in respect of which sickness benefit was paid.

The Bill also amends the provisions of Division 3A of Part VII of the Act. These provisions were enacted in 1979 but have not been proclaimed because of a number of administrative and machinery deficiencies. The principles embodied in Division 3A extend the principles already contained in section 115 of the Social Services Act and are not new. Section 115 provides that, if compensation is received for the same incapacity as that which qualifies a person for sickness benefit, and it is paid for the same period in respect of which he is qualified to receive sickness benefit, the rate of the benefit normally payable for that period is reduced by the amount of the relevant part of the compensation. Similarly, sickness benefit may be recovered where the compensation is subsequently paid for the same period for which sickness benefit has been paid. Typically, this occurs where a person receives sickness benefit whilst awaiting settlement of a compensation claim, and some or all of the sickness benefit paid is recovered on settlement. These provisions ensure that a person does not receive a 'double payment' in respect of an incapacity for work and that responsibility for maintaining the incapacitated worker is properly borne by the third party liable to pay compensation, rather than the community.

Section 115 does have a number of shortcomings and these shortcomings have been exploited to circumvent the recovery provisions to which I have made reference. It was in order to address these problems that Division 3A was enacted in 1979 to strengthen and clarify that provision where necessary.

Division 3A has itself been found to have a number of deficiencies. It was because of a concern that the division would not be as effective as intended that there has been delay in bringing its provisions into operation. For example , Division 3A as drafted would not encompass compensation payable under 'no- fault' motor accident schemes because its terms are restricted to cases where compensation arises by reason of a judgment of a court or an agreement in settlement of a claim. The amendments will remove this restriction.

The existing Division 3A also makes for cumbersome administration in some respects. The provisions under which notices relating to recovery of sickness benefit are given to the parties involved require the same notices to be given to both an insurer and a third party. Experience has shown that third parties who are insured do not wish to become involved in these matters, and the amendments provide that it is necessary to give notices only to the insurer. This will reflect the position at present under section 115, and avoid both costs to third parties and in administration. The amendments also enable notices to be given more efficiently, so that a more effective service is provided to insurers subject to the legislation. At present, notices under Division 3A would have to be given only by post. The amendments will enable the Director-General to give a notice to an insurer over the counter, in appropriate circumstances. This will also reflect the current position under section 115.

A further amendment changes the way in which the Director-General directs that compensation is to be taken into account in these situations. The existing Division 3A requires the Director-General to give a direction as to the rate of sickness benefit to be paid. This is cumbersome, because the rate of sickness benefit may alter for other reasons, such as a receipt of income, and a new direction would be necessary. The amendments require the Director-General to give a direction as to the amount by which sickness benefit is to be reduced in taking account of compensation. If the rate of sickness benefit alters for other reasons, it will not be necessary to make a new direction. Other amendments remove a number of other deficiencies in Division 3A of a machinery nature. As I have said, the Bill also contains machinery or administrative changes to other parts of the Act, as well as a substantial number of minor or formal amendments of a drafting nature.

Prior to 1972, the Department of Social Security was known as the Department of Social Services. The Social Services Act has not been amended to reflect this change of name. The Bill therefore proposes to change the title of the Act to the Social Security Act and the title of the Director-General of Social Services to the Director-General of Social Security. References to other specific offices within the Department will also be similarly amended.

The Government's initiative in 1976 in introducing a new system of family allowances is not fully reflected in the terminology of the Act. The Bill replaces a number of out-dated references to 'child endowment' with references to 'family allowance'. The Bill also incorporates an amendment to clarify the entitlement of institutions to family allowance in respect of dependent, full time students between the ages of 16 and 25.

Another amendment will extend the notification provisions of the Act with respect to handicapped child's allowance, where the child has left the home in which he or she was receiving constant care and attention. This will ensure that the person with continuing entitlement to allowance is identified at an early stage. A schedule to the Bill proposes amendments which will remove some technical inconsistencies in the legislation and bring the legislative drafting style into line with current practice. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Viner, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In my ministerial statement to this House on 'Wage Determination and Industrial Relations' on 16 February, I informed the House that I intended to introduce a number of legislative initiatives. I now present a Bill to the House about matters that I then foreshadowed. The Bill contains a number of elements but its philosophy can be distilled to three main themes: Protection of the rights of the individual; to provide a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and employees; and to open the door to movement from within the work force so that present union rigidities and monopolies are loosened and structures created which are more suited to a modern economy and representative negotiations between employers and employees.

Let me develop these themes and outline to the House how the Bill will give effect to the Government's aims. Fundamental to the Government's approach is its belief that the expression and pursuit of democratic freedoms, including the rights of association and the withholding of labour, and the operation of free institutions, such as trade unions, cannot survive in the absence of law. Our industrial relations system assists in setting a base from which behaviour patterns can develop which are acceptable to the majority and which in turn foster a strong, progressive nation. The notion that for some reason unions are so different that they and the conduct of their members should stand beyond the law is untenable and at the root of much of the industrial trouble Australia has experienced in recent years. There are constitutional limits on the Commonwealth 's industrial relations powers although there may be more room to make new laws than we have given the Constitution credit for in the past. In the life of this Government we have already acted within our legislative power to protect the public interest. We have legislated to ensure that rank and file union members have a greater say in union affairs and, to this end, are provided with full information on their union's financial affairs. We have strengthened the provisions for secret ballots. We have provided a method of seeking rapid deregistration where a union threatens the safety, health or welfare of the public. We have also strengthened our own hand in dealing with unreasonable industrial action by employees of the Commonwealth.

The Government is, by this Bill, proposing legislation in support of the principle of voluntary unionism and the restructuring of unions away from a craft and occupational basis. We are also legislating to give employers the automatic right to stand down employees who cannot be usefully employed as a result of industrial action. These proposals reflect so far as is reasonable the points raised by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employer representatives at two meetings of the National Labour Consultative Council.
Voluntary Unionism

Legislation for voluntary unionism is a firm policy of the Government parties. In our liberal democratic society individuals should have the right to decide whether or not they want to join a union. If they do not they should be protected by the law. This Bill will give them that protection. If they do so, they are encouraged to play a responsible and active part in their union's affairs.

Nobody should be under any pressure to join a trade union. There should be a completely free choice of whether to join or not to join a union. This is a central feature of the Bill now before the House. It introduces to the principal Act this right of choice. It removes from the jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the power to grant preference to unionists and it provides avenues of redress against both employers and unions in the event of victimisation of individuals who do not want to join a union.

The objects of the Act will be amended to declare positively the principle of voluntary unionism. By the Bill, an employer or a union will be prohibited from disadvantaging, to use a general description, an employee or prospective employee not wishing to belong to a union. A person will be able to defend his or her freedom of choice by a right to seek compensation in the Federal Court of Australia for loss or damage suffered as a result of action taken to force him or her to join a union. We are providing that, where an employer is the subject of compensation proceedings and considers that a union's conduct has induced the employer to take the action for which he is being proceeded against, the union may be joined as a party to those proceedings. It would then be open to the Court to give judgment against the union instead of the employer or partly against the union and partly against the employer. It may be of interest to honourable members to note that this is consistent with provisions passed recently in the United Kingdom Parliament.
Stand-downs

I now turn to the provisions in the Bill relating to stand-downs. Increasingly, strikes and bans from plant to plant or industrial action by small key groups of workers have been used to put intense economic pressure on a single employer, a whole industry or the whole community. In circumstances of this character, an employer simply has no work for his employees. The employer's capacity to resist a strike or other industrial action is reduced to nothing, because the wages bill goes on running. Protection is needed in that situation and the Government intends to provide it. If unions are to have, as a basic principle, the right to strike then it is surely not unreasonable for employers to have at their individual disposal, the right to protect their commercial interests in circumstances where they are put at risk by union action.

Strikes, and other forms of industrial action, do not simply affect the businesses of those directly subject to that action. They affect also other businesses and other employees dependent upon the goods and services of the business being disrupted. As the community has come to appreciate to its cost and often to its despair, industrial action in one place ripples widely throughout society. The law has long recognised, by awards of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, that workers who are not on strike but who cannot be usefully employed because of action elsewhere, may be stood-down without pay. But the processes to be followed are, in many instances, cumbersome and involve delays. The terms of the stand-down award may not in the end be commensurate with the industrial pressure being exerted leaving the employer lamenting that the law and the circumstances leave him defenceless.

Using a blend of constitutional powers, the Bill extends to employers the direct right-I emphasise that-to stand-down employees who cannot be usefully employed because of industrial action. The decision to stand-down will be the decision of the employer according to the circumstances with which he is faced. There may be circumstances in which employers would wish to use the processes available presently through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Bill gives employers the choice between doing that or using the new provisions. However, the Commission will not be able to limit the rights of employers under these new provisions.
Industry Unions

I now turn to the proposals relating to industry unions. There is a widely held community view that the craft system of union organisation is increasingly creating difficulties for the sensible operation of industrial relations. Craft and conglomerate unionism has resulted in a situation where most industries and many enterprises face a multiplicity of unions. Union amalgamation of itself is not sufficient to improve this situation substantially. Much of the past discussion about amalgamation of unions failed to distinguish between the objective of allowing the creation of industry unions and amalgamations which create bigger conglomerate craft unions, the membership of which straddles a number of industries. Encouragement of the development of unions along these lines will not, in the Government's view, assist in reducing the level of industrial disputes to any significant degree. The record of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union is testimony to that.

The Government's long-standing objective, expressed in our industrial relations platform, is the encouragement of industry based unions. It is also the objective of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. This legislation faces up to the need for change by providing a legislative framework which will facilitate the restructuring of unions into fewer industry based organisations. The Government is well aware that the development of industry based unions will not be an easy process or one that will take place overnight. However, a start has to be made. Within the trade union movement itself and amongst employers there is evidence of interest in some industries that unions should be industry based.

The Bill defines an industry for the purpose of registration of an industry union as the business, trade, manufacture, undertaking or calling of employers. It is proposed to leave to regulations the prescription of classes of industry for which a union can be formed to enable discussions to be held with the ACTU and employers as the process of change is initiated. In this way the development of industry unions can occur in consultation with unions and employers directly involved and the peak employer and union bodies. To obtain registration an association of employees will need to satisfy the Registrar that the members are employed in a single industry and that they constitute a substantial majority of the total number of persons employed in that industry.

The Bill also provides for regulations to be made to allow for a secret ballot to be held of employees in an industry to test whether a substantial majority wish to form or join an association seeking registration as an industry union. The Government also is making provision for an existing union to become an industry union by the process of changing its rules to enable the absorption of employees who would not otherwise be eligible to become members. However, an existing organisation, seeking to establish itself on an industry basis, will have to satisfy the Industrial Registrar that the rule changes are authentic and have been democratically endorsed within the organisation. Where an amalgamation of unions would result in the formation of an industry union, special conditions will apply to facilitate that amalgamation.

The present requirement that in a ballot to approve an amalgamation at least one half of the persons on the roll of voters must vote and, of those voting formally, more than one half must vote in favour of the amalgamation, will be relaxed. Where an amalgamation would result in the formation of an industry union, and only that in that case, not less than one quarter of the persons on the roll of voters will need to vote, and of those voting formally more than one half must vote in favour of the amalgamation. This particular provision is drawn from earlier recommendations made to me by the National Labour Consultative Council about the amalgamation processes of the Act. These provisions of the Bill are seen by the Government as a first step in the process of encouraging the formation of industry unions. We will naturally be watching their application and development closely and be ready to adapt or change them in the light of experience.

The Government has not included in this Bill any provision for the formation of enterprise unions of which I have spoken in this House and to other audiences. The Government's proposals in this area are being further developed in consultation with employer and union groups.
Other Provisions of the Bill

There will continue to be, unless the situation is remedied, problems in relation to the deregistration of organisations under both the State and Commonwealth systems. This Bill is intended to cover the situation where a union tries to play off one industrial relations system against another in circumstances where a State union is deregistered in its own jurisdiction. A State union will not be able to move into the Federal jurisdiction to avoid the consequences of its industrial misbehaviour in a State jurisdiction and the discipline of that jurisdiction. These proposals have been introduced at the request of the Western Australian Government. To operate, this part of the Bill requires reciprocal State legislation. I will be raising this with my colleagues , the State Ministers for labour.

Amendments are made by this Bill to provide for greater certainty in the administration of unions where casual vacancies arise. There are situations in which it may be desirable for a vacancy to be filled by appointment, rather than by election. The amendment will permit a casual vacancy to be filled by appointment, provided that the unexpired portion of the term of office is less than 12 months. Special provision is made in the case of appointment to a casual vacancy in an electoral college. At present, the rules of an organisation do not permit a person to be elected to hold an office for a period exceeding four years, without being re-elected. The Government has accepted representations from the ACTU, through the National Labour Consultative Council, that this requirement is unduly harsh when officers are approaching retiring age. The Bill , therefore, proposes that the rules of an organisation may permit the holder of a full time office, who is due to retire within a period of 12 months after the expiration of the period for which he was elected, to remain in office until he retires.

Consistent with what I said earlier about encouraging democratic control of organisations registered under the Act, the Government has decided to enlarge the scope for financial assistance to parties to proceedings in the Federal Court in cases involving that principle. The opportunity has been taken of consolidating the financial assistance provisions in the Act. The Bill also introduces new procedural arrangements to simplify the application of the Territories of variations to common rules made in the Commission. These arise from discussion of this matter in the National Labour Consultative Council. These principal legislative initiatives which I bring before the House-voluntary unionism, an employer's statutory right of stand down and the formation of industry unions-are the start of a program of reform of the Australian industrial relations system. There is much to be done. As I said to the House in my ministerial statement on 16 February last, ultimately reform of industrial relations in Australia needs to go further than simplifying and restructuring what we now have. It is as challenging a cause as any which faces Australia. This Bill tackles three principal areas of current interest. It is based on the philosophy, policies and objectives of the Government parties. The Bill confronts no one. It looks to strengthening the rights of individuals, bringing into balance the rights of unions and employers and opens the door to the restructuring of union organisation in this country. I therefore commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (VOLUNTARY MEMBERSHIP OF UNIONS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Viner, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is a short Bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, and a simple one. It follows from what is provided in the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill, to give effect to the Government's intentions about the voluntary nature of union membership and preference to unionism. The Bill declares void any award determination or agreement which makes provision relating to the employment of persons by reference to membership of an association. It withdraws powers to make provision for preference by reference to membership of an association. It is therefore designed to put into effect in the area of Commonwealth Government employment the principles proposed in the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
