PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, for Mr MacKellar, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House will make important changes to both the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act. Firstly, the House will be pleased to know that the National Health Act will be amended to authorise the provision, by the Commonwealth, of free vaccine for immunisation against the disease of mumps. The inclusion of a mumps vaccine at Commonwealth expense in the immunisation programs presently conducted by the States and Territories complies with the principles of good public health and is an indication of the Government's continuing concern to safeguard and improve public health. It is proposed to substitute a combined measles-mumps vaccine for the measles vaccine currently being provided. The combined vaccine will be administered to children at 12 months of age in accordance with the childhood immunisation schedule recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council. It is anticipated that around 342,000 children will be immunised in a full year with the new vaccine. At today's prices of $4.65 per dose, the Government will be contributing $1.5m a year to the new immunisation program. Although this will, in part, be offset by the phasing out of the single measles vaccine, the additional expenditure at today's prices will be in the order of $1m each year.

I turn now to the proposed changes to the health insurance arrangements. Honourable members will be aware of the considerable attention that has recently been focused on what is commonly described as medical benefits fraud by medical practitioners. This Bill contains new measures which will present a very strong deterrent against such abuse. It is now possible to estimate, from statistics compiled, that the extent of fraud and overservicing by some members of the medical profession is of the order of at least $100m a year in medical benefits, of which about half is attributable to fraud and half to overservicing. My references to fraud relate to such matters as making claims for services that were not provided, whereas my references to overservicing relate to the provision of services which were not reasonably necessary. Before proceeding to outline the provisions relating to fraud, I wish to place clearly on record the Government's view that it is a minority of the medical profession which is abusing the health insurance system. It is for that reason that I believe these provisions will have the support of the majority of medical practitioners.

In commercial terms, medical practitioners are in a virtually unique position. The financial structure of their practices is largely underwritten by the medical benefits scheme which is publicly financed through both taxation and medical benefits fund contributions. Furthermore, most patients are generally not in a position to question the correctness of medical accounts. The operation of the medical benefits scheme is therefore very heavily dependent upon the trustworthiness of medical practitioners. The existing health insurance legislation already contains provisions for penalties in the form of imprisonment or fines to be imposed by the courts on practitioners convicted of medical benefits fraud. However, those provisions do not take into account what might be termed the commercial aspects of such fraud. Furthermore, there are sometimes substantial practical difficulties faced by the prosecution in obtaining what might reasonably be considered to be adequate penalties in medical benefits fraud cases.

The Government considers that a medical practitioner who has been proved to have committed medical benefits fraud on two or more charges is guilty of a most serious breach of trust and should be dealt with accordingly. It believes that this serious breach of trust warrants the exclusion of that practitioner from the financial benefits of the medical benefits arrangements for a substantial period. Accordingly, this Bill contains provisions under which services by a practitioner who has been found by a court to have committed medical benefits fraud on two or more charges will not attract payment of medical benefits for a period of three years. I must emphasise that there will be adequate provision for appeal. First, in relation to the initial findings by the court, the practitioner has the usual rights of appeal to a higher court. Furthermore, before a first disqualification for medical benefits purposes comes into effect, the practitioner concerned may apply to the Minister for a review of the disqualification. In the course of any first period of disqualification, the practitioner may again seek a review of that disqualification by the Minister. The Minister will be empowered, upon any such application, to modify the disqualification by reference to several matters, including: A reduction of the period of disqualification from three years to some shorter period; permitting the continued payment of medical benefits for certain specified types of services; permitting the continued payment of medical benefits in respect of services to specified groups of persons or services in specified places, such as hospitals. Provision will also be made allowing an appeal by a practitioner to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a decision by the Minister on an application made to him for modification of a disqualification.

I should point out to the House that the provisions which I have outlined above concerning ministerial reviews of disqualifications apply only in respect of a first period of disqualification. They do not apply to any subsequent disqualifications which may arise where the practitioner concerned has again had two or more medical benefits fraud offences proven. The Bill provides for the publishing and laying before each House of Parliament of a statement setting out the details and effects of the practitioner's disqualification. There is also adequate provision made for past, present and prospective patients of a disqualified practitioner to be advised of the details and effects of the disqualification.

I ask honourable members to note that the provisions which I have outlined relate to cases of medical benefits fraud proven by due legal processes through courts of law. They are founded upon, and are limited to, the financial aspects of transactions through the medical benefits scheme and they stand apart from any penalties the courts may see fit to impose in relation to the criminal aspects of such cases. In order that the necessary supporting regulations and administrative arrangements may be made for the operation of these provisions, they will come into operation on a future date to be fixed by proclamation. While the Government has given priority in this Bill to the problem of fraud, it is also very concerned at the extent of overservicing that is believed to occur. It intends therefore to review the existing legislation relating to overservicing and take whatever measures are shown to be necessary to control this other area of abuse.

The Bill also includes provisions of an administrative nature, concerning the issue of health care cards to people in the low income category as defined in the Health Insurance Act. Currently, the legislation provides for the making of a declaration that an eligible person having a low income is a disadvantaged person. Such a declaration operates for a period of six months and enables the person to obtain concessions under the health insurance arrangements. The person is deemed under the legislation to have lodged a further application for a declaration of disadvantaged person status at the end of the six months period. However, this has the practical disadvantage that a new declaration can give continuous disadvantaged person status only retrospectively. The amendment provided for in the Bill will enable the assessment of eligibility for continued disadvantaged person status over the last four weeks of the six months period and thus for a new declaration to be made before the end of that period.

Recently, medical practitioners have been moving towards incorporation of their practices under company laws in order to gain certain benefits in relation to superannuation and to limit their personal liability for damages. The Department of Health has been involved in deliberations with representatives of the profession and with other interested organisations to ensure that, in relation to health benefits matters, the incorporation of medical practices does not affect the personal responsibility of practitioners for their services, and that they continue to be individually subject to the provisions of the health insurance legislation relating to the making of false statements and claims and the provision of excessive services. In principle, the Australian Medical Association has made quite clear its position on maintaining the personal professional responsibility of medical practitioners to their patients, whether or not they are employees of incorporated medical practices.

It is consistent with this approach that a practitioner who provides a service to a patient ought to be personally identified on any documents used in connection with the claiming of benefits. Accordingly, the Bill before the House provides that Commonwealth medical benefits are not payable in respect of a service unless these documents contain information to be prescribed by regulations. This will enable the making of regulations requiring accounts, receipts and assignment forms to bear the name of the individual practitioner who has provided the service and other associated information. Also consistent with the principle of personal accountability of practitioners are the provisions of this Bill which aim to ensure that, in the emerging situation of incorporation of medical practices, or in other employment situations, individual practitioners will continue to be subject to existing provisions concerning irregularities in connection with claims for medical benefits and controls over the provision of excessive services attracting medical benefits. The proposed new provisions will provide that, where a practitioner is an employee of an incorporated practice or some other type of employer, both he and the practice or other employer will be accountable in relation to the making of false statements or claims in respect of medical benefits.

In relation to overservicing-that is, claiming medical benefits for medical services that are not reasonably necessary-the existing legislation provides for a system of medical services committees of inquiry. These committees are able to make recommendations that practitioners who are found to have provided excessive services should be counselled, reprimanded or required to repay benefits. The provisions of this Bill will ensure that, in proceedings before such committees of inquiry, practitioners employed by incorporated practices or other types of employers cannot, in effect, shield behind alleged directions by the incorporated practice or other employer. The incorporated practice or other employer will also be subject to the operation of these committees. However, in a case of incorporated practices, the other practitioners who are not directly involved will not be affected as individuals.

Honourable members will be aware that the basic registration of medical practitioners to practise is effected under State and Territory laws. Responsibility for ensuring the personal accountability of practitioners to their patients insofar as clinical procedures are concerned, is primarily a matter for the State and Territory authorities. The Minister for Health is therefore consulting with his State and Northern Territory colleagues with an aim of obtaining, as far as practicable, appropriate co-ordination of their registration laws and those of the Commonwealth which are concerned with medical benefits.

The Bill also provides for time limits to be imposed on the lodgment of claims for Commonwealth medical benefits. Claims lodged by the public on the funds will no longer be automatically accepted for payment if the service was rendered prior to the introduction of current health arrangements and more than two years have elapsed between date of service and date of lodgment. The date the current health insurance arrangements came into operation is specified as 1 September 1981 and provision exists to vary this date in the event of future changes. It should be noted that there is no intention to impose a time limit on the lodgment of claims relating to services rendered within a current scheme.

A time limit will also be imposed for medical benefits claims where the doctor bills the Commonwealth direct. A claim will no longer be automatically accepted for payment by the Department of Health if the claim is not lodged within six months of the service being provided. At the discretion of the Minister for Health, the time limits referred to may be extended where this is considered justified, particularly to avoid any hardship that may be caused to the claimant . A period of grace of three months will be allowed after the legislation is enacted and before the restrictions are imposed.

As I have already indicated, there is presently no time limit on the lodgment of any claim involving Commonwealth medical benefits. The major reasons for the imposition of time limits are the difficulties and costs currently experienced in processing 'old claims' and the opportunities for fraud and incorrect payment that the present system provides. (Quorum formed). It is hoped that in the future these problems will be substantially reduced. Registered medical benefits organisations are currently required to lodge claims for reimbursement of Commonwealth medical benefits with the Department of Health and to provide such supporting information as is prescribed. A similar requirement exists for the organisations to lodge claims for advance payments of Commonwealth medical benefits. Such claims are required to be accompanied by certain information including prescribed information about earlier advances.

The Bill presently before the House provides that the form and the manner in which the required information is to be provided in support of claims for reimbursement or advances may be prescribed by regulations. It is intended that the regulations will specify the manner and form by reference to the media on which the information is to be recorded-for example, disc, magnetic tape or film -as well as the format for the data and the actual information content for each item of data. Information is currently supplied in a non-standard fashion which has required the Department of Health to operate expensive manual and computerised systems. For this reason it is considered, in the interests of economy and efficiency, that the new provisions are necessary.

Section 106AA of the Health Insurance Act presently provides for the publication of the particulars of determinations made by the Minister for Health in accordance with the report of a medical services committee of inquiry on alleged cases of overservicing on the part of medical practitioners. As a further means of discouraging such improper practices, clause 26 of the Bill will amend section 106AA to require the Minister to prepare a statement setting out the particulars of any such determination and have a copy of it laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of its preparation.

Clause 31 of the Bill makes a similar amendment to section 106G of the Health Insurance Act which contains similar provisions relating to the reports of optometrical services committees of inquiry. Again a statement setting out the particulars of any determination by the Minister will be required to be laid before both Houses of Parliament. The Bill will also make important changes to section 130 of the Health Insurance Act. This section concerns the divulging and release of information obtained by a Commonwealth officer in the performance of his duties under the Act. It is believed that these proposed changes will, amongst other things, greatly assist the Government's attempts to combat and discourage the instances of fraud, overservicing and other improper practices to which I have previously referred.

The present provisions of section 130 are mainly concerned with maintaining the confidentiality of information concerning the affairs of other persons, which is acquired by officers in the peformance of their duties under the Act. May I take this opportunity of reaffirming the Government's continued belief in and support of this very important principle. The Government also believes, however, that in order to assist in the discouragement of the sorts of improper practices to which I have just referred and the effective administration of other Commonwealth or State Acts, provision should be made to allow the release, by the Department of Health to specific persons or authorities, of information relating to these matters.

The amendments to section 130 will therefore allow the release of information concerning the conviction of a person on charges of fraud under the Act, to the Commonwealth Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs, specified State authorities and personnel and authorised personnel of registered health insurance organisations. The new provisions will also allow the release to these persons of information considered to be relevant to, respectively, the administration of an Act administered by either the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the administration of a specified law of a State or Territory, or the carrying on of the business of a specified registered health insurance organisation, whichever the case may be.

These provisions do not open the way for indiscriminate use of information concerning the affairs of individual members of the public. Protection of the identity of an individual person will be maintained except in cases where the person has been convicted of an offence under the health insurance legislation or where the Minister has reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person has committed, or been a party to, such an offence. Furthermore, persons under the control of any recipient organisations or authorities shall not divulge information made available by the Department of Health except in the performance of their official duties within that organisation.

I now turn to the amendments to the National Health Act. Honourable members will be aware that under the new health funding arrangements States and Territories generally have the responsibility for determining levels of public hospital charges. However, the levels of public hospital charges, and the related benefits are a significant factor in determining basic hospital contribution rates. As a general principle, the benefit available from basic hospital insurance should generally cover the charges raised by public hospitals provided the charges do not bear too heavily on the hospital insurance system and, therefore, on contributors to the basic hospital tables.

The amendments to the Act extend the existing power of the Minister for Health to declare standard hospital inpatient fees for hospital benefit purposes to cover professional and outpatient service fees for which basic hospital benefits are also payable. They will ensure a consistent approach by the Commonwealth in this area and, at the same time, provide a mechanism for the Commonwealth to protect the interests of contributors where hospital charges raised conflict with Commonwealth policy or would increase basic hospital table contribution rates to an unreasonable extent.

The Bill also proposes the conferring on the Minister of an additional power to control management practices of registered health benefits organisations. The Government has always maintained a policy of minimum interference in the internal administration of registered health benefits organisations. It also believes that healthy competition in the industry promotes efficiency, assists in keeping contribution rates at minimum levels and, therefore, is in the best interests of contributors. These views remain unchanged. It is believed, however , that a broad power to deal with inappropriate management practices would be desirable. As the National Health Act currently stands, there are provisions that may be used in relation to specific instances of undesirable management practices, but only on an ad hoc basis. In addition to conferring powers to deal with inappropriate management practices, the new provisions will authorise the Minister to issue directions to a registered organisation, other than a friendly society, prohibiting it from carrying on business other than business as a registered organisation.

A further minor amendment proposed in the Bill relates to the processing of rule changes of registered health benefits organisations under the National Health Act. The Minister's power to approve changes to rules relating to benefits and conditions for the payment of benefits for non-basic tables will be extended to cover existing tables as well as new tables. However, the overall policy of allowing organisations considerable scope for innovation and flexibility in relation to non-basic health insurance benefits cover would not be affected.

The Government has for some time now viewed with concern the various problems that have necessitated many of the amendments proposed in this Bill. These proposals have been foreshadowed for some considerable time and will receive, I believe, the full support of the Australian people. Much careful thought and planning has gone into their preparation. Overall, I firmly believe that the Bill contains important provisions which will be of great assistance in ensuring that the provision of health care in this country remains as efficient, equitable, cost effective and free from abuse as possible. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the main part of a package of Bills to extend taxing and control laws to rigs used in exploring or exploiting the non-living natural resources of the seabed of Australia's continental shelf. The package includes provisions extending the control and taxing aspects of Customs, excise and sales tax Acts and the controls available under immigration and quarantine laws. For constitutional reasons, amendments proposed to be made to the various taxing Acts will be the subject of separate Bills in the package. Certain collection and control provisions associated with those taxing provisions are, however, included in this Bill. It has been the Government's longstanding policy that the treatment to be accorded these off-shore activities should be no different, in principle, from the treatment accorded similar resources ventures being undertaken within Australia. The petroleum exploration and recovery activities taking place in Bass Strait and elsewhere around Australia for upwards of 15 years have been governed by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. In that period, the only extension to off-shore activities of Commonwealth law outside the ambit of that Act was the application in 1968 of relevant income tax legislation.

This package of measures has now become necessary as a result of developments on the North West Shelf of Western Australia. The previous practice was for all overseas sourced rigs, ships, equipment and materials for off-shore operations to be imported in the normal way through Australian ports. The massive scale of the North West Shelf developments, however, requires that a number of giant platforms be brought directly to the places on the shelf at which they are to operate. During the operation of the rigs there will necessarily be a constant flow of service craft, personnel and goods between the installations and the Australian mainland. There may be occasional movement between places overseas and an installation once attached. It is essential that these important activities should not provide an avenue for the entry into Australia of prohibited imports, such as drugs, or of exotic diseases or illegal immigrants. I know that both sides of the House support the Government in the importance that it attaches to the maintenance of Australia's security in matters of customs, quarantine and immigration. The package of Bills provides a proper legislative basis for the exercise of customs, excise, immigration and quarantine powers to remove any degree of danger of illicit activities at these remote sites. The powers are necessary both for the arrival of those installations and for subsequent contacts between the installations and places overseas.

Under the amendments proposed by the Bill, a person wishing to bring an installation directly from overseas to its operating site will be required to obtain prior permission. Where permission is granted it will be subject to the applicant's compliance with specified conditions. The conditions will ensure that the arrival of the installation and its attachement will be supervised by officers until customs, immigration and quarantine clearance is given. Generally , these Bills provide that installations attached to the Australian seabed will be deemed to be places in Australia. However, the amendments to the Quarantine Act provide that an overseas installation shall be deemed to be part of Australia on attachment only if it has previously been given pratique. This will be given only if the quarantine officer on his prior inspection is satisfied that it is disease free. By the device of treating installations as part of Australia, movements between the Australian mainland and installations which have been attached and cleared may be allowed to proceed without substantial hindrance. However quarantine controls may, if necessary, also be applied to this movement. Contact between an attached installation and places overseas will be controlled. This means that anything which comes from overseas for delivery to an installation must first enter Australia through a first port of entry. At first ports of entry there are adequate facilities for the customs, immigration and quarantine examination of vessels and goods which would not generally be available at installations. Goods that are found to be a health risk can be treated or destroyed and prohibited imports can be seized.

The customs and quarantine amendments provide for goods from overseas to be permitted to be brought directly to an installation. This discretion is considered desirable to permit the operator of an installation to obtain goods quickly from overseas. Such goods might be mechanical parts which may be necessary to repair some equipment and which would not usually present a customs or health risk. The discretion will be used sparingly and as a general rule vessels will be required to call first at normal ports of entry. The discretionary arrangements if used may present some risks of avoidance of controls. Accordingly, the Bill proposes provisions to give officers powers and functions that are, in respect of off-shore installations, equivalent to those now given to them by existing legislation in respect of vessels, goods and persons at points of entry into, or exit from, Australia. Powers under the Immigration (Unauthorised Arrivals) Act 1980 now apply to certain ships when they enter Australian waters and to certain aircraft when they land in Australia . For the purposes of that Act, 'Australian waters' do not extend beyond the outer limits of the territorial sea. The powers under that Act will be extended to those ships when brought to an Australian installation outside Australian waters, as so defined, and to those aircraft that land at any Australian installation. The powers I have mentioned include the power to board installations and search or examine them for goods on board for customs, immigration or quarantine purposes. If, for example, there are any goods on board which could carry disease to mainland Australia, these may be ordered into quarantine and treated or destroyed as appropriate. Prohibited imports may also be seized and customs control exercised over dutiable goods on board. It is also necessary to ensure that there is proper authority for the application of the taxing provisions of customs, excise and sales tax law. This will be achieved by further Bills in this package.

A very important result of applying the customs laws to these operations will be the legislative protection of the right of Australian industry to share in the Development opportunities to the same extent as now applies in relation to undertakings within Australia. The granting of concessional by-laws in respect of equipment and materials manufactured outside Australia for use with off-shore installations will be dependent on suitably equivalent goods of Australian manufacture not being reasonably available. By Parts VIII and IX of this Bill, which will amend Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1 and 5) 1930, together with a group of sales tax Bills that I will introduce shortly, it is proposed also to extend the application of the sales tax law to off-shore installations of the kind that I have earlier described. In practice, the sales tax law in respect of the importation of goods is closely associated with the customs law. Administrative efficiency in the collection of sales tax on importation of goods is achieved by giving a collector of customs power to collect sales tax at the same time as customs duty is collected.

Parts VIII and IX and the associated sales tax Bills will amend the sales tax law in conformity with the proposed amendments of the customs law, thereby achieving desirable uniformity in the application of these laws to off-shore installations and removing the scope for anomalies which could exist if the two laws operated differently. The amendments to both laws will have a common date of commencement. It is intended that, after the second reading is agreed to, this Bill be referred to a legislation committee of this House. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Keating) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff Act 1966 as part of the package of Bills proposing extension of the Commonwealth taxing and control powers to off-shore operations. The Bill proposes that an overseas installation, and goods on board, shall be deemed to be imported when the installation is attached to the Australian seabed. Where such an installation is first brought to a place in Australia from which it is to be taken for attachment to the seabed, the installation and goods on board are to be taken as imported on arrival of the installation at that place. Goods brought direct from overseas on an installation are also to be deemed to be imported on their arrival. Likewise, goods taken from an installation to a place overseas are to be deemed to have been exported. The Bill also proposes amendments to the principal Act to identify when an installation is imported. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX AMENDMENT (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) BILLS (Nos 1 to 9) 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

These Bills are a further part of the package of Bills to extend the application of certain controls and taxation measures to off-shore installations. The Sales Tax Acts do not currently impose tax on transactions or acts involving goods which are outside geographical Australia but within the area of the continental shelf.

The measures proposed by these Bills, together with the associated measures contained in other Bills in this package, will have the effect that any off- shore installation will be given, from the date of its attachment to the continental shelf, the status of a place in Australia. This will mean that any transaction or act affecting goods on such an installation which would be taxable if the goods were in geographical Australia will, in future, also be taxable.

The amendments will apply to installations brought to the continental shelf directly from overseas and to installations taken there from Australia. They will apply to the latter whether or not the installations were themselves originally imported into Australia.

In their practical effect, the amendments will not subject to sales tax an installation itself insofar as it is for use in the mining industry in carrying out mining operations or in the treatment of products of those operatons because such an installation is, in these circumstances, exempt from tax under other provisions. However, certain attachments to or parts of an installation-for example, attachments or parts used for the comfort, entertainment or recreation of persons living on an installation-could be subject to sales tax. Attachments or parts of this kind which would be taxable include cinema equipment, built-in or fixed sporting equipment, floor coverings and kitchen equipment. A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of the technical aspects of these Bills is being made available to honourable members. I commend these Bills to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Mr Hunt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Road transport, whether of freight or people, will in the Australian context remain in all areas the most efficient and convenient form of transport, except for large bulk cargoes. Therefore Australia, with its huge distances and low population, will always rely heavily in both city and country areas on its road system. The natural tendency of Australians to prefer the motor car to mass transit systems is to be commended. There is ample evidence, even in areas of large-scale public transport, that the comparative cost of mass transit is still higher. Australia does not suffer from lack of space and the only real requirement is that our planners commence the planning of Australia, and in particular our urban areas, to accommodate the problems that the automobile will generate. This should commence by reducing the density trend of our cities and be followed by effective road systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike other sectors of the transport system, the motorist and the road freight operator make substantial net contributions to the federal revenue. The States also impose a considerable burden on the motorist although to my knowledge most of these funds are spent on the road system. The tax contribution of road users is much greater than many would believe. While personally involved in the transport industry I was able to calculate that for a truck travelling on a thousand mile journey the contribution to government revenue was in fact 50 per cent of the actual freight charge, presuming that the truck travelled loaded to its permissible maximum. When I mention the less obvious contribution to revenue from road users few people realise that the sales tax attributable to fair wear and tear on truck tyres is 50c per tonne.

The car owner also contributes, albeit to a much lesser degree, through sales tax on the original vehicle and replacement items. The taxes levied in the financial year 1979-80 on the road user are as follows: The Commonwealth received fuel excise collections of $861m, the crude oil levy of which about 70 per cent would be applicable to the motorist of $1,445.3m; sales tax, $1,245m and customs duty, $302.4m; total State receipts which can be added to that of combined motor vehicle and driver taxes, $471.5m; road maintenance taxes and similar charges, $12.2m. That is a total of State and Commonwealth collections from the motorist of $4,337.4m. Expenditure on roads by all governments in 1978- 79 was $2,139.4m. As honourable members can see, there is a huge discrepancy, in fact $2,198m, or half the money that was spent on roads. At this stage let me make it clear that I do not support the expenditure of all road user revenue on roads. I accept that the purpose of some collections may not really be seen even for that purpose. However, I raise the matter to destroy any argument that the motorist and in particular the road freight operator does not fully fund the provision of his running surface and ancillary aids.

Railways lose money and coastal shipping loses money. Only road and air users contribute directly and in excess of government expenditure. Remote area dwellers are particularly hard hit by this policy. The incidence of road use compared with other transport systems must increase as one gets further away from the cities. The burden of direct funding of one's transport must therefore fall heavily on these people. Further, nearly all taxes related to road users have a direct relevance to the miles covered. This would appear to be fair and reasonable, but it totally ignores the huge costs to those who live furthest away.

The policy is a tax on decentralisation. The huge irony is that after contributing this high level of revenue to government coffers, road transport is still generally cheaper than government transport, such as rail. So those rural areas achieve little benefit from the community subsidy to public transport. Such subsidy, plus more, is consumed by the gross inefficiencies which invariably surface when government deviates from its successful function of tax gathering and assumes the role of entrepreneur. Australia must therefore treat its road system with top priority in terms of its transport options, now and for many years in the future. This statement is further substantiated when we consider that it is estimated that 25 per cent of the cost of all goods consumed in Australia is in freight costs.

Another interesting assessment of the savings attributable to better road systems is to be found in the submission to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of the Australian Automobile Association in January 1981. The submission states:
It can be shown that significant savings in commercial and private travel time would result from an adequate road system.

Again, quoting the Bureau of Transport Economics, discounted benefits in travel time reductions of $6261 million would flow from the warranted roads programme. Because of inadequate funding $700 million of these discounted benefits are being lost. The $700 million is made up of $188 million in savings of private travel time and $512 million in savings of commercial travel time. The latter figure of $512 million is particularly significant. As road transport is a highly competitive industry the benefits of this saving and the consequent reduction in cost pressures will be quickly passed on the community at large.

As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety I am constantly exposed to road trauma. I was hospitalised in 1976 for four months as the result of a road crash that certainly would not have occurred had road conditions at that place met acceptable standards. Allen Atkins, a researcher, estimates that the annual cost of road crashes to the Australian nation is $2, 000m per annum. Naturally this total cost cannot be attributed to road conditions, nor can money replace the 3,500 dead per annum or the 100,000 maimed . However, if as little as 10 per cent were so attributable the cost is still substantial in terms of total road expenditure. The case for a better road system has many more supporting factors. However, I will rest my case in that area and deal with other aspects of today's legislation.

This Bill provides for Commonwealth expenditure of $2,337m over the financial years 1982-83 through to 1984-85. The annual allocations are $734m, $778m and $ 825m respectively. During this time State and local governments will also make substantial contributions to the road system. Unlike the Commonwealth these two levels of government will also be actively involved in spending all of the funds provided. Relatively there has been a change in the levels of expenditure between the three levels of government. Comparatively local government has emerged as the biggest spender on roads and the Commonwealth the lesser. Figures on road funding provided by the Bureau of Transport Economics in its 1979 assessment of the Australian road system give the following information: Based on current prices in 1974-75 the Commonwealth spent $439m, the States spent $ 356m and local government spent $567m-a total of $1,362. In 1978-79 the Commonwealth spent $584m, the States spent $696m and local government spent $ 859m. The annual average growth rate for the Commonwealth was 7.4 per cent; for the States it was 18.3 per cent and for local government it was 10.9 per cent.

The latest Bureau of Transport Economics report also extrapolates this type of funding based on a 1974-75 constant year. When we get into present times we find that spending by the Commonwealth for 1981-82 will be reduced to $277.4m and for 1982-83, to $258.5m compared with the actual cash amount of $734 which I have just mentioned. For 1983-84 it will come down to $238m from $778m, and so on. This is a real value decline in spending over the previous decade of 39.4 per cent. From 1974-75 to 1978-79 the percentage share of road funding by levels of government had changed as follows: For the Commonwealth, the percentage share in 1974-75 was 32.2 per cent and by 1978-79 it was 27.3 per cent. For the States, in 1974-75 it was 26.1 per cent and by 1978-79 it was 32.6 per cent. In 1974-75 local government spent 41.7 per cent and in 1978-79 it spent 40.1 per cent.

All of these figures can be debated. The method by which the States and local governments divide up the funds provided by the Commonwealth can lead to double counting. These figures do not show the very substantial untied grants that this Government makes available to local government by way of the 2 per cent personal income tax. This year these funds totalled $350,866,000. A large percentage of these funds is directed to roads yet appear as local government expenditure. State and local governments do have the prime responsibility for their road systems. The purpose of the 1981 Act to divide roads into only three categories of national, arterial and local, and for the Commonwealth to accept the responsibility for national highways, supports this view. Therefore, I am not prepared to argue that the Commonwealth is necessarily spending too little in relation to its partners in the roads business. I am sure, however, that the total expenditure is insufficient.

This statement is further supported by the fact that although there has been a change in the relativities between the Government's expenditures, all appear to have reduced their expenditure on roads when expressed as a percentage of total Budget outlays. In recent times, the percentage of local government Budget expenditure on roads has dropped from slightly above 40 per cent to slightly below 40 per cent, which is a small drop. Total State expenditures in 1974-75 were 5.38 per cent of Budget outlays and in 1979-80 were 4.93 per cent of Budget outlays. Commonwealth expenditure had dropped from 2 per cent in 1975-76 to 1.74 per cent in 1981-82.

For all the reasons previously given I deplore the reduction in priority that all levels of government have given to our road system and to our road users. The Labor Opposition probably would agree with that viewpoint. However they, like most other Australians who support this viewpoint, do not generally choose to discuss the method by which this imbalance might be rectified. Too many people still believe that the fairy godmother will attend to that. They overlook the fact that even in that fairy story the conveyance eventually turned back into a pumpkin.

The Australian Automobile Association, in its submission to the Prime Minister, did have the courage to bite the bullet. At page 6 of its submission it made a suggestion as to the reallocation of Commonwealth budgetary outlays that it thought should occur to redress the imbalance. This was accompanied also with a graph showing how certain areas of the Budget had taken over in expenditure terms. The AAA quite correctly addressed itself to our big ticket expenditure items of social security, health, education and defence as they existed in the 1981 Budget. It recommended expenditure cuts in two of those areas which had shown the greatest percentage growth in recent times-that is a cut of $159m in social security for a percentage reduction of only 1.6 per cent and in health a cut of $39m for a percentage reduction of 1.07 per cent. When the total amount of $198m was transferred to roads it increased the allocation from $628m to $ 901m or an increase of a whopping 31.5 per cent. Had the Association been prepared to include education for a small nip it would probably have achieved an even better result for our deserving road user.

Before the gasps of the Opposition members become too audible, let me promote arguments for this courageous stand taken by the AAA. It is beyond debate that roads will improve the Australian economy and the ability of the Australian road user to meet his special tax burden. Expenditure on roads is visible and long lasting. The desires of the Australian public, created in the main by the Whitlam Government, for excessive welfare, health and education spending is robbing all other worthwhile yet less sensational programs of sensible funding. Health spending has already entrenched a degree of corruption not previously experienced. Most people would see road spending as preventive medicine; so why should we not allocate money from the health budget directly to roads? In education we have long passed the stage when government spending was aimed at improving the student. Recent teacher strikes in the Australian Capital Territory clearly indicate that the education lobby sees student welfare as its prime industrial tool. When we spend money on roads we get better roads. I cannot say that we get better students for the expenditure of more money. Whilst recognising the needs of the aged, infirm, unemployed, families and others-I sincerely recognise their problems-I sincerely doubt that many other welfare payments do much for Australia or, indeed, the recipients of such welfare. There is money in the system for roads but Australians must be prepared to question the expenditure priorities at present allocated by this Government and by the State governments. The alternative is a declining road system or heavier taxation.

Other inequities do arise in regard to the distribution of Commonwealth road funds. Western Australia, the State from which I come, represents one-third of the Australian land mass. It has a commitment to essential roads unequalled by other States. Past Commonwealth governments recognised this fact and ensured that 17.9 per cent of total Commonwealth funding was directed to this State. This has been eroded steadily to a level of 12.67 per cent. Western Australian road makers face a constant battle to hold this level of expenditure, against the recommendations of the Bureau of Transport Economics that the figure should be more like 9 per cent. The period of decline of these funds has occurred at a time when resource development in Western Australia is at its greatest. Western Australian resources almost invariably occur in remote and underdeveloped areas which require long and difficult road systems. The massive Tom Price iron ore mine, first established in 1966, still requires 270 kilometres of road sealing to connect it to the established highway system. Many resource companies are now making as much as a dollar for dollar contribution to speed up the road making to their facilities. These roads will eventually generate untold future revenue for expenditure upon all Australians.

The Minister has chosen to recognise the disabilities of New South Wales and Queensland. Yet the members of the Committee of Senior Representatives of Commonwealth and State Road Authorities-MCSR-2-which considered the national highway system decided that if the present level of funds made available for national highways was only maintained, the years required to complete Western Australia's national highway system to a reasonable standard would be 44, whereas the period for New South Wales was 24 years and for Queensland it was 33 years. The fact that all these periods are unacceptably long is one thing but the evidence of the needs of Western Australia is obvious.

States choose to spend their funds in different ways but Western Australia, both through efficiency and expenditure, has established a road system beyond its resources. Other States may have preferred free hospitals or, as with the voters of New South Wales, a government of economic incompetence. Their difficulty should not be visited upon Western Australia. A government dollar invested in that State will still show a return.

Finally, I refer to the position of local government and, in particular, rural local government in the road making and maintenance area. I have already indicated the huge financial contribution that this sector now makes to roads. I also believe that it generally expends its money wisely attempting at all times to maximise the result in terms of road length and quality. This Government has made serious attempts to ensure that adequate funding from Commonwealth allocations is available for expenditure by local government in the interests of their constituents. My own experience, at a national level, of local government indicated considerable dissatisfaction on the east coast as to the efforts of State governments to divert Commonwealth funds, by one means or another, from local government to themselves. I appreciate the constitutional problems that confront the Commonwealth in this area. However, this matter is of such concern to me that I believe local government would be better served if the Commonwealth extended its personal income tax grants to local government as a trade-off for road funds. The result would guarantee the money to local government and would place the responsibility on the local authorities and people who use those roads .
Debate (on motion by Mr Morris) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Money Supply-Telecom Australia-Satellite Tracking Stations-Telephone Services- Coastal Surveillance-HMS 'Invincible'-Naval Air Station Nowra-State Electricity Commission of Victoria

PROCTEXT.PARA: Money Supply-Telecom Australia-Satellite Tracking Stations-Telephone Services- Coastal Surveillance-HMS 'Invincible'-Naval Air Station Nowra-State Electricity Commission of Victoria
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The interest that resulted from the question that I directed to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) this morning suggests to me that perhaps the concept to which I was referring needs some clarification. In fact, the concept that lies behind that question and the formula which is applied in connection with it, are both essentially simple. The point that I was making was that the growth of the money supply during any period must be sufficient to accommodate both the rate of increase in prices, or the inflation rate, and the rate of real economic growth. If the money supply grows by less than that combined percentage, credit must be tight and the volume of liquidity or money will be too little to do what the economy requires of it; thus, the cost of money, or the rate of interest, must increase. A smaller percentage increase in the money supply may be sufficient if the velocity of circulation of money increases enough to compensate for the lower volume of money.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that in relation to these concepts the Budget targets for 1981-82 were for an inflation rate of 10.75 per cent and a rate of economic growth of between 3 and 3.5 per cent. For this reason, to accommodate those two expectations, the money supply during 1981-82 should have been targeted towards an increase of 13.75 per cent to 14 per cent. But in fact the Treasurer and the Government set at only 10 to 11 per cent their target for an increase in the money supply. Therefore, the objectives of tight credit and higher interest rates were built into the budgetary strategy and were deliberately designed and have been persistently pursued by this Government.

The volume of money, or M3, at 30 June 1981 was $55,387m. To accommodate the increase in prices and the anticipated rate of real growth, this should have increased by between $7,616m and $7,745m during 1981-82. However, with the Government setting its target at 10 to 11 per cent, only about $5,816m would have been provided for in relation to an increase in the money supply. During the current financial year this would represent a shortfall of between $1,800m and $1,940m. The velocity of circulation of money, that is the number of times each dollar turns over, is currently in Australia about 2.35. For that reason the Government deliberately aimed for expenditure or purchasing power to be curtailed to the extent of between $4,230m and $4,559m during this current year. In fact, during this current year there could have been an additional amount of consumption and/or investment expenditure of over $4,000m. The Government, by the strategy that it adopted in the Budget, made sure that that additional expenditure in the form of either consumption or investment would not be realised.

The Government and the Treasurer now pretend some degree of disappointment that the economic growth target indicated in the Budget will not reach the 3 to 3.5 per cent which was targeted for. In fact, it is now running at about 2 per cent and over the full year it is most unlikely that economic growth will reach 3 per cent. I hope that someone will bring what I have just said to the attention of the Treasurer. The point about this is that within those Budget targets there never was, from the time the Budget was introduced, any possibility that economic growth would reach that target. I indicated on a previous occasion that in order just to maintain the current level of unemployment, economic growth of at least 3 1/2 per cent each year would be required in order to absorb into employment those people who were joining the labour force. This year the growth rate will be less than 3 per cent. Next year it will be between one per cent and 1.5 per cent. As a result, the level of unemployment must rise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice from the comments of the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) that we have another theorist on Treasury matters in the Australian Labor Party. I am not sure whether his comments are an improvement on those which the shadow Minister makes. They are theorists; they are not realists. I want to speak tonight about a commission which in the bush, in country Australia, is much maligned. I refer to Telecom Australia. I have just been shown the results for Telecom for the 1980-81 financial year. Of course, what people look for mostly is the profit. I am happy to say that Telecom recorded a substantial profit of $232.5m. The document goes on to state that that is the return on net assets of $8,198m. Of course, that is not a great return on that amount; it represents a 2.9 per cent return on the assets.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is often forgotten in the cities of Australia that people in rural Australia face grave difficulties with communications. I understand that Telecom , with the resources that it has available, tries to allocate to rural Australia sufficient funds to expand the network in that very vital area. It is a vital area: it is the producing area of Australia. The development program for last year accounted for $1,164m. That is a plough-back of profits, the depreciation allowances and the borrowings, and probably makes Telecom one of the biggest enterprises in Australia today-probably greater than the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and any of those other large private institutions.

In the six or seven years that I have been a member of this House Telecom has provided new facilities for people in the bush. I think those people appreciate those facilities, although they still want more. Radio telephones are now a reality in areas that Telecom can service. Normal reticulation would not have been available for the next 100 years in those areas. That is a start in a marvellous program for inland Australia. Also, concessions have been extended on capital contributions made by people connected to radio telephones. They pay $ 500 a year in rental. I ask honourable members to compare that $500 rental fee with the $120 to $150 that a city subscriber pays for a private telephone. There is still an anomaly and an inequity in that regard. Community Access 80 gave many subscribers access to their nearest community centre and provided for a relaxation in the high cost of trunk calls. The rates for after hours calling have been reduced and also automatic subscriber services are very much on stream .

Tonight I pay tribute to a new body that is being formed in rural Australia, the Rural Telephone Subscribers Association. This movement began at a meeting at Clermont in the Division of Kennedy, which is represented by the Honourable Bob Katter. At that meeting a provisional national council of people concerned about improving communications in that area was formed. The President is Charles Gall. The Secretary is Mrs Pam Pownall, a constituent of mine. She has pushed this matter of rural telephones for the past two years. The Assistant Secretary is Mrs Lindsay Macdonald and the Treasurer is Mrs Daphne Rich. All of these people have an understanding of the difficulties faced by people in rural Australia, particularly in respect of communications. I see this organisation, the Rural Telephone Subscribers Association, as being a latter-day successor to the Australian Inland Mission, the Flying Doctor Service and all of those people who brought a bit of life to central Australia and were concerned about it. The Association has achieved quite a lot already. It has arranged for meetings to be held in eastern Queensland, particularly over the December-January break.

Big concessions have been granted, particularly on the capital contribution made by subscribers towards the cost of providing a rural telephone service. Three scales now apply, particularly in relation to the rural connection fee. Maximum contributions have been set. A maximum of $1,350 has been set for contributions by people who live 16 kilometres outside the range. For customers seeking a new manual service the maximum is $1,750. All of these factors are a clear indication that Telecom and this Government are concerned for those people . Prior to this those services did not exist. I might mention also that the Labor Government in 1972 to 1975 practically removed this concession completely from the rural customers. These fees are now realistic so that people can avail themselves of the services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 and on 18 November 1981 I asked questions on notice of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) relating to satellite tracking stations in Australia. In those questions I asked for three pieces of information. Firstly, I sought details on the function, designation, orbital parameters and timing of satellites tracked by the Tranet station at Smithfield in my constituency. Secondly, I asked for similar information with reference to other satellite ground stations in Australia. Thirdly, I asked for the location of all satellite ground stations and observation posts involved in operations with United States geodetic satellites.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I received answers from the Minister. Apart from the information that portable geodetic satellite receivers have operated from over 250 sites-which is an interesting piece of information-in the last seven years, the short and rather trivial answers given by the Minister provided no information not already on the public record. It was certainly not my purpose in asking those questions merely to have known facts reiterated. Having provided rather trivial answers, the Minister went on to say:
To provide all the information sought by the honourable member would require the diversion of significant departmental resources which I am not prepared to authorise.

First of all, that is a rather cavalier treatment of a member's question. It is peculiary cavalier coming from a Minister who has prided himself on his dedication to the parliamentary system. I point out to the Minister that such a system can work well only when required information is provided without restriction, and this has certainly not been done in this case. It is possible, though not likely, that my constituents in Smithfield could depart this world quite suddenly. My advisers' and my assessment of that possibility is very dependent on the information requested, for the implications for my constituents of having the Tranet station in their midst is closely related to the particular satellite system involved and the regularity, timing and orbits of the particular satellites.

Let me say, first of all, that given the large number of movable geodetic satellite posts involved, I do regard it as perhaps inappropriate to seek the detailed information on that point that I requested. However, I would be surprised if no master list of these locations is on file somewhere in the Department of Defence. But it is my belief that informed public debate in this country requires the information that I requested in detail on the satellites linked to Australian ground stations. To deny it on the ground that it would require the diversion of too many departmental resources is just not good enough . Moreover, that excuse is either transparent or scandalous. It is transparent in the sense that I find it very difficult to believe that the Department of Defence does not have master lists of all satellites tracked by Smithfield and of geodetic satellites tracked by other stations in Australia. Such lists should be readily available. One would expect them to be in the Department, if the Department was doing its job.

That brings me to the other alternative. If it is not simply a transparent excuse, if those master lists of the satellites do not exist, we have a rather scandalous affair because such lists are necessary for any member of the Department of Defence or any member of this Parliament to make a proper assessment of the role of the Australian tracking stations. I am not personally able to make that assessment, but certainly we have advisers who can make that assessment if we have the information. I am simply not able to accept the Government's assurance about the innocuousness of Smithfield without being given the detailed account of its operations necessary for a proper and independent assessment. I ask, therefore, that the Minister be asked to give a full answer to question No. 3688 and at least answer paragraph (b) of question No. 3444.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up the words spoken by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I support what he said about what the Government has done in the area of communications. Certainly in the last five to seven years in which this Government has been in office much has been done in this regard for the people of Australia, particularly the people in the outback. We have to appreciate that today a telephone is a most important part of a person's life. I was pleased to hear the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) say today that arrangements have been made whereby quite a number of technicians from other parts of Australia will be working on the North Coast of New South Wales and within the Hunter Valley area. It is essential that this sort of work be carried out because this part of Australia is growing at a tremendous rate so far as population is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Those people who know the coastline from a geographical point of view would know, I am sure, that small properties exist in the mountains behind the hinterland right down to the coastline, involving areas 30 to 50 miles long. There are, I suppose, thousands of small properties in the area. Many of these properties have been divided over a period. People from the west, from Victoria and from the metropolitan areas are settling in this area on 5-acre, 10-acre or 50-acre properties. These people are accustomed to having the use of a telephone . In my electorate many outstanding applications for telephones will not be processed for quite a period. That is why I welcome the statement today of the Minister. I feel that a telephone is essential for people who live in the country.

If one looks at the coastal area from the Hunter valley to the Queensland border one will see, as I have said, that it is an area of Australia that is perhaps growing quicker than any other part of Australia. The people who are coming to this area, the business houses and the industries should have a telephone. I know that the Government is doing everything possible with the available funds. We have to appreciate the fact that Telecom Australia is a statutory authority. I believe it is well geared to meet the demands of consumers. The point I want to make is that in my electorate and the neighbouring electorates of the State there has been a great increase in the population and a tremendous demand for telephones.

Admittedly it costs a lot more to connect a telephone to a property located five miles up a creek or a road than it does to connect one in a town and the cost of laying a cable for the installation of 20,000 to 30,000 telephones in a village or town may be the same as the cost of running a cable to a property way up a road, but the point is that the people on such properties are entitled to the service. Many honourable members will have been to the Forster area. The great lakes area is a very picturesque part of Australia. A large number of city people have recently moved on to blocks of land there. In the Coomba Park area, for instance, over 30 people are waiting for the installation of a telephone. It appears that it will be late in 1983 before their priorities will be reached. That is a typical example of some of the problems in my area.

There has been an increase in the problem of line clogging. Often it takes an hour or so to get through to the Newcastle area by telephone. These problems are due to the greater demand for telephones. I would like to see much more attention than has been announced by the Minister today being given to the allocation of extra funds and materials to meet the demands for telephones within that area of the State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some trepidation that I follow the contribution to this debate tonight of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) , but I want to follow up the reference he made to the coastline from a geographical point of view. It is the coastline of Australia that concerns me. This morning the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt)-I regret that he is not in the chamber now; he was present earlier this evening-referred to the new arrangements that will be made for the surveillance of Australia's coastline. In his answer to the question this morning, he referred to the renegotiation of contracts. I had the opportunity a little earlier this evening to make a suggestion to the Minister for Transport about the possibility of using the naval aircraft, the Trackers, which have been involved with HMAS Melbourne and which will not be available or cannot be used on HMS Invincible. We have already debated in this House the absurdity of the Government's position on the purchase of HMS Invincible, which is an aircraft carrier which will not be carrying any fixed-wing aircraft. But there is available to the Australian Government the Tracker aircraft that were formerly on HMAS Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the suggestion to the Government-out of a great sense of generosity, I might say-that the Tracker aircraft formerly used on HMAS Melbourne, and which cannot be used on HMS Invincible, be used for this very important function of coastal surveillance. The Government's record on coastal surveillance is appalling. We must be the only country in the world in which the security of the country is franchised out like a pizza hut franchise to the private sector. This is Malcolm Fraserism gone mad, where the security of Australia is handed over to private enterprise, and not only to Australian private enterprise but also to foreign companies.

I should like the Government to think very carefully about this proposition. It is spending vast sums of money on defence, but the very significant feature of low-level incursions-it involves smuggling, and I do not have to go back into the Nugan Hand arguments-threats of smuggling, intrusions by fishermen, and so on, are being left to private enterprise. I do not think that any government in the world, not even the Reagan Government, with its great attachment to the Adam Smith notion of private enterprise, would accept the very fundamental proposition that the security of any country should be left to the private sector. So I now see the possibility, given that our Government has purchased HMS Invincible, which cannot take even the aircraft from the old HMAS Melbourne, that instead of providing funds to the private corporations to buy aircraft-this is a net loss to the Australian community-the Government should reorganise coastal surveillance, with these Tracker aircraft, under the proper and only authority that should be the authority responsible for coastal surveillance, which is our Defence Department.

I notice that my good friend the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) is coming into the chamber. He has an interest in the Fleet Air Arm. Perhaps he will support me when I say that the Tracker aircraft that will not be used in future by the Navy for the purpose for which they were designed should be used for coastal surveilance. In that way we should be able to maintain a Fleet Air Arm. The Fleet Air Arm would have a very serious responsibility for coastal surveillance. Australian defence and security would be stronger. This action would have much less impact on the Australian taxpayer. I hope that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson), who is at the table, will pass on to the Minister for Transport the suggestion that the Tracker aircraft be used for coastal surveillance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in hearing the comments of a former Minister of Defence and my university colleague of many years ago, the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison). I regret to say that, although my hair is not quite as white as his, there is not as much of it. The point about the Tracker aircraft is well worth examining, although I would hope that there will still be a use for the Trackers in a defence context, particularly in view of the sophisticated equipment with which they are fitted. But I should like to make a point about HMS Invincible itself, a matter on which I strongly disagree with the points made by the honourable member for St George.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for St George asserted that HMS Invincible will not be carrying any fixed-wing aircraft. At the moment, there has been no decision on whether short take-off and vertical landing aircraft-STOVLs-will be carried by that ship, because the present generation of Harriers, while having been established to be very effective in recent North Atlantic Treaty Organisation trials from HMS Invincible, nonetheless appear to be coming to the end of their effective life, in the absence of a new generation or a major upgrading of them. There is no doubt that the Government has properly said that it will not make a decision on the nature of the aircraft. If there are to be fixed-wing aircraft on HMS Invincible, no decision, naturally, is being taken about the nature of those aircraft until a clearer view is held of the prospects of the development of a new generation of STOVL aircraft.

It intrigues me that a report in a newspaper today, following a briefing by the Navy to the back bench of the Australian Labor Party yesterday, as I understand it, indicated that, after the briefing, there was some criticism by Labor members of parliament about what they claimed to be uncertainty about the naval air station at HMAS Albatross in Nowra, in my electorate. I quote from the report:
Labor MPs also said the future of the naval air station at Nowra, NSW, was uncertain because the present fixed-wing aircraft used on HMAS Melbourne would not in future be based there.
There are a few things to be said about that.

Firstly, I can remember during the last election campaign the then Labor candidate for Macarthur, quite disgracefully, raising immense uncertainty among the population of Nowra and the Fleet Air Arm in Nowra about the future of that naval air station, saying that it might well be moved to Western Australia or somewhere else because HMAS Melbourne was likely to be involved in exercises off the Western Australian coast. That was utter bunkum, but it served to make some people unnerved and unsettled.

It seems to me that any statements by any Labor members suggesting that there was any uncertainty about the future of the naval air station in Nowra are mischievous nonsense. There is an immense volume of investment going on there, whether or not there are to be fixed-wing aircraft at Nowra, and that investment is involved in providing the facilities to service the enormously increased volume of helicopters that will be in service with the Royal Australian Navy, because not only will the Invincible carry very large and very effective helicopters in its anti-submarine role, which is its major role, but also will all the frigates, the ships that the Australian Navy is taking delivery of from the United States, be equipped with helicopters as well.

An immense upgrading program is going on at HMAS Albatross, which guarantees its future. This Government is guaranteeing the future of HMAS Albatross and any attempts by the Labor Party to suggest that that is not so are in the same category as the utter nonsense that was spread around about it before the last election by the monumentally unsuccessful Labor candidate for the seat. I suggest that, if the Labor Party wants to make certain that it never has representations in the Nowra area, it should continue with that kind of rubbish about how there is alleged uncertainty about the future of HMAS Albatross. The only government that will assure the future of HMAS Albatross is this Government .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Since February 1981 right up to the present date, there have been ongoing negotiations between the Gippsland Trades and Labour Council and the State Electricity Commission of Victoria about a wide variety of matters; but, in all of these discussions, the condition of electrical plant and the continued ability of the system to keep up with demand have been an overriding consideration. These negotiations were carried on because it was well known by the SEC and the workers in the Latrobe Valley that the system was in great need of much maintenance otherwise it would be breaking down, as it had done in Victoria during last winter. We all remember back to last winter, when Victoria had great difficulties with its power supply, very similar to those which New South Wales is now experiencing. New South Wales was in a position to assist Victoria through its problems during last winter.
