ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Porta Printer Telephones for Profoundly Deaf Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to Question No. 380 (Hansard, 10 June 1981, pages 3528-9) in which I sought his assistance in having installed Porta Printer type telephones in at least each main State office and central office of each Commonwealth Government Department to enable them to receive telephonic communication from the totally or profoundly deaf, has any Commonwealth Government Department in any State installed in any office even one of these receivers; if not, why not.
(2) Will he urgently investigate the provision of these telephones in Government Departments immediately.

(3) If not, does this decision indicate that the Government is of the opinion that profoundly or totally deaf people (a) have no need to seek help or advice from Government Departments or (b) should have to be confronted in perpetuity by an impediment to communication which all other members of the community do not experience.

(4) Will action be taken before the much publicised International Year of Disabled Persons ends, and pronouncements of intent to especially redress impediments to handicapped persons recede from memory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Porta Printer units have been or will be installed by three Commonwealth Departments.

(2) and (3) Following the honourable member's earlier Question No. 380 (Hansard , 10 June 1981, pages 3528-9) an examination was undertaken to determine what the Commonwealth policy should be to the installation of Porta Printer type telephones in Central and State Offices of Departments. The conclusions of that examination included:

the Porta Printer is the only known facility available which meets specification drawn up by Telecom and the Adult Deaf Society. It is understood that the sale price of Porta Printer plus is $996 to Government Departments and commercial organisations, and $846 if sold to disabled persons and their respective institutions;
the Porta Printer can be of assistance not only to deaf people but also to those with speech impairments;
the units would be helpful in enabling Commonwealth Departments which have a high public contact role to communicate with clients who have, or who have access to, a Porta Printer;

usage of such a facility may not be particularly high in initial stages, given the small number of Porta Printers currently available in Australia, but their installation in selected Commonwealth Departments would serve to encourage wider use of the units in the general community and be an added contribution to facilitating communication with deaf persons and those with speech defects.
So far as Commonwealth Departments are concerned the following position applies :
Porta Printers were placed in the National Acoustic Laboratories in the 5 mainland States in 1980. This facility is available as a contact point for the Department of Health generally.

It is the objective of the Department of Social Security to have a Porta Printer installed in a centrally located regional office in each State and Territory. To date, units are operational in Central Office in Canberra and Adelaide. The Central Porta Printer is available for use by the Secretariat for the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped, the Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation, and the Secretariat of the IYDP National Committee for Non-Government Organisations.

The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service considers the provision of units when assessing clients, although they would only be provided when considered essential in enabling a person to acquire maximum independence in daily living and employment.
Porta Printers are to be installed in the Regional Office of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs in each State Capital and Darwin and the Sub- Regional Office in Canberra.
Consideration will be given to the requirement for Porta Printers to be installed to meet the needs of clients of other Departments which have a wide contact with the public.
Departments which have installed Porta Printer units already, or are in the process of installing them, will keep under consideration the need to install units in additional locations.

In addition, the Minister for Social Security has taken up with State and Territory Ministers responsible for International Year of Disabled Persons their support in encouraging the inclusion of a Porta Printer at all major contact points for emergency services. Co-operation in this respect is desirable given the important role played by the States in the provision of services.

(4) The action taken in relation to the more general availability of Porta Printers in Government Offices is designed to provide a special service to deaf people and certain speech impaired members of the community, and is consistent with other measures taken by the Commonwealth to assist disabled persons.
The Commonwealth has undertaken many measures to assist disabled persons over the years and will continue to do so after the International Year of Disabled Persons has ended.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Prime Minister stated in 1977 that countries wishing to reprocess Australian uranium would be required to seek Canberra's consent first.

(2) Has the Australian Government since that date, by virtue of agreements with Euratom, France and Sweden, abandoned Australia's right of veto in the case of any irregularities after consent to reprocess had been given in advance.
(3) Does the Australian Government intend to repeat this abrogation of its right to veto by signing similar agreements with Japan and Switzerland, if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 24 May 1977, the Prime Minister stated that, prior to a clearer outcome emerging from international studies and consultations including the International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation (which concluded in February 1980), it would be premature for Australia to adopt a unilateral decision on the detailed conditions under which it might be prepared to agree to reprocessing of nuclear material supplied by Australia. In order to reserve Australia's position on reprocessing for the time being, the Prime Minister added that Australia would wish to make provision in bilateral agreements with countries importing Australian uranium that any reprocessing of uranium supplied by Australia may only take place with the prior consent of the Australian Government.

(2) and (3) The Government has not abandoned Australia's prior consent rights in any of its nuclear safeguards agreements including those with Euratom, France and Sweden, as well as that with Japan which was signed on 5 March 1982.
These agreements uphold the Government's policy requirement for the provision of sanctions in the event of any breach of stipulated obligations including those related to reprocessing.

In a statement in the Parliament on 27 November 1980, I set out the conditions under which Australia would be prepared to exercise its prior consent rights over the reprocessing of Australian origin nuclear material and the controls that would apply, including the application of IAEA safeguards. The conditions and controls set out in this statement are contained in these agreements which incorporate all of the requirements of Australia's nuclear safeguards policy. The agreements have been presented in Parliament and have been the subject of detailed Ministerial statements.

The text of an agreement negotiated at official level with Switzerland is still the subject of consideration by the two Governments. All of the requirements of Australia's nuclear safeguards policy have been upheld in the negotiations with Switzerland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was it a condition of Australia's original uranium, safeguards policy announced in 1977 that uranium sold remain fully Australian owned until it was processed into a form attracting International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards inspection.
(2) If so, has this condition been fully met; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In formulating its nuclear safeguards policy the Government announced that arrangements for exports of Australian uranium should be such that the uranium will be in a form which attracts full International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards by the time it leaves Australian ownership.

(2) On 18 July 1979 the then Minister for Foreign Affairs announced that in future the export of uranium would be permitted from Australia without a requirement that Australian ownership be retained until the uranium is converted into a form suitable for fuel fabrication or enrichment. He informed the Parliament of this decision in a statement on 23 August 1979 in which he said that this requirement of the Government's safeguards policy had created unnecessary difficulties unrelated to the field of safeguards. He also explained that the Government had established a framework of control which would prove to be fully effective and maintain the integrity of Australia's stringent nuclear safeguards policy. Safeguards are not a function of ownership. Irrespective of who owns the material, Australian origin yellowcake is subject to controls and is accounted for before it is processed to the level at which it attracts full IAEA safeguards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government consent to the transfer of Australian-supplied nuclear material from the European Atomic Energy Community, or any country with which Australia has a bilateral nuclear safeguard agreement, to third countries which do not have any such agreement in force with Australia when such a transfer is for the purpose of enrichment beyond 20 per cent in the isotope uranium 235 or reprocessing; if so, what conditions will apply to this consent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: None of Australia's bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements permits the transfer of Australian supplied nuclear material to any third country which does not have a nuclear safeguards agreement in force with Australia for the purposes of enrichment beyond 20 per cent in the isotope U235 or reprocessing without Australia's prior consent. No customer country has sought Australia's consent for transfers for either of these purposes. As stated by the Prime Minister in the Parliament on 24 May 1977, the prior consent provision 'will give Australia the means of making sure that our safeguards requirements are met despite any onward transfers of the uranium we supply or nuclear material derived from it'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Prime Minister state on 25 August 1977, in reference to the Government's nuclear safeguards policy, that this policy is stricter and more rigorous than that adopted to date by any nuclear supplier country and that, by exporting uranium and standing with the United States and Canada on the crucial issue of adequate safeguards, Australia is contributing to the application of effective nuclear safeguards and to the avoidance of the misuse of nuclear materials.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to reports in Australia Broadcasting Commission radio news bulletins on 25 November 1981 that a Swiss Government spokesman had stated that Australia's safeguards conditions were less restrictive than those of Canada and in The Age newspaper of 31 December 1981 that Switzerland had to turn to new sources of fuel after Canada halted its supplies in 1977 because of disagreements over safeguards.
(3) In what respects are Australia's requirements with regard to reprocessing, retransfer and low enrichment more rigorous than or equal to those of Canada.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. During the nuclear safeguards negotiations between Australian and Swiss officials in Canberra in early December 1981, the Swiss side specifically denied comment attributed to Swiss Government officials in the ABC bulletins. In response to subsequent media reports Swiss officials voluntarily contacted the Australian Embassy in Berne to deny any suggestion that the Swiss Government had entered into negotiations with Australia because of difficulties with Canada over nuclear safeguards requirements.

(3) Australia and Canada maintain prior consent rights over reprocessing, high enrichment and retransfer to third countries of the uranium they supply. Neither country imposes special conditions on low enrichment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the nature of Australia's participation in the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) expert studies concerning an international plutonium storage scheme and international spent fuel management.

(2) What progress has been made towards the implementation of schemes for (a) international plutonium storage and (b) international spent fuel management, and what is the projected date for commencement of the schemes in each case.
(3) Have specific sites been proposed for the implementation of the schemes; if so, what are these sites.
(4) Has any Government indicated a preparedness to approve the siting of such facilities within its own territory; if so, which Governments have done so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Officers of the Australian Embassy in Vienna, of Departments in Canberra, and of the Australian Safeguards Office have participated in meetings associated with the IAEA expert studies on International Plutonium Storage and on International Spent Fuel Management. Issues in these two studies have also been the subject of consultation between Australian officials and those of other participating Governments. The Australian Government has also made a cash contribution to the IAEA of $A15,000 towards the cost of running the International Plutonium Storage study.

(2) A range of issues has been canvassed in the two studies and it is expected that reports on both will be submitted to the IAEA later this year. There is no projected date for the consideration of these reports.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In which countries, with which Australia has concluded a nuclear safeguards agreement, or to which uranium sales are proposed, does all nuclear material attract International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards.
(2) Which nuclear material does not attract IAEA safeguards in each of the remaining countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia's agreements with customer countries provide that all Australian origin nuclear material transferred under those agreements be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards in accordance with relevant agreements between the IAEA and those countries. In the case of the non-nuclear weapon states customer countries with which Australia has concluded agreements, that is Finland, Philippines, Republic of Korea, Canada, Sweden and Japan, the agreements of these countries with the IAEA are pursuant to the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty (NPT) and therefore cover all nuclear material in the entire nuclear industries of those countries. In the case of Euratom, similar safeguards arrangements are applied to the non-nuclear weapons Member States parties to the NPT pursuant to an agreement between the IAEA, Euratom and Belgium, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands.

(2) Existing nuclear weapon states recognised under the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty are not obliged by the Treaty to renounce nuclear weapons or accept international safeguards. They retain the right to use nuclear material for weapons as well as for peaceful purposes and nuclear material used for military purposes in those countries does not attract IAEA safeguards. The nuclear weapon states with which Australia has entered into bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements are France, the United Kingdom and the United States of America.

Our agreements with these three countries provide assurance that the nuclear material we may supply for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or explosive purposes and also provide that this material be covered by IAEA safeguards in accordance with agreements which they have concluded with the IAEA in respect of nuclear material in installations in their civil nuclear industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the arrangements which have been made for Australian uranium supplied to Finland to be enriched in the Soviet Union, can he say whether the Soviet enrichment facilities are not subject to International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards.
(2) Can he also say at which other facilities throughout the world, not subject to IAEA safeguards, will Australian supplied nuclear material be handled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Nuclear facilities in the USSR are not subject to IAEA safeguards. Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements with Finland, Sweden and EURATOM permit nuclear material supplied by Australia to undergo fuel cycle services in the USSR on the basis of verification that all material which goes into the USSR will be returned to a country having a nuclear safeguards agreement in force with Australia. In addition to enrichment services in the USSR, these agreements also allow for the possibility of conversion and fuel fabrication services being undertaken in the USSR. The controls under these agreements including the procedure for verification provide assurance that Australian origin nuclear material is not diverted to non-peaceful or explosive purposes. Arrangements under our other nuclear safeguards agreements provide that Australian origin nuclear material subject to the agreements will at all times be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the arrangements made by the British-Dutch- West German uranium enrichment consortium URENCO to supply Brazil with enriched uranium.

(2) In view of the arrangements which have been made for the export of uranium from the Ranger mine to the Federal Republic of Germany, is the Government prepared to approve the retransfer of Australia supplied uranium from EURATOM to Brazil.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The text of the Australia/EURATOM nuclear safeguards agreement makes clear that the Government would not be prepared to approve the retransfer of Australian supplied uranium from EURATOM to a country such as Brazil which is a non-nuclear weapon state not party to the NPT and which does not, therefore, meet our policy requirements for the negotiation of a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Military Use of Uranium Sold to United States

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the decision by the United States Government to make nuclear weapons with plutonium from civilian power plants involve the usage of any of the 4000 tonnes of uranium that Australia is contracted to sell to the United States.
(2) Will he secure assurances from the United States Government that Australian uranium will not be diverted to military or explosive uses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that the United States Government has made no decision to make nuclear weapons with plutonium obtained from civilian power plants nor is any recommendation to do so at present before it. The Deputy Assistant Secretary of Energy for Nuclear Materials, Charles Gilbert was reported in the New York Times of 28 February 1982 as stating that the Administration 'would not require' and ' has no intention of using' fuel from commercial nuclear reactors in the United States weapon program.

(2) The United States Government has accepted a legally binding Treaty commitment in the bilateral Agreement Concerning Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy signed on 5 July 1979 and presented in Parliament on 23 August 1979 that Australian uranium supplied under the Agreement will be used exclusively for peaceful non-explosive purposes.
See also answers to questions numbers 3672 and 3674, Hansard p. 411 of 18 February 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Publication of Seasonally Adjusted Unemployment Figures

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For what reasons is the practice of not publishing seasonally adjusted unemployed statistics continued.
(2) Will consideration be given to reintroducing publication of seasonally adjusted monthly unemployment and employment figures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Seasonal adjustment of the former series of quarterly unemployment estimates was suspended in 1977 because problems associated with changes in the seasonal pattern, which had accompanied the higher levels of unemployment from 1974 onwards, had rendered the figures unreliable. Subsequently (in February 1978) the quarterly labour force survey from which the unadjusted data were derived was replaced by a monthly survey.

Calculation of seasonally adjusted estimates for a statistical series requires an analysis of past figures extending over a sufficient period to enable a seasonal pattern to be identified. The new monthly unemployment and employment series have now been established for four years, which is the minimum period from which a seasonal pattern for a monthly series can be determined. Following an analysis of these figures, the Australian Bureau of Statistics proposes to commence publication of seasonally adjusted estimates of unemployment and employment from February 1982 onwards.
The seasonally adjusted data will first be published in 'The Labour Force Australia (Preliminary)' (6202.0) due to be released in either late March or early April 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the cessation of wage indexation has he directed the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay since November 1981 to examine and make recommendations on Defence Force pay and allowances following the movements in the cost of living and other community wage levels.
(2) If so, will the review coincide with the review of wages normally held in April or May under indexation.

(3) If not, will he immediately initiate the action proposed in part (1) and give guarantees to members of the Defence Force that he will not withhold references for reviews of Defence Force pay in order to defer salary adjustments for members of the Defence Force and thus reduce Departmental costs at their expense.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Committee of Reference in its Third Report dated 4 November 1981 were mindful of salary movements in the community following the abandonment of wage indexation and took account of them in its recommendations. Paragraph 12.12 of the report stated-'Including as they (the salary scales) do a component to reflect salary movements which are now becoming manifest in the public and private sectors we see no need to review Service salaries here recommended until the last quarter of 1982.' In regard to any national wage movement the committee also recommended at para 4.17 ' . . . national Wage Case decisions, where appropriate should be continued to be flowed to the Defence Force.' The Committee of Reference has therefore already comprehended in its recommendations the salary and wages movement in which you refer.
(2) and (3) Not applicable. See answer to Question 1.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Space Defence Research Facility at Pine Gap, Northern Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he made public details of military activities at the Joint United States-Australian Space Defence Research Facility at Pine Gap, Northern Territory.
(2) What is the degree of activity of Australian staff at the facility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The nature of the research programs at the Joint Defence Space Research Facility (JDSRF) at Pine Gap, its operations and the information derived from the programs are classified.
(2) At present there are 228 Australian employees at the Joint Defence Space Research Facility, out of a total staff of 455. Australian personnel participate in all aspects of JDSRF activities.
